BEST GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED

Very few pieces of media have touched me like this game has. It is very important that you don't spoil yourself going into this game, because the main appeal is the narrative.

I would describe the game as similar to Undertale in style if the main driver was tragedy and loss instead of comedy and hope. The whole game has the overarching feeling of the g-route in Undertale but more personal and melancholic.

The game is a JRPG with turn-based mechanics, but with a twist in that the dynamics are based on the emotional states of the party and enemies. I think the battle system is fun and meshes very well with the story, but if you're absolutely sick of turn-based battles then you might find it to be a drag. Although, there are no random encounters; all encounters are activated by touching enemies visible in the overworld and you basically don't need to grind, so you don't feel slowed down. I think the pacing is excellent.

The game contains very heavy themes and disturbing imagery, so keep that in mind if you're sensitive, especially to depictions of depression and suicide. It's a psychological horror game, but the horror elements ultimately serve to make you sad, not scared, although it can be pretty frightening.

The artstyle is supremely charming but watch the trailers to form your own opinion. The music is also fantastic. The game has a couple of different routes which gives it some replay value, but the central mystery is the main appeal and this can be approached through two main routes. Expect your first playthrough to give you at least 20 hours of gameplay if you don't rush through, and probably 50 hours if you want to see everything.

I am still in the middle of playing this game, but I know enough that I have enjoyed everything it throws at me, whether it be wholesome interactions between young friends in the headspace or the traumas that silently creep up behind these wholesome interactions. Now I already knew that this was going to be a depressive game from the start, and that this game can give people depression. That was completely fine, as I am feeling a bit depressed myself, and I like to play emotionally intense games, especially ones with mental illness themes. It helps a lot with putting myself in the place of other people like the characters within this game, and it allows me to feel more seen with the mental state I am in. I guess that says a lot about me to play these games mentally unwell lol.

One emotion that remained constant throughout the time I played this game is the empathy. I relate too much with the characters that I feel sort of fucked up in that way. Sunny's fears and loneliness, Aubrey's [spoiler]sense of being misunderstood and[/spoiler] raw emotion, Basil's anxieties. They all remind me of myself. The game does really well in exercising the short and long term effects of anxiety, depression, and loneliness through the eyes of the protagonist. It does it in a manner that is not over exaggerated. Each character has a mountain of depth waiting to be unpacked in the scope of OMORI's breadth. During your exploration of the game's maps, you can listen along with the amazing soundtracks that have been a joy to hear, ranging from chill adventure music to intense bangers of boss fight music. The world building is resonating enough to exude nostalgia to those who long for the days when they could have the imagination of a young child.

Despite what many say about turn based combat, I find it exciting, especially with the feature of utilizing emotions to lay out a strategy against common foes and challenging bosses alike. It not only adds some difficulty, but it feels unique in the way that the game portrays emotion in combat. It integrates the game's thematic focus on emotions into the gameplay itself.

EDIT: My opinions of this game have drastically changed since originally writing this review so I edited it to be more in-line with my current thoughts and feelings about OMORI.

No, I'm not bawling my eyes out at 3 in the morning. You are!

OMORI is truly a game you have to experience to understand. 
I don't know how to feel about it. The story is both heartwarming and heart-shattering at the same time. 
Seriously, if you somehow haven't gotten this game spoiled for yourself, go play it, now. It is one of the most emotionally powerful games I have ever played and one of the few games that made me genuinely sob at multiple points in the game. I don't know how a story can go from 0 to 100 that quickly without feeling some tonal whiplash, but somehow, someway, OMORI pulls this off brilliantly multiple times. It portrays trauma, guilt, depression and fear so well that I just stared at the screen processing what the hell I just saw multiple times. The "something" that follows you around the whole game is absolutely terrifying at times with me being unable to move in-game and irl out of fear.
It sucks that this story unfortunately trips at the finish line. The big reveal at the end of the game is great, but it just leaves a plot hole that can sort of be ignored if you squint really hard. I won't say what the plot hole is for spoiler reasons, but it's a plot hole that exists depending on how you look at the game. If the stars aligned perfectly in the game's story, then this plot hole technically doesn't have to exist.

The gameplay is not as amazing as the story. The battle system is great, but everything else in terms of gameplay is just okay.
The battle system, like I said, is great, however the battles themselves are... not that great. Like, the boss fights are amazing, they are some of the game's highlights, but the battles against regular enemies are just too short and easy for me to actually think about what I'm doing. Most regular battles are just spamming attack with all of my characters until the enemy dies. The boss fights are great because doing only that isn't going to work. I actually have to think about what skills synergize with what and what emotions my characters should have (I know, strategy in a turn-based RPG, crazy right?). It's a shame that the game doesn't have that many really hard bosses, because that's when I had the most fun with the battles. 
Now, the gameplay outside of the battles, isn't much better. It's split into two parts: the Headspace segments and the Faraway Town segments. One of them happens in the protagonist's head and the other one is in the real world. 
The Headspace segments are great but man do they drag on for wayyy too long. Like, some areas could be completely cut from the Headspace segments and the game would honestly benefit from it. A lot of them are just filled with boring padding where nothing meaningful happens. Like, in terms of the game's story, that makes sense. It's the protagonist trying to supress all the messed up thoughts that he has. But this translates to the gameplay being so god damn boring sometimes. Thankfully, the Faraway town segments are amazing. I don't have many complaints about them because it's where stuff actually happens and characters actually develop. 
One thing I can't stand in both of the worlds is backtracking. I missed SO MUCH content on my first playthrough solely because I almost never went back to areas I already explored. Sure, that's kinda my problem for the most part but it was a little frustrating missing an entire area because I missed a train station in the very first area of the game. Although, I will give the game credit, if you're someone who looks around everywhere and I mean EVERYWHERE, then there is a good chance you will be rewarded for your curiosity.

However, unlike the gameplay this game's soundtrack rocks! There are so many good songs in this OST. Especially the boss themes. 
A lot of songs utilize leitmotifs in such clever ways where I can't even tell it's supposed to sound like another song from the OST, but when you listen closely you can hear it and it's awesome. For example, I love how the Faraway Park theme has this part which sounds so similar to the Headspace Playground theme yet it also sounds nothing at all like that theme.
And oh man, the way this game uses music to play with your emotions is just soul crushing. It knows exactly when to play THAT theme (if you know, you know) and I would be lying if I said I didn't start sobbing when it starts playing.

The visuals are also amazing. Most of the game is in pixel art which is really good, especially the animations, but the battles and cutscenes have this hand-drawn looking style which I absolutely adore. It makes me wish the whole game was in this art style. 
I also love the animations that visualize attacks in battles because almost each attack has it's own unique animation which adds so much charm into an otherwise visually bland battle system.
The game also uses low quality realistic photos for some backgrounds and joke enemies which are pretty funny imo.

[h1]TLDR[/h1]
The story's great with one big "idk how I feel about it" flaw and the gameplay is perfectly servicable. Music goes hard and the art style is fantastic. Probably gave me depression for the next couple of months. Definitely recommend.

It's good despite the filler.

Overall, OMORI is a kind-of a gem, or in other words, a ride that deserves it's spot of "Top 3 of Psychological Horror", despite the horror factor not being constant. It's a rough diamond, but easily a must-play if you haven't seen *any* spoilers before stumbling here. It's perfect if you waltz in blind.

No, it's not Undertale, and i know that it's promotion (and some of the early-game, be that with Something or... anything else) makes it seem childish. It isn't that.

It's a generally well-written game with a quite likeable cast, making you feel bad for said cast, it has room for interpretation and discussion, nice art, good music, interesting-ish plot, pretty high attention to detail, leitmotifs that count as detail, foreshadowing, and memorable events of a variety. Basic things being complimented as if they were unique, i know, but the game just does well in all aspects.
When it hits a peak, it hits a peak. The moments where the game is at it's best are just perfect.
All of that meshes together pretty well.

A bit of the type where the player would wish to lose their memory to re-experience it. 

The large amounts of good is dulled and dented by a few things, one of the more apparent issues being the *slow* beginning the game has, along with non-excellent pacing on some other parts, which causes people to say that the entire game feels like a slog. I didn't really notice that, aside from minor annoyance during some parts that people generally liked, which is... funny? Sort-of?

Shouldn't forget about the issues that rise if you aren't bent towards what the game wants you to feel, or just having a distaste towards a few aspects.
Though, as you somehow will not notice any of the mild issues and inconsistencies that don't change much (if you even realise they exist, that is), you'll be fine, because there is stuff to awe over. As i said, the game's a ride, and besides, most people weren't bothered by it at all.

Ignoring the last (negative) part, it's certainly one of the better games that i have played recently, maybe ever. The positive traits make up a great game, which... well, obviously has something to do with the Overwhelmingly Positive ratings and some people describing it to be life-changing. I don't know if the game is "lighting caught in a bottle", but some feel like it is. The negative traits or issues don't ruin it, but you can easily have an issue with them. 

There's a reason that i kind of had an obsession with the game (Or "brainrot"), as have other people, despite some of the things that i had disliked. I won't actually mention them particularly, because, in-case somebody actually reads this, their experience could be tainted.

Also, maybe ignore that about... 36~% of the players reached the ending, i can't say how or why. 



And... that's it. Feel free to ask questions, as the comments are not locked.
Maybe look at the other positive reviews of the game if you want to, though, they are *far* more positive. Negative ones also tend to lead too heavily into negativity, so it would be hard to find a balanced take.

Alright, have a good day.




7/9/23 EDIT: Removed a *lot* of text that could be considered bloat, 75% of which was ranting.
Later edits: Grammar fixes, additions, overall readability.

I've already beat this game like twice on my switch, and I'm about to do it again on PC.

But seriously though, this game has to be one of the best RPG games I've played to date, and that's really saying something considering I don't usually prefer RPG-type games. Admittedly, the combat does get mildly boring after a while, but I feel like OMORI easily makes up for that in its story. So much so to the point where I've literally witnessed myself become emotionally attached to one of the main characters. Hell, I would go as far as saying that this game quite literally has changed my life. Because if I had never seen or got interested in this game, I would've never met my partner. (I love you, Parsley. <3)

I'd say that this game's a 9.5/10.

This is overall the best game I have ever played in my whole life. I know that might sound a little dramatic but just listen. The story line and game play is very compelling, It really is worth the money. It's a long game with many different hidden secrets and achievements that you can gather. It does take a lot of game play and commitment though, but that's what I think makes it so great. It really builds the story line into detail and helps you get to know the characters well. It's definitely not a game where you get bored easily. I highly recommend this game if you're into psychological horror and story games. The end really just made me burst into tears. OMORI is a captivating experience that challenges you to think critically about your mental health and how it affects your entire being as well as the lives of those you love. It actively discourages false positivity, toxic nostalgia, and mental repression. You cannot "fight" away your past or sweep it under the rug; you [u] MUST[/u] face it head-on, no matter how much it may hurt or how devastating the consequences may be. We're also talking well beyond the realm of mere uncomfortability, as OMORI deals with some very dark and traumatic subject matter. Despite this, OMORI also advocates for patience, understanding, and personal responsibility, reminding us that those we love will be there for us when we need them, and, as painful as it can be, reality will always be more comforting than a world built on falsehoods.

Some things I like: I like OMORI's soundtrack. A lot. It is atmospheric, unsettling, sentimental, emotional, and heart-pumping (in more ways than one.) Some of my favorite battle themes are It Means Everything, World's End Valentine, GOLDENVENGEANCE, You Cannot Go Back, Underwater Prom Queens, [spoiler] OMORI [/spoiler], and Whale Whale Whale. Some of my favorite other themes are Remember to be Patient, H20:HCL, A Home for Flowers (Daisy), Sinking, Lost at a Sleepover, Poems in the Fog, Clean Slate, and Spaces In-Between. The skillfully crafted hand-drawn art present in battles and interspersed cutscenes is nicely evocative of a children's book. Also, major kudos to OMORI for not using the common trope of disparaging medication and/or therapy. I don't agree with stories about mental health that put down real-life resources that can make a significant positive impact on people who are suffering.

Some spoilers follow:

[spoiler] My biggest gripes with the game are with its pacing and certain aspects of the real world. Some RPG sections drag on for too long, and as the combat/gameplay is quite simplistic (but still satisfying, I must mention), you might find yourself wanting the pace to pick up a bit. This was more of an issue for me in my first playthrough, as the psychological horror-tinted teases for what really happened are so tantalizing that I wanted to get to the truth as quickly as possible. One thing I commend the devs for is how quickly you earn EXP, especially towards the end. Grinding never felt like a slog. As for the real world, I found some of it too silly for my liking. The game clearly wants to have its off-kilter, Earthbound-esque indie RPG small town with all of the wacky trappings like fighting other kids and doing part-time jobs (which is strange in and of itself for someone who hasn't left their home in 4 years to want to do), but I felt this approach didn't mesh well with the extremely silly and bizarre Headspace existing already. I would've appreciated it if the real-world segments were just a touch more mundane or perhaps more complexly written to be better balanced out against the dream world. That being said, there were segments of the real-world I really enjoyed, such as Basil's despondency and especially how they handled real-world Aubrey and her struggle to navigate her dissonant feelings of abandonment, grief, and justified rage. [/spoiler]

Through effective use of symbolism, humor, and horror, OMORI's impactful story encourages healthy responses to trauma and guilt. Things can get better, but it's up to us and how we want to handle confronting our issues.

I finished this game on Chirsmas Day 2022 (which was exactly 2 years after the game's release) and I can easily say, it is the most emotional piece of media I have ever experienced. It has been haunting me for over an year and it comes periodically back in my life from time to time. While gameplay wise it isn't anything special - a classic turn-based JRPG, with some rather interesting rock-paper-scissors-like fighting system, it's the heartbreaking, yet also extremely funny at times, story, phenomenal sountrack, that will follow you years after you have finished the game and it's unorthodox, yet legendary art style, what take this game on a whole new level to other RPGMaker products. Easily an experience, that you will think about for years to come and you will not forget.

[h1] Omori: A Truly Amazing Game with a Quick Twist [/h1]

[b] Introduction [/b]

Omori is a captivating RPG Maker game that has been making waves in the gaming community. With its cute and colorful presentation, it may seem like a lighthearted adventure at first glance. However, beneath its charming exterior lies a dark and thought-provoking narrative that tackles themes of depression, anxiety, and suicide. In this review, we will quickly explore the various aspects of Omori and delve into why it has garnered such praise and recognition.

[b] Gameplay and Storytelling [/b]

One of the standout features of Omori is its ambitious storytelling structure. The game quickly takes players on a journey through the mind of the protagonist, exploring his inner struggles and emotions. The narrative unfolds in a non-linear fashion, allowing players to uncover the mysteries of the world at their own pace. The game seamlessly blends elements of traditional RPG gameplay with psychological horror, creating a unique and immersive experience.

[b] Visuals and Sound Design [/b]

Visually, Omori is a treat for the eyes. The game features vibrant and colorful graphics that contrast with the dark themes it explores. The character designs are charming and memorable, adding to the overall appeal of the game. The soundtrack is equally impressive, with a hauntingly beautiful score that perfectly complements the atmosphere of the game. The combination of stunning visuals and captivating music creates a truly immersive and emotionally charged experience.

[b] Reception and Recommendation [/b]

Omori has received widespread acclaim from both critics and players alike. It has been praised for its compelling storytelling, unique gameplay mechanics, and thought-provoking themes. The game's ability to tackle sensitive topics with sensitivity and depth has resonated with many players, making it the best title in the RPG genre.

However, it's important to truly note that Omori may not be for everyone. the game did contain depictions of depression, anxiety, and suicide, which may not be suitable for all audiences. It also included bright flashing imagery that may be triggering for some individuals.

In conclusion, Omori is a gem of a game that should be recognized for its innovative storytelling, captivating visuals, and emotional depth. It offers a unique and thought-provoking experience that will leave players reflecting long after they have finished playing. However, it's important to quickly approach the game with an open mind and be aware of its sensitive content. If you're looking for the best game that RPGs have to offer and explores complex themes, Omori is definitely worth checking out.

INTRODUCTION: When this game released i never thought much of it i ocasionally looked at it thinking it would have a good story and be kinda fun, but never bought it. One day it was my brothers birthday, i bought omori for him. He tried a bit but never played it, my sister got omori too she quit too. 1 year later i got it. It was pretty fun, then that got my brother to play in about a week i quit on sweetheart while my brother beat it, and he said it was one of his favorites ever. Eventually about 3 months later i got on and finally beat sweetheart. After that it was an AMAZING expirence. Once i beat humphrey. I finally got to the end of the game. Without giving spoilers lets just say i got the  "Abandoned ending" i was mad. Then i watched the good ending. Finally about a 4 months later i decided to beat it again. That time i flew through the game beating it in 15h. I got the good ending and it was offically my favorite game ever. 

Story
The story is amazing probably one of the best stories ever it tricks you into thinking its a happy game. The charachters are so amazingly designed that it feels like they are actually real and you feel emotion when somthing drastic happens to one of them.

Gameplay
Some people are not a fan of the fighting style (it is an rpg) in my opinion its very fun its sort of a pokemon style fighting based of turns. Most rpg games have some sort of "this is weak to this and that" this game uses emotions which is highly unique.

Omori is a flawed masterpiece.

It is an incredible game that is often poorly paced. It both opens and closes incredibly well, but the middle sections of the game were often dull. Its 20h story could easily be cut down with the removal of certain moments, or even entire areas, to make for a more focused experience, which would solve almost all of its issues. Additionally, random combat encounters feel entirely unnecessary, and removing them would help to bring the game closer to a more appropriate 10-12h runtime, and only make the boss fights, which are mostly really good, feel even more significant.

However, despite these issues with pacing, Omori’s story is an incredible one, which tackles its themes with incredible precision. It’s very difficult for me to properly express the exact reasons for which the game’s story is so good, without spoiling it, but I can say that its last 3h were what properly convinced me that Omori is an incredible game. Backing that brilliant story is a phenomenal soundtrack. It features a lot of music traditional for a pixel rpg, with a very fitting, psychedelic touch. It really shines, though, in the game’s boss fights and more significant story moments – again, especially in those last 3h or so. And the game’s visual art is exceptional, featuring vivid pixel art and beautiful hand-drawn images, which effectively convey the emotions of the story. 

Ultimately, Omori is a phenomenal game which, despite poor execution in some moments, wholly deserves the high praise it receives.

I don't normally write reviews, but my hours played reached a particular number right now and I needed to have it saved.

Anyway, I don't know if the game will work for you. All I know is that it worked really well for me. It's the only story I know that really made me feel something.
But I am going to give a spoiler-free list of a few things I wish I knew during my first playthrough:
[list]
    [*]To reach the Good ending, the only things that matter are that you open the door to Kel on the first and second morning, and that you don't go back to sleep or go outside during the sleepover at Basil's house. Everything else is fair game. Nothing that happens in Headspace will matter in the long run.
    [*]At one point you'll reach a game of opening randomly strewn doors. Open every black door before touching the red one. You'll recognize the last black door in that it takes place on a playground.
    [*]Install Photo Album Extended mod. It makes one of the best parts of the game even better by letting you read the hidden descriptions of photos at the end.
    [*]Avoid reading anything about Sunny, Mari, or Basil, if you care about spoilers. I thought I didn't and I regret it to this day.
[/list]

I don't write reviews but I needed to get my feelings out for this game. OMORI is something special and a labor of love.

The artstyle in this game is amazing. The pencil-sketched aesthetic has an unassuming quality that perfectly matches the world we see through the eyes of a child. When the game starts to reveal its cards, certain figures and objects have jarringly different styles that help emphasize the dissonance. Color and motifs are carefully planned and packed full of symbolism, more than I know how to talk about.

Music is absolutely banging. The bossfight tracks are especially great, super hype when half your team is toast and you're desperately trying to hold on. Throughout the story, you hear a certain melody, in various incomplete/distorted electronic forms. Then you reach this certain point in the game, [spoiler] after everything has built up to a climax, you finally hear the full, clear, instrumental song, [/spoiler] and the emotional weight hits you like a truck. That's probably my favourite moment in the game.

Difficulty was just right. Hard enough to keep you engaged but never a real struggle. There's some leeway in team builds, if you don't care about combat I'm pretty sure Omori's SAD POEM + Kel's MEGAPHONE wipes the floor with most enemies. Progression is natural and there's not much backtracking. 

I love all the little details in this game, from the punny enemy designs that are plays on words, to how all the sprite designs in battle have small variations depending on what emotions you inflict on them, to the goofy side quests and characters, to obscure interactions like Kel using FLEX will cause the muscle mussel enemies to lower their attack because they're insecure.

I won't say anything about the main story itself. Not because it falls short,that couldn't be more opposite. Absolutely go into it blind, don't look for any more details. You won't be disappointed.

OMORI gave me wishful nostalgia for memories I never had, and wry smiles at the quirky humor. It broke my heart utterly and gave me hope at the same time. And it told a powerful message I'll be thinking about for a long time. Please play this game.

The quick pitch I would have for this game is "MOTHER 3 but with even more depression somehow" but I feel that's selling it a bit short. As a JRPG, the mechanics of the game are just as well though out, even if battle balance tends to be on the easy side and fights tend to drag as you progress through the game. Yes, it's a game about somewhat real, somewhat fake Americana (tm) that sometimes veers into trite territory, and the NPC-to-NPC, setpiece-to-setpiece quips and humor seem like a mirror image of that series. If OMORI was just trying to be a carbon copy of that series, I wouldn't be writing this, but as you may be able to tell, there's more than that to this game.

OMORI opts to do something that its inspirations (or nearly any other game) didn't, couldn't, and wouldn't do: pull you in and suffocate you with its horrifyingly dark undercurrent. The scenario for this game is horror in its rawest sense, drip-feeding you implications about the story that only manage to get darker. Making the player choke up in terror from the storytelling, art direction and music when all is revealed is its greatest accomplishment, delivering point-blank one of the best endings and emotional payoff in a video game ever.

[spoiler]...or you could just not get this payoff. There's a way to just not resolve the plot and live in denial, failing everyone and persisting in the doomed escapism you created. For a game about undercurrents, the darkest and deepest undercurrent is one that most players won't even see, but the mere existence of makes me legitimately nauseous.[/spoiler]

OMORI's biggest strength is its wonderful (albeit potentially disturbing) story that remains profound in spite of how it is fully reliant on a single twist at the end of the game. In addition, OMORI's soundtrack has to be one of the best in any indie game of the 21st century, with multiple vibrant areas robust with unique audio design. However, OMORI is also plagued by a fair share of gameplay issues commonly associated with games of its kind: being that the game may feel long-winded and bloated during certain segments not directly linked to the main story. Be that as it may, while OMORI may not be the best game for those of the faint of heart or with shorter attention spans, the enthralling tale it tells makes the game perfect for those who prioritise storytelling in gaming above all.

Omori is a deeply imaginative and complex game. While parts of it are lighthearted fun, each new bit of information you get unveils a much more serious story as well. It's just as dark as it is whimsical!

I played this because I was doing the same thing as Sunny, holing myself up for over a year, and I was curious what direction the game would go. I won't say it changed my life or anything, but it was clear that this is a one of a kind experience, and it really did blow me away. It's a heartbreaking story of grief, acceptance, and a kind of horror that is horrifying because of how real it is.

This isn't a story that tries to make you feel good or tie up all the loose ends neatly by the end. Instead, you can't help but cry alongside the characters with the same pain and reflect on everything that happened afterwards.

Sunny definitely reminded me a lot about myself and reminded me about what it takes to truly move forward from painful memories. I'm still doing my best to keep at it. 🙂

If it weren't for me playing NieR:Automata prior to this, it would have easily taken the spot for my favorite game and that's only really due to my personal preferences. These two are the only games that I truly enjoyed down to the last detail. They are such different games though, that there isn't much of a point to comparing them because they're so phenomenal in their own ways.

If you want to think about life for a bit or you like being depressed, then go ahead and play the game. If you don't, then you [b]should[/b] play the game.

This has to be one of the saddest games I've ever played. Absolutely immaculate storytelling, and gut-wrenching dialogue. When you play this game, everything comes together absolutely perfectly to make you legitimately feel emotions. Anger, when you're forced to leave as basil is begging you to stay, everybody acting like mari was fine in dreamworld, and the absolutely incredible foreshadowing in the lost library.

What a cheery yet sadness inducing game, I do quite like the types of games that give me a melancholic or "nostalgic" feeling while playing and this game definitely made me feel so, and of course I should mention great music.
There's a kind of 'charm' with how text or combat is 'delayed' or 'slowed' a bit, though it gets a little bit irritating when farming the 50th Squizzard. 

One thing I don't understand is how this game doesn't have steam cards nor any emojis or stuff you'd expect from other games, there was definitely care put into the achievements yet no steam cards or emojis / steam backgrounds? And there's apparently exclusive console content for Omori as well... a big pity it's not on the steam version..

A very good game with breathtaking visuals. 
I enjoyed it a lot, especially the parts in which the game showed and made me explore the twisted mind of Omori. 

Only downside to the game, in my opinion, is that it kinda “forces you” to be good at fighting and managing boss fights. First of all,  there is no save button right before boss fights, meaning that if you need to setup your characters differently, you have to lose a lot of progress. Second of all, bossfights are hard, and in my opinion they kind of interrupt the flow of the storyline (not mentioning all the fights during exploration).

Apart from this small imperfection, the story is amazing, I felt shivers multiple times from how involving and well designed the scenery and music were. 

Definitely one of the games that got me caught up emotionally the most, very highly suggest it.

game was cool... the wait was a bit long for my liking but i'm not disappointed.
cool things about the game:
- very good art. the style is very pleasing.
- banger soundtrack (favorite track is Fermentation Disorientation)
- story was very heart breaking, would experience the pain again fresh if i could.
- battle system is good, the follow-up commands are ok, i use the same tactic most of the time though.
somewhat annoying things about the game (for me): 
- i'm not a big fan of fullscreen so, i do wish the regular window size was a little bigger, and didn't have those black bars on the side.
- some areas are way too dark for me to see anything, though i can understand its really for atmosphere and its intended but i wish it was a little brighter as my computer brightness doesn't help.
- post-game areas feel very unfinished. I can understand why, but still a bit disappointed.

would i recommend it? yeah, enjoyed every hour of this game. exploring was fun too, found a lot of cool and scary things and the side quests were a bit fun too, my favorite was the ghost party one.

I decided to pick up Omori because of it's unique and charming art direction. After completing it, I can tell you that this title has loads more to offer than just its visual flair. 
The story depicted in Omori is quite gripping with a healthy dose of humour added in just the right places. However when the narrative requires it, the funny quips and one-liners are cast aside in favour of powerful writing that will most definitely tug at your heart strings. Omori was capable of making me laugh, bringing me to a verge of tears and make me tremble in fear. 
Moreover to give credit where credit is due the gameplay is very fun and creative. One criticism that could be levied at Omori's combat system is the amount of random encounters which at times got a bit tedious to say the least. This issue is especially prevalent when backtracking through a location. However it is important to mention that this did not make me dislike Omori's gameplay, quite the contrary. Even if repetitive at times, the combat and exploration were very fun and rewarding. The bossfights were also a highlight of my experience with the game. Every boss we face in Omori is beautifully designed and full of personality.
As i have mentioned the art style is also a major apeal of the game. Every character is unique not only in how they are written but also how the look. In other words the visuals perfectly complement the narrative. The same applies to a certain degree to the enemies we face during our journey through the Headspace. Although some more variety in this case would be a welcome change it isn't a major criticism on my behalf. Especially taking into account that this is addressed by the creatively nightmarish creations we sometimes get to face. I will gladly accept quality over quantity and let me tell you that quality is most definitely what we get.   
To summarise Omori is overall an amazing, fun and emotionally engaging experience. I wholeheartedly recommend it.

Imagine yourself as a child. You have friends with whom you'd spend time regularly just because it's what you all naturally want. You all live in a small town where everything is a walk away. You have the most nurturing, fulfilling childhood that humans can have together. But you cause a grave accident that brings about its destruction. You lose everything about which you care and bury the past in the deepest, fragmented recesses of your mind, hoping to never find them again. A few days before you move away, years later, you're faced with the choice to heal from the past and rekindle what was, or hide in thoughts forever.

Now, imagine playing Omori: an experience that's as much of an idealist-existentialist as it is a pessimistic fatalist. The happy moments are satisfying, nostalgic, and extremely funny thanks to plenty of bizarre humor, and the sad moments are, aside from being macabre and grotesque, spawned from the loss thereof. This experience uniquely juxtaposes both the good and bad parts of living, in equally vivid and saturated ways, to breed nostalgic love, and painful regret. The experience is augmented by the brilliantly intelligent and intricate intertwining of visual and sonic motif, and verbal profundity, all of which elaborate on an overarching cacophonous symphony of a tale which can ultimately be interpreted as an ideological epitome for living one's life. With every possible artistic trick employed, Omori is one of the most real representations of the complete continuum of the human experience: good and bad, happy and sad, nostalgia and crippling anxiety, hope and regret--life and death.

Thank you all for sacrificing your time, effort, and artistic virtuosity to create an experience to share with so many people. Thank you for making Omori.

Pros:
- great atmosphere
- makes you cry
- easy on the hands, no need to fight intensely since it's strategy-based
- beautiful soundtrack that I listen to regularly
- interesting story
- nice animation 
- unique style
- cheaper than therapy sessions
- insanely good at understanding your depression, anxiety and phobia's. I felt really seen and a little less alone. 
- interesting characters
- tonal shifts are done well

cons:
- battle system gets old after a while
- if you want to do a different routes/endings, the main section of the game can feel somewhat long. (although a tip for reaching alternate endings from me would be to keep a separate save near the end) 

I really enjoyed this game. It's heartbreaking and sad and sometimes disturbing, but it really understands how depression feels like. The story was very captivating and mysterious until the end. The game is both really comforting and unsettling, and does a good job of making you scared and (intentionally) confused. The different endings really put perspective into how one's mind can work, how even slightly different circumstances can change so much. It also doesn't try hard to be a cool game or to appeal to certain people; it's story is one that, I suspect, the creator wanted to tell, rather than a company wanting to sell merch. Overall, I would recommend this game a lot, especially if you like things like Undertale.

some things to note in terms of trigger warnings, if you're like me and want to be informed well: (mild spoilers)
- The game has themes and imagery that some would consider disturbing. If you can't look at things like gore, blood, and have trouble with seeing themes of anxiety, suicide and depression, I would recommend leaving the game be until you're better able to process it. However, Omori never romanticizes these themes. It's part of the story, and if you're feeling down, it might feel good to be understood. 
- People with arachnophobia might be scared by this game. I myself am terrified of spiders, and got jumpscared a little. That being said, it's never insanely scary, at least to me.

I will try to keep this to a minimum, but this is the saddest and most touching game I have ever played. Compared to games like Resident Evil or Silent Hill this may look cute and kid-friendly but do NOT think that. This game is very deep with its topics of grief, depression, suicide, and trauma. These themes are mainly in the later half of the game with them being extremely sad and even the "good" ending still being extremely dreary to watch. I have never played a turn-based RPG and I probably won't again unless Omocat makes a sequel because this game is so damn good. The combat uses different emotions such as Anger, Happiness, and Sadness which all have their benefits such as sadness giving you more defense, and anger giving you more attack power. The horror elements in this game are very well executed with jumpscares being at a lower rate, with dread and tension taking hold. The story of this game is incredibly great with a cast of likable characters, a sad and interesting plot, and an ending that is honestly the worst part of the game depending on how you feel about it. Speaking of endings there are multiple with varying degrees of depression they will leave on you. 
Enough blabbering this game is amazing and please buy it and go in BLIND. You won't forget it. 10/10

I just going to start off by saying I have played many video games. Up till now I have never wrote a review in my life. This game, is the most incredible, gut wrenching, most emotional game anyone will ever play. Words cannot do justice to how incredible and depressing this game is. As someone who has dealt with suicidal ideation, depression, and loneliness, I can confidently say this game does the best job at portraying these subject matters. I have never cried to a video game, not even a piece of media. This not only made me cry but broke me. I love this game. I love every character, as they are all given personalities and motivations. They feel like real people. This game is the greatest game to ever be released, it may even be one of the greatest expressions of art. I don't care who you are, play this game. You wont regret it.

A game about trauma, denial and eventually overcoming it.
The art ingame is awesome, love the pastel colour palette; which one generally doesn't see in games. The music is fun too.
If I need to give some critiques, some parts felt a bit confusing, as in where to go and what to do. Some parts were a bit tedious, (having to walk around... do this and that, stuck at things that feel like they don't contribute to the story, etc.), and I personally felt the ending was a bit too confusing/open to my liking. But that is a personal preference.

This game is wild in the sense that it tries it's best to balance extremely childish humour and banter, with extremely dark topics relating to depression and trauma. Sometimes the shift from goofy and pleasant to depressing and terrifying can be... jarring.

So, in conclusion... Well... Let's just say that after playing this game, I too, have received some trauma I need to overcome...
No, seriously, I came in with a very specific view and expectation of how this game would be, and the fact it ended up so differently is... My worldview is shattered. It's a great game but I don't know if I have the heart to ever play it again. I don't know if that's a good thing or a bad thing. I genuinely need to recover.
But the fact that a game did this is... quite impressive. Well done Omocat.

Absolutely gorgeous! The ending fully caught me by surprise and shocked me to my core. [spoiler] Having to accept Sunny's past and guilt as technically my own in real time with the peak of his internal battle- it's really something else. Because what do you do with that? How the hell do you live with that? [/spoiler] Learning what even some of the simple prevalent imagery actually meant throughout the game? Haunting, chilling, brutal.

Here's the thing about this game too: A large chunk of the play through is this really fun pokemon-esk adventure/party battle sim with cool quests and everything and you can feel there's a meta-textual layer going on behind everything, but the game was able to lure me into this false sense of security for long stretches of time battling critters and exploring. So when the psychological thriller parts DO happen, it's like everything grinds to a halt. And I remember that I, like Omori, am escaping something dark and inevitable.

I highly recommend giving this a try. It's well paced, extremely fun, with an emotional story that will grab your heart with both hands and not let go.

i've only finished one of the endings so far but oh, my god. this game is really extraordinary. i've cried so many times while i've played it, to where i get all choked up. you really get attached to the characters
there's a lot of good with this game. the art style is soft and cute for the most part, eerie at others, and it's so nice and fits so well. the soundtrack is amazing, i listen to it a lot outside of playing. the characters, again, are all great. it's really hard to choose a favorite because they're all so wonderful. the story is so good, and there's more than just the main plot -- there's lots of side quests that you can do, which makes the game replayable.
idk. all in all, omori is an incredible game and i highly recommend it even if it will tear your heart out and smash it into pieces (and then put it back together). it's very depressing and you should heed the warnings, but it left me feeling hopeful.

OMORI is like, THE game you gotta try, it's all warm and heartbreaky. 🎢 The story's like a rollercoaster of emotions, from cozy to super intense in a blink. Seriously, if you haven't spoiled it for yourself, go play it NOW. It's like, crazy emotional and made me legit sob at points. 😭 The "something" following you around? Absolutely terrifying. I couldn't even move in-game or in real life, total fear vibes. 😱

Okay, so the story trips a bit at the end, leaving a plot hole you can kinda ignore if you squint really hard. No spoilers, though! 🙈 Gameplay is okay, not as wow as the story. Boss fights are awesome, but regular battles are just a quick spam fest. The Faraway Town segments are where things happen, so yay for that! 🌟

Headspace segments drag a bit, like, could've cut some parts for the game's benefit. Faraway Town bits are where the magic's at, with character development and stuff. Backtracking? A bit frustrating, but if you're a super curious explorer, you'll find cool rewards. 🕵️‍♀️

Now, the soundtrack rocks! 🎶 Boss themes are on point, and the clever leitmotifs in songs are mind-blowing. The music knows when to hit you in the feels, and it's just soul-crushing in the best way. 💔

Visually, it's a pixel art wonderland with cool hand-drawn style in battles and cutscenes. Unique animations in battles add charm to an otherwise visually simple system. Low-quality realistic photos in the background? Hilarious! 🎨

TLDR: Great story with a quirky flaw, gameplay's cool, music rocks, and the art style is fantastic. Probably left me in a mood for a while. Totally recommend it! 🌈✨

This game isn't as great as the fanbase would like to you believe. The pacing is tedious, the characters are based on overused tropes and their relationships are shallow. Two thirds of the game you're obliged to grind and get through mind-numbing combat and an even more lackluster story, only to realise it was nearly completely irrelevant to the actual plot and is a complete waste of time. Getting to the plot twist/climax is not worth your time either.

The art and music are nice, if they made the last bit of it into a short game or VN and all the pointless fluff before that were erased it would be much better, or at the very least more bearable.

Most of all I condemn how the topic of self-harm was tackled and portrayed throughout the story. It was mostly disrespected and abused as a cheap shock tool and if not that used as a way to make the audience feel pity.

TL:DR; An amazing story game with just the right amounts of mystery, twists and horror/anxiety. For the best experience don't spoil yourself at all until you have reached the credits. Overall I'd say it's a must-have if you want to experience a great story

Pros and Cons here at the beginning, full review below.

Pros:
- Probably the best story I have ever experienced
- Great artstyle (a mixture of a pixel art overworld and hand-drawn cutscenes)
- Amazing soundtrack
- Unique mechanics
- Indie developers
- Cheap price
- Long (15-35 hours for a first playthrough, depending on how much time you spend on side-quests)
- 2 drastically different routes and several endings depending on your choices
- Perfect difficulty (easy if you take your time getting equipment/upgrades, hard if you rush through it)

Cons:
- Gameplay can get repetitive after a while
- Some achievements are grindy/annoying to get
- Some parts of the game can feel like they are 'dragged out'
- Low replayability, because it is mainly a story game

In short I recommend playing the game if you want to experience a great story. It has great plot-twists so whatever you do, do NOT get spoiled about anything in this game. Unfortunately some the community consists of people who are too young/immature for the game's intended audience, which leads to people joking about the plot even unprovoked. So to be safe I recommend just ignoring anything to do with the game until you have reached the credits because apparently a part of the community just wants to spoil people for some reason. Anyways, if you are not that into stories or reading and instead are looking for riveting gameplay, this might not be the game for you. 

The story felt weird and dull to me at first and I even considered refunding, but the mysteries introduced at the start kept me in and I have not regretted playing the game ever since. And regarding the 'horror' tag of the game, I recommend playing the game even if you aren't a fan of horror. Only about 10 % of the game is horror-esque and it is psychological horror that is mandatory for the game's story to be so good. I don't want to go into full details about it for spoiler reasons, but I'll just say that dark elements are essential parts of the full story.

Thank you for reading this review and I hope this helped you with your decision about whether to buy this game or not. 



Now here at the end I would like to give you a tiny hint about what you should do to achieve the 'correct' route/ending, which you should do on your first playthrough to get the full story. Feel free to ignore the rest of this review if you want to go in 'fully blind', as I did. 

What I mean is that if you make the wrong decision near the beginning of the game, you might miss out on the full and true story of the game and thus are left mostly clueless. In any case you'll be fine as long as you pick rationally.

I know this game has a reputation as being for annoying fandom kids but it legit rocks. The presentation is always bangin on every level and the story, although stupid at times, is sincerely compelling. It also hits the perfect balance of difficulty for a turn-based RPG; you are never really forced to grind levels or repeatedly replay sections as long as you make intelligent decisions in boss battles, and I commonly was placed in tense scenarios where I barely clutched out victory after a series of deliberate plays, which was very rewarding. This game exceeds its reputation regardless of how I look at it.

Beautiful game with an amazing soundtrack, the characters are really touching and it's impressive how many little easter eggs you can find ! There are so many details and theories to be made, so many side characters and story that you can discover. It  pictures trauma, depression, anxiety in a beautiful but realistic way, which is hard sometimes but also makes the game so moving. Cried countless times too ! The game is a bit slow, the dialogues and fights were a bit long sometimes but I felt like it really echoed to how slow time seems to be when you're hurting. Also it forces you to take time, breathe, truly delve into the emotion. 
For me, a true masterpiece. An emotional journey, both conforting and also devastating : I would pay to play this game all over again for the first time. Also, try to really be in a peaceful setting when playing to truly appreciate the emotion !

[spoiler]This is one of my all-time favorite games! The story is rich and emotional, the characters are lovable, the flavor is fun, the soundtrack is phenomenal, and the way that the game uses psychological horror never feels cheap. The game play is simple, but there are a few puzzles sprinkled in, and the emotions system keeps the turn-based combat fresh. This is a great game for completionists, and has a fair amount of replay value with two vastly different play-through possibilities, and several optional bosses and side-quests. (Although there is a large amount of dialogue/perhaps too many cut-scenes in some parts, and your subsequent playthroughs will never quite live up to your first one.) Its style is reminiscent of Earthbound, and the amount of detail and number of Easter eggs is insane. The depictions of mental illness, trauma, grief, and guilt feel real and the way that the gameplay and ost support the emotion in the game is incredible. This is an amazing use of the medium of video games; if it was a book, movie, etc. getting the same kind of emotional impact would be impossible. I can't recommend this game strongly enough. [/spoiler]

OMORI is an incredible, extremely funny, horribly tragic, and overall harrowing game that feels like it ascends beyond the confines of its low-budget RPG Maker vibe. The story is key here, split across two realities, and the way the game slowly unravels the machinations of its core twist and how that has informed everything else about the game is both riveting and extremely unsettling. The contrast of the cutesy, pastel dream world and the awful things that hover just beneath the surface of it make for an incredibly engaging playthrough, and I enjoyed every minute of it.

In terms of actual RPG elements, the combat system has a lot of charm and appeal on the surface, but in practice, I found that even the bosses don't pose much in the way of a challenge - or, the challenge comes from enduring waves of damage and then finding the opportunities to dish out your own waves. I found a general combat arrangement that worked for me almost right away and basically never deviated from it for the rest of the game because I never saw a need to change my process, but I still had fun with the fights, particularly the theming of the bosses, both in the dream world and elsewhere. It's a system that has a lot of depth to it that I suspect is only truly unlocked on the combat-heavy alternative route, but it's still fun enough on the standard route.

The characters and the way they're connected and interact with each other is the real prize of OMORI, though - the story told of a childhood trauma shattering a friend group, and following the aftermath of that trauma to see where everyone has ended up, is extremely well done, jumping between the dream world of the protagonist and the real world he's tried to leave behind. Without getting any deeper into it than that, the characters of the dream world in particular are frequently hilarious, with a charm and whimsy to the writing that comes through in every single line of silly dialogue, and provides a lovely palate cleanser and contrast for when the horrors come back around. And the horrors are horrible! The way the game doesn't flinch at the truth of the core trauma, doesn't provide anything in the way of a justification or an out for the people involved, is remarkably dour and amplifies the impact of it when the entirety of it is laid bare. 

OMORI's not a perfect game - the sprite assets aren't anything special compared to the character art, the combat can become rote and tedious, and sometimes it can feel like you're kind of blindly groping around trying to figure out what to do next, but on the whole, this is a fantastic, unbelievable experience, and to come from a small indie developer on their first swing is mind-boggling. Play it, it's worth it.

This game has some pretty excellent writing that makes use of the medium of game storytelling in some subtle but genius ways. You really feel attached to the characters, and towards the end you really feel like the entire world is pulled out from under you. It is kind of the platonic ideal of "indie game", given that it's a quirky top-down pixel art RPG about mental health, but it performs that very well, and has some utterly unexpected elements.

This game is far from perfect, in fact I'd go so far as to say there are a lot of problems and quite a few things that I just straight up think aren't very good, but I think the overall package makes up for it.

Problems:
1. This is more a personal problem but to me turn based combat is just boring as hell. If you have some interactivity like Undertale or Paper Mario that makes it better, but this game's gimmick (the rock-paper-scissors battle mechanic) is a bit clunky. It makes encounters more strategic, but also drags out encounters with a lot of non-attacking actions.
2. The game is buggy as hell, I had to turn it to windowed because fullscreen made it crash every few minutes.
3. While the hand-drawn animations look great, with the line-art drawings, the pixel art can often look kinda trash.
4. There were probably about 3-4 hours of amazing content in a 20 hour game.

A phenomenal game with a wondrous soundtracks, tons of flavour text to enjoy, and a dynamic turn-based combat system. Sit back and enjoy the journey. There's a lot of things to do if you're a curious explorer, for which you'll be rewarded but not always. 

First time players will find it quite difficult to get through some of the hurdles this game has, as it offers no real assistance in itself (at hard times) in guiding you to your next action (which can leave you stuck sometimes, racking your brain), or reminding you where you need to go if you left off at a save point, or the spam of intentionally annoying common enemies, or straight up locking you in a bad route for one vague mistake you might've made without thinking of the drastic consequences. To me, that's a bit of artificial difficulty and a mild annoyance.  

There are a ton of guides out there for you to watch if you're stuck, or if you played through once and don't want to repeat for multiple endings. 

In 2024, this game is still amazing for the standards it has set. Great story, great characters, great music, great game play (except the common enemies). Boss fights are cool & have their crafty mechanics and banger songs. Spaceboys & Sweethearts OST are my favourite.

Admittedly, I didn't expect to enjoy Omori. I passed it off as another quirky Earthbound clone with cliche mental health topics added to be #relatable with the kids, not to mention that it's synopsis of "psychological horror" was  off-putting for someone as squeamish as me. However, I was pleasantly surprised with my experience. 

Besides a somewhat abstract and scatter-brained last 30 minutes or so, the story was a pleasant mix of wholesome fun and cold reality, which is only heightened by its incredible use of colour to weave the emotions and the events into one. Combat is the familiar "rock-paper-scissors" system of most turn-based RPGs, using emotions as the elements, which not only works well with the story, but also allows for clever twists and alterations to be made (e.g. being afraid or being miserable). Whilst some of the pixel art leaves a bit to be desired, especially considering that's how characters are portrayed most of the time, most of the sprites are well-made, and the in-battle sprites are extraordinary.

The highlight of the game, however, is the general theme, topics and mood of the game. I was sceptical at first, but the thoughts the game left me with throughout feel like nostalgia of the experiences and troubles in my own lifetime. The only way I can think of describing it is like a time capsule, kind of like listening to a song that brings you back to a specific point in your life, how you were feeling at the time, what your problems were, etc. in a way that feels like a shared experience, and I'm sure it will act the same for the time I'm in now, should I choose to revisit this game. In a simpler way, Omori uses its overarching theme and story to serve as a mirror to our collective past, making key plot points hit harder, as they feel like metaphors relating to our own lives by pulling heartstrings on our childhood.

I won't go into too much detail with negatives, as I feel most of them are minor personal complaints, and I truly believe this is a game worth playing. However, my main gripe with the game is the music. Most of the pieces that weren't the classical piano and violin arrangements (which only play at very specific times for impact) I found to be an ear-ache, repetitive or annoying.

All in all, Omori is both a fun time and a story that leaves you thinking. 8/10.

Man, what phenomenal game. 
OMORI is my favourite game of all time, and has been for just a little over a year now. The emotional journey this little indie RPG took me on was incredible: One I enjoyed, one that made me feel dread and unease, and one that hit me right in the heart.
I'm going to start with a non-spoiler overview of OMORI. I do want to say, please mind the content warnings. OMORI can be subtle, definitely, but a lot of the depictions of depression and suicide especially are not mild, and no matter how great this game is, if you are triggered by that type of thing, please, don't play OMORI.

One thing I've actually seen complained about often is the gameplay, so I'll get that out of the way first. Personally, as somebody who is super into and accustomed to RPGs, OMORI was highly enjoyable for me. It was unique, fun, pretty, and I loved almost every second of it. However, as some have pointed out, a lot of the sections in this game do tend to feel a bit like a slog, especially if you're not doing much but trying to progress. I didn't really feel that way, like I said, but a good number of people who did enjoy this game thought the gameplay was a little lacking in some areas, so if it's super amazing gameplay you're looking for, I'm not sure if OMORI will deliver for you. It's good, great even, but can get a little so-so.

OMORI, at its core, is about friendship. Or not just friendship in itself- relationships, the bonds you share with people close to you, or rather, people who used to be close to you. This premise is depicted beautifully in the game.
Another thing- the characters. The story in OMORI is spectacular, but it's the characters that really make it, that set it apart. The game does a really great job at getting you attached to all of these characters early on with their dynamic, relatable and lovable personalities, so it can tear your heart out and stomp on it later with them.

And finally, the horror aspect of OMORI. Man, do some parts of this game make you feel uneasy. OMORI isn't a jumpscarey game, as you may have been able to tell. It terrifies you in a completely different way. It uses memories, things you've already seen. It lulls you into a false sense of security only to creep back on you when you least expect it to, and make you feel that awful sense of dread once again. Basically- the horror is really good.

SPOILER SECTION - ANYTHING BELOW THIS LINE WILL BE SPOILERS, SO IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED OR FINISHED OMORI YET, AND IF WHAT I'VE SAID HAS CONVINCED YOU, GIVE IT A SHOT.

Okay, so the truth segment is what I really want to talk about here. I know it won't hit as much with other people, because it depends on my experience. But there's people out there that it will resonate with too.
Specifically, MARI and SUNNY, two characters I relate to too much.
When I was younger, I was told that playing an instrument would be the best gift of my life. As OMORI puts it, a rewarding hobby. But as OMORI also puts it, "nothing more than a nuisance". That captures my feelings so, so well.
When I started playing piano, I wasn't doing it or continuing because I wanted to. I was just told that it would all be worth it in the end. Maybe it will be, but it's not a hobby of mine, and I don't feel that way about it. An instrument that might be cool to learn, but when I actually put it into practice, my fingers just can't seem to move right.
I was also always MARI. I've struggled with a really deep perfectionism all my life. Everything has to be perfect. MARI's my favourite character in OMORI, because we only ever see her for fractions of the game, and yet she's fully fledged out, and deeply relatable. That deep, hungry competitiveness and perfectionism, the feeling that you always have to overdeliver, and be perfect, no matter what- that's something I struggled with, too. It was so, so refreshing and surprising to see that in a character I loved.
But it's not about that. It's about what happened on the recital night with MARI and SUNNY.
When SUNNY pushed MARI down those stairs, when I first heard the truth captions for myself (yes, I know these aren't in the game, I found them on the internet) it felt all so real. Even more so because I've been SUNNY before. There have been times I've lashed out. Times that lashing out causes me to do something I don't intend. I think everyone's been SUNNY at some point. It felt like I was reliving every single day I'd lashed out and messed up so badly in the process that I felt so... emotional. Sometimes, we do cause harm to the people we love, if it's on accident. But the thing is, we still love them either way. And most people will get to apologise and make up.
SUNNY never got to do that. It feels so hauntingly real and unfair, it feels like I'm the one who just pushed my sister down the stairs. What would twelve year old me do? SUNNY was a scared kid who made a mistake. It's so hauntingly real.
And I've been MARI too. Again, we've all been MARI. We've hurt the people we love unintentionally, and we've been lashed out at. You understand their perspective, but you still feel hurt. You feel angry. Anybody would.
And yet she forgives him.
I won't get into the debate on whether the MARI apparitions are real or not but gosh, everyone of her speeches to SUNNY hurt me inside. "Maybe I pushed you too hard. I'm sorry."
For a character like MARI, that would be so hard to say. I know. I'm so, so like that too. But she said it.
At the end of the day, SUNNY and MARI love each other. More than anything. And they each hurt one another, unintentionally, in a spur of the moment.
But it was overcome.
SUNNY knew MARI would forgive him, even deep down when he was flooded by guilt. She always would because they loved one another. And that love is what helped him to learn to finally forgive himself.
Then the game got worse, and built up even more, and then it all came to a breath taking conclusion with its final moments: the final battle against OMORI himself, the final duet, SUNNY finally gathering the courage to confess to his friends and relieve himself of the guilt that was weighing him down for years. I could hardly believe OMORI was real, a real game that I could play out there, that was so great.

The fact OMORI is a game makes it even better. It just wouldn't work as anything else, be it a comic, a book, a movie etc. Because actually being in control of SUNNY and OMORI just adds another layer of realness to the whole thing. It's heartbreaking and devastating, but bittersweet, knowing that you were able to make things better by your choices just breaks me. But it's not you- OMORI puts you in SUNNY's shoes and makes you feel like him, without you actually feeling that you are him. The whole silent protagonist switcheroo was brilliant, with OMORI and SUNNY having the general appearances of protagonists in which the player is meant to project onto, and not speaking so you could insert yourself in their place, but then  continues to flesh out that character. We explore SUNNY and OMORI's personalities, we see the people they care about, the things they enjoy and don't enjoy. They're not just you- you feel like them, but at the same time they're their own people, and you cheer SUNNY on until the very last moments.

OMORI doesn't show you your friends, the characters you got to know for its whole runtime, reactions to what SUNNY tells them. Which is perfect. Because OMORI isn't about getting others to forgive you, it's about forgiving yourself. Evolving from your mistakes, and moving on, and stopping blaming yourself.

Overall, I give OMORI a 10/10. Masterful, and I recommend it. OMORI feels like a part of me, the empty hole now filled, with these beautiful characters and their beautiful story, that made me laugh, cry, and even afraid.
OMORI truly did hit right in the heart.

I've known the game for a while but this is my first time playing the actual game and i have no regrets. [spoiler]My playthrough of OMORI brought me some spooks, laughs, and a LOT of tears. The developers made a great story with a bunch of characters that i got attached with so easily from how relatable they could be at times. The scenes with Mari always seemed to make me sad and happy at the same time, showing how she forgave Sunny and how she wants him to forgive himself. Basil and Sunny's fight also made me sad to see how much the truth hurt them and see how much Basil has been going through the past 4 years. The good ending is probably one of the best endings to a game I've ever seen as it doesn't matter how the others reacted to the truth, all that matters is that the weight of the truth has finally lifted off their shoulders and that they have both come to terms with the truth.[/spoiler] The battle mechanic is really cool too, I love all the bosses I encountered and beat. And i absolutely adored all their soundtracks. The music in general was so good, I'm definitely gonna be listening to those on repeat. Thank you, Omocat and the rest of your team for making such a nice, scary, sad, and sweet game, I cant wait to see what other stuff you got in the works!

Omori was a very unique and thrilling experience. I've never played games of this genre because turn-based combat always repelled me. However, this time I decided to overcome my bias and try this game. 
The story was very touching and unique. At first, I thought it would be quite generic following usual troupes of trauma and depression, but I was so wrong. It had many complex twists and turns that blew my head away. It's my genuine belief that this game can truly change how a person perceives the world. Even though I never cry playing games, there were multiple moments when I just couldn't hold back my tears. Only for the story, this games deserves to be remembered as one of the greatest games of our time.
The gameplay was also surprisingly fun. As I mentioned before, I hate turn-based combat, but here I actually enjoyed it. The thing that made it stand out to me was how stylized it is. Every move and mechanic were very fitting to the world and immersed me. There also some complexity to the combat with emotions and follow-ups, but it's simple enough, so a player like me that never played turn-based games could get a hang of it very quickly.

OMORI is a masterpiece that took me on an emotional rollercoaster, leaving an indelible mark on my gaming experience. This surreal RPG adventure, available on Steam, weaves a compelling narrative that seamlessly blends captivating storytelling with visually stunning aesthetics.

From the moment I delved into the world of OMORI, I was struck by its unique art style – a harmonious fusion of charming pixel art and evocative illustrations. The game's visuals serve as a portal to a beautifully crafted universe, and each environment is a testament to the developers' dedication to creating an immersive and visually striking experience.

The storyline is a poignant exploration of emotions, friendship, and self-discovery, masterfully presented through the eyes of the protagonist, OMORI. The game's ability to effortlessly transition between lighthearted moments and deep, thought-provoking themes is truly commendable. As I navigated through the richly detailed world, the characters' personalities and struggles became deeply relatable, forging a genuine connection that kept me invested in their journeys.

OMORI's turn-based combat system is both strategic and engaging, with a unique twist that adds depth to battles. The inclusion of a "emotion" mechanic introduces a layer of strategy, allowing players to leverage the emotional states of characters to gain a tactical advantage. The result is a dynamic and satisfying combat experience that complements the narrative seamlessly.

The soundtrack deserves special mention, as it expertly enhances the game's atmosphere. The emotionally charged music, ranging from tranquil melodies to intense compositions, serves as the perfect accompaniment to the unfolding story, immersing players even further into the world of OMORI.

Beyond the main storyline, OMORI offers a plethora of side quests, secrets, and optional content, ensuring that the adventure is both expansive and rewarding. The level of detail in every aspect of the game, coupled with its replayability, showcases the developers' commitment to delivering a comprehensive and fulfilling experience.

In conclusion, OMORI on Steam is a captivating journey that transcends the boundaries of conventional RPGs. Its emotionally charged narrative, stunning visuals, strategic combat, and immersive soundtrack make it a must-play for fans of the genre. I wholeheartedly recommend OMORI to anyone seeking a deeply enriching and unforgettable gaming experience.

This game is amazing. It gives you a ton of gameplay, and personally, it's not too expensive. It can be frustrating with certain enemies, but the game's content is fairly easy to get through if you learn how to play! The plot and the details and the way it portrays certain things is very pleasing and the music was the cherry on top. It was amazing.

The game's fighting mechanics are turn based, and your characters unlock different skills as you progress. This way of fighting was very enjoyable for me. The way they handle emotions and give them different effects and weaknesses add even more ways to defeat the enemies. It's great.

[spoiler] The way Sunny had to fight Omori to overcome his troubles was amazing and well thought out, and the way they revealed that the real way Mari died kept me on the edge of my seat. Basil being slowly forgotten in headspace was also something I found to be a good addition, since it really shows how distracted the others got with other things. This game also portrays depression and mental illness very well with all of the horror and entities you find late game. The different bosses coming back later in the game like Sweetheart and Space Boyfriend was also very entertaining, as they are good twists to end off different areas of the game. Overall, a great game with tons of depth. [spoiler]
