Have you ever played a game? Crazy, right? Well let me be the first to inform you that your favorite game sucks unless it is this game.

Omori is unlike anything you have seen before, and I'm finding it very difficult to write this, not only because words cannot describe how absolutely immaculate it is, but also because going into any level of detail at all would put me at risk for spoiling it. The main thing with story games (and especially this one) is that playing blind is the penultimate act of good you can do for yourself. There are many aspects of the game that I was skeptical of initially that rebutted quickly and effectively; which I will go over now. Then, I will discuss the unique vibe the game gives amidst the story progression, and finish off with things that related to me to better explain my love for the game.

First, I will go over the gameplay basics that made me doubt the game at first glance. By far my biggest concern was this: I hated horror (games) as well as RPG turn-based combat and gameplay. Even in the first 20 minutes of the game I was pleasantly surprised at how well integrated it was with the overall flow, which prevented me from hating it. [spoiler] The combat, instead of using types like Pokemon to create interactions, instead uses emotions; which is not only a unique concept, but it also has major relevance to the story, such as heavy foreshadowing. [/spoiler]. Despite having practically zero RPG game experience, I found it incredibly easy to get into. As a whole, the game introduces itself exceptionally, and as a result, allows the story to show itself at a perfect pace while allowing people such as myself to get a hang of it.

What is more, it has a very fantastical atmosphere. The game primarily goes back and forth between two types of segments, which each have their own flair. Throughout the experience, you meet many interesting characters, both main or otherwise, that really enhance the world and encourage you to explore and visit everything (which you should definitely do). The soundtrack introduces new motifs at every corner, and the incredibly diverse settings always pique your interest. Although it shares many basic aspects with other RPG maker games, it puts a subtle twist that makes it feel off. It puts up a very pleasant front that slowly shows its true nature as you progress through the story. Despite the fact that you return to the same areas you have been through before, they somehow still manage to feel different despite being identical. It's a strange feeling; it's like when you speak to somebody you haven't spoken to for years and they seem like a completely different person. You get filled with this odd sensation of uneasiness that feels like it's progressively getting worse as stages of the game reach their end. I think it is this feeling that really puts the icing on the cake for the story immersion, and it hangs around with you until the very last moments of the game.

Lastly, I will go over some parts of the game that I found generally relatable in such a way that made it hit different and stand out. To give you context of how impactful this game is, I'll tell you this so you understand why I'm so passionate: Even after almost a year since I played this game for the first time, I still think about it everyday. There is zero hyperbolic intention or exaggeration in that statement. Let me compare it to another game I love to death, Red Dead Redemption 2. Don't get me wrong, it was also an absolute banger of a game, but when I played Omori I couldn't help but think RDR2 got put to shame. The story and setting was also beautiful in its own right, but I first played RDR2 three years ago and I don't really think about it often. Even during the first year after I played it, it was often a background thought. Not Omori though, not Omori. In addition, many of the settings carry their own auras that any given person is bound to relate to at least one of. They give you that awesome feeling of being a kid again, which the game successfully attempts to induce (that last bit makes more sense if you've seen the main store page trailers). 

In sum, there's much, much more to the story that you should find out yourself. Don't worry though, it does not matter what kind of person you are. Even if you take little interest in facets of mental health, or you're scared because mental health is a sensitive topic for you, it's not a big deal. The game eases you into it, so you're not bombarded immediately. In fact, it's quite the opposite. Story beats are incredibly vague and always leave you guessing. It sounds like horrible story design, but it all catches up to you in the end as one massive depressing, but gratifying, haymaker. Except, the game's metaphorical fist is covered in barbed wire, and you're standing on the cliff edge of a volcano. Despite all of this, I still feel like I have not done the game justice, and I don't think it is possible with a review, either. It's just one of those "you have to play/do it to understand" type of things. As disconcerting or unhelpful as that is, I promise you that this game fulfills that title more than any other game out there.

You know what, forget the rest of this review, just buy it already. Every second you spent sitting here not buying it has only made me more and more angry.

The game could have been a narrative masterpiece.

I loved the concept, the art, the characters and the story for the most part. The head-space was an amazing idea and I loved the parallels with the real world with it. The game play was easy but I didn't care about that personally because I liked the story. The sense of progression felt nice, the buildup of the story and the "mystery" of what happened. I enjoyed Sunny learning to calm himself with the struggles of anxiety. I loved the friendship between the characters and the banter, sure the dialogue was cheesy but it was cute and I liked it.

Spoilers: Basically I hate the story, the plot twist that Sunny killed Mari and Basil helped cover it up at 12 years old is so stupid. Like its disappointing that the build up of the game was Sunny forgiving himself for making an oopsie of killing his sister and covering it up. It makes the story so much more shallow. Just because a twist is out of left field does not make it good at all. It makes the plot not make any sense at all, a 12 year old doing that and nobody apparently noticing the bruises or other brakes Mari's bones made falling down the stairs. Its like a family guy episode levels of bad storytelling. It makes the last 20 hours you play less impactful and disappointing. I was so excited for the climax for it to fall on its face, it gives it so many potholes and feels rushed. And the good ending is him admitting it to his friends and leaving with no consequences basically for killing his sister.

It's good, but the game has heavy standards in terms of patience. You have to be willing to explore everywhere, talk to everyone, and interact with any bit of furniture you see, because you don't know if it will have a spare item, or piece of equipment, or key item, or sidequest, or hidden boss, or flavor text that hints at the plot. It is certainly a much bigger game than I expected - I've apparently only scratched the surface of the side content. 
The game itself has great use of colors with its colored pencil style and the combat is pretty good - though you'll fall into tried-and-true strategies after awhile just to push through some of these boss fights.
Story grapples with guilt and blame, and its fairly good, though, after the reveal, I don't know if I would forgive Basil. That was kind of sick. 
In any event, pick this one up if you're looking for a slower game heavy with dialog and exploration with some JRPG battles mixed into it.

Holy moly, where do I even begin with this game. I originally shared a library with a friend who had it, played it with said friend watching, got busy, and here I am now just as invested as I was when I first started.

First of all, this is NOT a game to play if you don't come in with a strong mindset, or are currently in a bad place. If you are, I recommend at least playing with a friend. That psychological horror tag is no joke, folks. This game can get deep very quickly.

That said, everything about this game moves you emotionally in both a good and bad way, with good mechanics and a great artstyle to boot. It's just as cute as it looks, but filled with so much depth not just story wise, but game wise- completing this game fully will take you a while (unless you're like me with way too much free time).

The people of OMORI put so much love into what is both a JRPG with slice of life elements, while somehow still being a sort of mystery game. There are multiple endings to get, which are sort of obvious to spot in the relevant story places, but this game does not hold your hand (except in the very beginning, naturally). There are many game references, jokes, easter eggs and even different generic NPC dialogues you can choose between that have no effect on the main story. It's a game jam packed with everything you can think of.

I would recommend this game to everyone. It WILL move you emotionally. And even if you find you don't hold that strong of an attachment, the story that you reveal has enough of an impact to go "yeah, it wasn't your average story." And I think that's way more important, since not everyone feels the same way about just one game.

The story is intriguing, the visuals fantastic and the music poping but every time I was faced with the concept of spending the next few hours walking through the most simple dungeons with some of the most basic, press attack 4-16 times to win combat I have ever seen I couldn't do it.  I get why people love this game but I genuinely believe that games can't just ignore gameplay as a core part of what they are, staple together the laziest RPG mechanics imaginable and call it a day, and worst than that have the gall to make you play that bare bones combat for HOURS.  If you couldn't make the combat interesting than just cut it down, or remove it entirely.  I genuinely this would be a better game with no combat.  

TLDR just watch a plot summary on youtube, gameplay is booty and way too plentiful.
If this game looks at all interesting to you, just pick it up. You will not regret it.

Personally, the story and concept of the game is well planned; however, it is laid out badly and did not reach the expectations I had for the game. The game takes way too long ( 30hrs ) for the audience to be immersed into its characters and story and the ending did not really make it up for the time spent on this game. The character development of the characters throughout the game is well thought through however some scenes do not really add any value to the story or their background. Sure, there were some teary moments towards the end but personally, everything just felt lacking and incomplete. Overall, great attempt of the devs for making their first game but I personally would not reccommend playing it

This game is absolutely adorable and left me emotionally devastated.

After two full playthroughs wanting to see everything there is to see (it's a LOT), I can confirm Omori deserves all of the praise it's received. From the handcrafted art style, to the flippin banger of a soundtrack, a fun and engaging combat system, as well as the complete roller coaster ride of a narrative this game sends you on... This game is a .[b] m a s t e r p i e c e .[/b] 

Do yourself a favor if you stumbled across this game by chance, pick it up now and play completely blind. You are in for a magnificent journey. I don't care how tough you think you are [spoiler]you will cry.[/spoiler] 

Thank you OMOcat and company. It's clearly evident how much thought and care you put into every aspect of this game. [u]Easily one of my favorite games of all time.[/u]

[strike]P.S. Please give us 'Basil Rush' content. Us PC players are feeling a little left out.[/strike]

I really like this game even though i havent finished it. The vibe is there, and its eerie. I did get spoiled for the entire game but that didnt make me not want to play it, since its all around really good. Also the story is a fucking banger, its really good. They also handle the hard topics well, so theres always that.

only played through the good ending as of writing this review since i don't currently have the time to get the other endings & play through the other routes, but gosh, i've watched a few videos for the other routes i haven't explored myself and they look wickedly terrifying. this game is such a masterpiece, it didn't go through years of development for nothing, that's for sure! its attention to detail and meticulousness in story execution is such a delight. i wish i wasn't so eager to learn the story that i completely spoiled myself for the story (blunder on my part) but i still bawled my eyes out in the last portion of getting the good ending. anyways yes please play this game, absolutely shattered my world and tore my heart to shreds <3 i got SO attached to the characters. i wish i could forget all about it so i can play it for the 1st time again (and not-spoiled haha)

There's nothing about Omori I could say that hasn't already been said, but I'll still give it a go.  Mild spoilers warning !

This is the kind of game you want to experience at least twice. Once completely blind, the second with all the knowledge of your previous playthrough.

The depiction of fear, guilt, and trauma in this game is extremely poignant. One thing I really like is how alive Faraway town feels, despite having less npcs than Headspace. The npcs in Headspace feel pretty flat too, outside of the ones who are developped, I don't know if this was intentional, but it makes the shift between the two worlds all the more jarring, and drives forward the point that this really is just a story the protagonist is telling himself, as immersive as it can get.

It was pretty hard to get through [spoiler]Black Space[/spoiler] the first time, or to complete [spoiler}the Truth photo album[/spoiler], it's exceptionally well done, but it can be really triggering, so tread with caution.

ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ 
ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ ᗜˬᗜ v

A beautifully stunning game both art wise, gameplay wise, and story wise. Omori is a game all about making decisions from deciding to confront and or to repress something. It's a story of accepting something and moving on or not moving on, as you the player makes those choices yourself. Each game is personal to the player, everything they do and don't do will affect them in someway. Guilt, depression, anxiety, suicide and fear are all tackled in this game. How will you as the player deal with these emotions and concepts is up to yourself.

A game that is not a cliche at all and you will not get bored while playing it

OMORI is an amazing psychological horror game. It has a great story, amazing unique game play, and cute characters. The story by the end of the game is life changing. You might even cry at the end its that good! The soundtrack is amazing, I find myself listening to it in my free time.

This game has multiple endings which each are very fun to try to get! There's a ton of little secrets you can find as well. I find myself replaying this game over and over it's truly a masterpiece. Each moment of the game feels exciting, through HEADSPACE and FARAWAY TOWN. There isn't a second in the game where im not amazed or excited. This game was released in 2020 and still is a great play today in 2024

I recommend this game to anyone who is OK with the content warnings. OMORI is truly a great game, and my favorite game of all time.

I don't wanna spoil anyone. I just wanna say that this is one of the best RPG Maker games I've ever played. Fun, heavy, and surreal at the same time. It's hard balancing those three elements visually (and story-wise) and Omocat, the author, and the crew just nailed it. I advice playing again after reaching an ending..because this game has a lot of easter eggs depending on the path (ending) you're heading. Kudos!

This game is the perfect example of "Don't judge a book by it's cover".  To whoever is reading this, please give this game a chance even if pixel type games isn't the type of game you love. This has a seriously mind wrecking deep lore and the game theme gets intense the more you play on. The replay value is high with multiple story routes and always, the end result will be that you will wind up an emotional wreck. Any more said would be a spoiler. OMORI isn't just a game, its an emotion. 11/10 recommended.

Omori is one of the best game I've ever played. The gameplay is great. The combat isn't really that difficult once you get the hang of it, but there are some variations to the enemy and the special abilities that keep the gameplay fresh. The world that this game has to offer is interesting. There's so many places, quests, and secrets you can discover throughout the game. The places also changes when each day passed, so there are reasons to coming back to the same place. But the best thing that this game has to offer is the story. You'd feel all sorts of emotions as the game progress. The distict athmospheres between the fun, happy section for most of the game length, makes the more horror, depressing, and sad moments stand out and more emotional. The ending really broke me. This game motivates me to become a better person and face the truth no matter what the outcome may be. Thank you, Omocat for giving me this experience.

[b] Never before in my life have I loved and connected with a game as much as I have with OMORI. [/b] Never before have I found myself in a sense of bereavement at the thought of a game being over, not in the lost sense, but in the sense that I have completed a game. I find myself longing for the connections that I developed with Aubrey, Basil, Hero, and Kel, despite them being fictional characters. This game is so well written and has such a good atmosphere that the characters feel they could, and at some point, did, actually exist. The constant development hell that the dev team went through is not lost on me, though the end product, to me and many others, was well worth it. Those who love meaningful storytelling, RPG's, and even video games in general (I tend to lean towards FPS's) this is the [b] THE GAME [/b]. This game legitimately changed my life and made me cry. Never before have I ever felt the need to write a story about a game (with the exception of Project Moon, but that was after). If you are going to play any game, play OMORI, and even after you're done, there's a large and passionate modding community. This is the first game I have ever read and enjoyed fanfiction about. My hat is off to the OMOCAT team, you all have made a genuine masterpiece. If this game were to get a DLC, it would become my definitive favourite game. It is CRIMINAL to charge only $20, I would pay for it if it was $60. All in all, this game is not GOTY, it is Game Of The Century.

Beautiful game. The characters are obviously flawed but not evil or even bad which just makes them more human and relatable. The game has good restraint and isn't too "on the nose" about many things and doesn't go over the top with the scares. I don't have all of the endings but I have been spoiled on most of them, and the only thing I can say is this game gets dark, part of me doesn't even want to get them because of how emotional they are. Ten out of ten game, it's went through development hell but still came out as a masterpiece. Can't wait for the up-coming manga, a way to relive the story through a new form of media will be interesting and I can only hope the execution of the manga will be just as good as the execution of the game. Best of luck to Omocat and all of the other developers behind this game, and happy holidays to the dev team. As for the community surrounding the game, you are all truly dedicated and I believe that's something all fanbases should aspire to. (edit: I corrected a comma)

Wonderful game but save yourself the need for therapy

You will always have to fight with things you regret. Shoving them down is never the answer. Regrets are apart of life, and mistakes, no matter how grave the consequence, are too. You need to speak out about your problems, deal with them, talk with other people to cope with them. Allowing something to be regressed means it's going to build up, and, if not taken care of properly, damage you mentally. 
This game deals with this idea. The idea of suppression, and how you deal with events. This game shows how trauma, if pushed down, can hurt not just you, but others as well.
This game is amazing for that.
In summary?
Buy and play Omori.
And also know, you're never alone. Don't ever try to fight something alone. People are there for you.
Everything is going to be ok.

I'm gonna be real with you guys on this one, but up front I have to say I need to talk about spoilers to express my points and why I wouldn't personally recommend this game. The only non-spoiler thing I wanna say is that an update introduced a bug that ruins the atmosphere, but you can find different methods of fixing said bug online so make sure you sort the fullscreen bug before you play if you decide to get this game.

Extremely small spoiler here:
I don't like this game. For every interesting and fun character there are at least two others that are massively annoying in the extended cast. It's a good thing the main cast are good characters if we count only the playable party, Basil, and Mari, but the clownish NPCs are just grating on the nerves most of the time. Don't even get me started on Sweetheart. Her scenes just drag on and on and on and they have nothing to do with the main themes of the game, it's so infuriating.

MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.

Then there's the main plot, which is as dumb as it is confusing. You're telling me I'm supposed to sympathize with a kid who murdered his sister to avoid a recital and his insane best friend who helped him cover it up? Not just that, but also I'm supposed to believe the police either never figured it out, or that, if they did, the parents and the neighbors and the pastors all chose to hide what really happened from the other children? What about police reports? Mari would have been severely banged up from her tumble down the stairs, so everyone would know the false suicide was a bad cover job. Sunny and Basil should have just left her at the bottom and hid the photos to pass it off as an accident and the story could have been the same, but the dev wanted imagery of her crumpled on the floor and hanging dead from a tree so came up with this convoluted way to have both.

And the trope of it all being in a character's headspace makes the overwhelming majority of the game feel like a pointless chore to get through in order to get to the actual story. The real world sequences were mildly narratively interesting while I was still riddling out what really happened, but were mechanically boring as Hell. The more mechanically interesting headspace parts also became mechanically boring very quickly, since the energy system lets you start killing most enemies on the first turn if you're any good at RPGs. Do well in a few optional fights against some tough enemies and your only reward for overcoming that challenge is being bored out of your mind for the entire rest of the game since you're now very, very overleveled. There wasn't that much to even do, so why not have a max level at 20 or 25 to keep the power-level in-line with the whole experience? I didn't fight anything with my level 40+ party at the end that I couldn't have beaten with much weaker characters and some items.

The story feels like a weird middleground between Undertale and Night in the Woods that doesn't succeed at being either, or even close to the same level of immersion and quality, subjectively speaking. While the game failed to pull me in, I can see a lot of interesting ideas in Black Space being very moving and upsetting for a lot of people. Personally, though, I was checked out and didn't care about anything that was happening to the fake mental projection people and just wanted to see what the Hell it all actually meant. It's hard to feel bad about what the protagonist is "doing" to "their friends" when all of it is just a nightmare they're having about how guilty they are over some other, actually real thing.

I got the good ending on my first run, but I'm not sure I even want to see the others. The depressing fact of playing as either a murderer, or the murderer's evil self-projection in a nightmare realm torturing and killing his partner in crime for daring to... to help cover up... the protagonist's crime? I just don't like it. I don't like this protagonist. I don't want to play as this protagonist. They do nothing to characterize themselves, and the game never sets up any choices of consequence to make the player feel responsible. You can't just let the player name the character at some point and then assume they'll take on the guilt of stuff the protagonist did before the story even began. I don't identify with this dead-eyed psychotic murderer.

If you can easily identify with a murderer, enjoy this game! If you can't, well, it isn't without other merits, but I honestly wish I could have my thirty hours back to have spent on anything else. I know Toby Fox loves the dev and was really hyped for this game and I respect his opinion, and the opinions of others who call this a masterpiece. I just simply don't agree. I want to be able to recommend it, even though I didn't like it, but I can't fathom why anyone does like this. It's not scary, creepy, or horrifying. It's just disgusting. Gross. I don't have any desire to touch this game again.

This is going to be a LIVE kind of on-going diary/review for the game OMORI as I play it blindly. I am going to be pathetic.
I will have a proper review finalized by the time I beat it. I'll start off with bits about myself. I am finally playing this game because it's been over a year since my best friend said goodbye, and someone else had advised me to play the game. My best friend liked this game, called it cute and said it dealt with dark subjects. She also had a pfp of Aubrey at some point.

I think the game started off being unnerving to me from the get-go, and I'm already guessing about subtext as I play along through the prologue. I am a paranoid/hypervigilant person, and I really am sensitive about stuff after all. Later I got to a certain point where a video-game genuinely terrified me in over a decade, I wound up all curled onto my bed. I'm texting my friends and snapshotting my monitor with my phone's camera to show my progress. I do that instead of simply prnt-scrn'ing the game because I didn't want to leave behind my support blankets and stuffed shark. 

I did finally come around to the game's budding charm. I got advice from Aubrey, which lit a lightbulb in my head about something I was struggling with. IDK why but the thing her advice helped me out with just seemed spectacular to me - in the sense that my mouth became agape with a grin. [i]She[/i] was right: [i]the game is cute[/i]. It's also, as cliche it is to say, "oozing with atmosphere". From the scenery to story... and suggested subtext, as well as the charming characters that I come across and travel with. G-d knows exactly how much this game is going to snap my spine, and which way I'll bend.

I ask you this. If a film is profound, but boring, is it a good film? If a song is philosophical, but sounds terrible, is it a good song? What about a political book with poor pacing? 

To me, Omori is good ONLY if you're someone who instantly sees something 'deep' and is impressed. Sure, it handles complex themes, but the actual gameplay sucks. A forced battle system, poor pacing, and the such, combine to make a terrible slog of a playing experience. Sure the game has beautiful artwork, and a great soundtrack, but who cares when it's so boring?

+very good characters, I pretty much liked the entire main cast + some side characters
+fun battle system with it's emotion and follow-up system
+good balance between horror and non-horror.
+I really like the drawing style this game tries to pull off. It took a bit of getting used to, but now I like it, because it conveys the characters emotions really well
+good story

-battle system is at first quite confusing, because of the lack of in depth tutorials
-sometimes the puzzles felt more like a chore rather than a fun thing to solve and often they are simple, but tedious
-side quests are very hard to keep up with. Often times you'd check how far you are in a specific quest route, only to receive a very vague description. Other times you are supposed to meet the quest giver x. However, if you don't remember who x is, then good luck finding them. If this wasn't a problem, I'd have for sure done all quests, since this game doesn't seem to be swamped with them.

Overall an excellent game. If you like RPGs with a good narrative/characters, or are looking for a more serious story, then this game is for you.

The combat system can be slightly more fleshed out, enemy variety (especially in some parts of the game like the castle) could be 10x better, but that is about it.

This game is incredible.



[spoiler] This is one of the best games I've ever played. I laughed, I cried, I cried some more, I got scared, and cried some more. If only I could forget everything I knew about the game just to experience it again. The portrayal of depression, anxiety, and other mental health issues feels so realistic, the music, and the way it pulls you in with its false atmosphere to make you forget that it's even psychological horror. It made me feel so emotionally attached to the characters that I felt like they were my friends. I can't think of another game that had such a deep and emotionally impactful story as this. The world building is immaculate. 50 hours into the game and I'm not even finished with all of it. It may just look like another Earthbound inspired RPG, but it's much more than that.  [/spoiler]

[spoiler] I've played many games but not one has been as emotionally impactful and has brought me to tears as much as OMORI. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] It's a reminder of the friends that I've lost over the years, the friends that moved away, and it has an important lesson  of moving on and forgiving yourself.  [/spoiler]

Amazing game, few notes:

Lore/Storytelling is amazing, albeit a little hard to comprehend sometimes. Was extremely new to the genre of the game (psychological horror), but overall was a pleasant experience and 100% stuck with me. Can't really say anything about the story itself (no spoilers), but I can attest to the fact that it is extremely touching, and emotionally draining. No game has made me experience this before - 9/10. 

Design and art style is amazing as well, and I found that it conveyed emotions very well. Not a spoiler, but one way they do this is through making certain things/objects more pixelated than others (A realistic scary object behind a pixelated background, making it more creepy). Also, the design choice makes the game less scary when compared to other "horror" games (due to its cute like nature), but instead makes it all the more creepy and "emotional scary" in a sense - 10/10.

Game-play was a little mediocre however. I found that the fighting system was sub-par, and that the design of items, etc. was not amazing by any means. The game follows the usual game-play mechanics you would see in similar 2-d games, with the fighting mechanics following a turn to turn basis, making it pretty bland imo - 5/10.

Overall score: 8.5/10 100%, would recommend.

Lovely game so far :^) Huge fan of the art and soundtrack. A very very calm gameplay exploring interesting themes. Creators ate with the character design tbh.

Omori's pastel-hued world holds a surprising amount of darkness, beautifully captured in its hand-drawn artwork. Lushly detailed environments shift seamlessly into dreamlike landscapes, while character designs range from adorable plushies to grotesquely fascinating creatures. The story masterfully builds uncanny tension, not through cheap jump scares, but by immersing you in a world steeped in unsettling secrets and veiled anxieties.

However, Omori's biggest hurdle lies in its pacing. The opening hours meander through repetitive random battles and seemingly innocuous interactions, making it tough to connect with the characters or feel invested in the unfolding story.

tl;dr -- A game for players who are patient and willing to grind through boring repetitive battles

8.5/10

This game could've — and SHOULD'VE — been the next Undertale. That's not to say it is, per say, the same experience as Undertale, but... it is impactful and possibly more emotional. Each character is lovable and interesting, the RPG aspect is bright, colorful, and not to mention just pure old fun, and at the end you'll be wondering, where do I go from here?

Well I'll tell you where I went! (in the bathroom to cry) But also I went to try and get my friends irl to play this. OMOCAT may be a controversial figure (I personally don't think any of the allegations and controversy surrounding her is based in any substantial proof), but her game was well worth the long wait and honestly? It's worth every cent. The narrative is rich and emotional while still managing to keep things light with the headspace sequences, and the psychological horror, while scary, is more bone-chilling than knock-your-socks-off terrifying, iykwim. The artistic choices to depict the uncanny feeling you get from this game is incredible, as is the art in general.

SPOILERS DO NOT READ IF YOU WANT TO GO INTO THIS BLIND

.
.
.

You play as Sunny, a sixteen year old boy, and Omori, his twelve year old self. It's not DID. Omori is the avatar in which you traverse Sunny's complex mind and trauma. He is the embodiment of Sunny's trauma, the part that desperately wants to forget the incident that caused it. Omori will do *ANYTHING* to keep Sunny from remembering. Sunny spends his days and nights locked up in his room, as a Hikkikomori does, sleeping and dreaming his life away. He's pale, without friends, and practically mute. A great depiction of living with mental illness. His dreams are worlds from his imagination that stifle and sit atop his subconscious, where the memories of his trauma are trapped by them. The worlds are expansive, vast, bright creations that hide the nasties underneath.

Omori lives his life peacefully with his friend group, a friend group that Sunny used to have. There's Kel, bright, resilient, and fearless. He can also be dense, and Aubrey — kind, stubborn, and strong — always bickers with him when he fails to read the mood or annoys her. Basil is Omori's best friend, sweet, shy, and optimistic, always with a flower crown and a camera. Hero is the designated "big brother" of the group, both in his caring and brotherly nature, and literally as he is Kel's older brother biologically. He's the ultimate alpha male, with a certain charm and an affinity for cooking and cleaning. Mari is the "big sister" of the group. She is beautiful, graceful, and kind, and she is also Omori's older sister.

Basil goes missing, and the RPG aspect of the game kicks off as Omori, Aubrey, Kel, and Hero all set off to find him. And the closer you get, the more the memory of him fades, the more Omori works to hide the past from Sunny.

[i]The closest I've been to being happy is being asleep...[/i]

Turn-based RPGmaker depression spiral.  If you grew up on drowning yourself in escapism to deal with your own bad situations, OMORI is designed to stab specifically you in the chest with bitter nostalgia.  It strikes hard at the anxiety that every good moment is fleeting, and will eventually have to crash back down to reality.

It's hard to sell OMORI because it doesn't have an immediate hook.  It's slow burn as hell and doesn't leave you perfectly satisfied, but goes a lot of places other games don't dare to and commits to it extremely hard.  What you get out of the game by the end, upon reflection, can feel like a metacommentary on how letting narrative influence gameplay can craft a more memorable experience.

But putting analysis aside, it is a memorable experience.  OMORI is a game that frequently sets you up to dread what's coming around the corner, but that doesn't mean you can't find things to enjoy on the way.

A sometimes fun, sometimes disquieting 20-30 hour romp, with a fair amount of replayability.

Update: Unfortunately, since the time of writing, a Switch version of this game came out with more content, being an objectively superior version of the game.  They seem to have no plans of supporting the Steam version any further so I no longer feel comfortable recommending it.  Personally, I think it is a very scummy move for a developer to screw over the earliest supporters like this.

TLDR: I think I can recommend OMORI to most people, especially those who like games such as LISA, Undertale, or other Earthbound-inspired games. I don't think it's as good as these games, but I might be in the minority on that one judging by the other reviews. Let me explain what I mean.

The developer of OMORI clearly had a lot of faith in their character writing, plot, art, and music, and I will say, it's not misplaced. These are what make OMORI worth your time, and I can't imagine being too disappointed with these elements.

The big problem I had was with OMORI's pacing.

The strengths I just mentioned started to wear thin about 9 hours in to my 18 hour playthrough. Make no mistake, this is a JRPG, and like most JRPGs, OMORI tends to drag on a little longer than it should. Eventually I started rushing because I wanted to see what happened next, and my general lack of interest in just about anything else happening in this game. I think someone taking their time could have a relaxed playthrough well over 30 hours- it's not Dragon Quest or Persona or anything, but I think a faster pace would have vastly improved my experience of the game.

JRPG combat does not generally interest me, and OMORI did nothing to change my mind on this, but it functioned. There is too much farting around in [spoiler]HEADSPACE, especially Sweetheart's Castle[/spoiler], and I just don't think the combat, sidequests, "puzzles", or any other non-story content is strong enough to justify how long this game is. Even some of the story moments drag on too long, which for me, ruined a couple of big moments and reveals because I started feeling impatient. I think if someone is mashing through the climax of your plot, there's something wrong, and I'm sure it's not just me who felt this way.

Anyway, I've said my piece, and I still recommend OMORI to a patient player who likes JRPGs in this style.

I'm going to make this short and sweet because I don't want to give this slog-fest more of my time than necessary.

I adore games like Off, Undertale, etc. I love turn-based combat. But the combat in this game is such absolute trash, which is a shame, because the art is nice, the music is fantastic, and... well, I didn't get far enough into the story to really care, so I won't comment on that.

The combat makes absolutely no sense. Much like Final Fantasy 4, there is no logical reason for why enemies do the damage they do. You have to spend hours, upon hours, upon hours grinding to even keep headway against regular enemies, who will chunk half your HP or more in a single hit, except this is where the game has led me so I have to be ready for this place, right? I mean, I beat the boss so handily, THEY weren't doing this much damage to me, so why are the regular enemies suddenly decimating my party?

It's just no fun and I refuse to waste more time on it.

I cannot stress enough how good this game is. I'm glad I was able to play it and get to experience the story; nevertheless, I wouldn't recommend it to someone currently struggling with deep depression just because this game can get really dark.

I remember looking into this game as a kid, wishing I would be able to play it on the 3ds, but boy am I SOOOOOO glad they delayed its development to improve it. I think what sets this RPG apart from the rest of the lot is its story: Omori is SO good in puting you in the headspace (wink wink) of its titular character, Sunny/ Omori. It's portrayal of depression/ psychological trauma is so well played to a T that it almost hurts to watch all of it unfold. Speaking from someone who has quite similarly "lived in my head for as long as I can remember", this game will win your heart (and will haunt you forever).

Omori flips over the "it was all just a dream!" troupe onto its head- delving deep into its psychological implications. This game may seem "quirky and random XD" at first, but don't be fooled- it's all intentional and not at all what it seems at the same time.  Although the Earthbound series undoubtedly pioneered the whole "quirky rpg aesthetic", I would argue that Omori takes this a step further through connecting its art style with its story and message. Every bit of seemingly negligible area or plot point in this game has a purpose- and the game best shines through its attention to detail. Omori takes the best aspects of its inspired source materials and personally sets the bar higher for any future indie RPG I am to pick up next. 100/10 would cry again.

An incredible game with an unforgettable story - OMORI is undeniably, and will forever be, one of my favorite games of all time. 

Despite this being my first RPG-maker style game, OMORI was easy to pick up with a surprisingly complex and fun combat system. OMORI delivers its narrative in such a brilliant and ingenious manner that I've never seen in any other game before, with moments of haunting beauty and gut-wrenching sadness beneath its bright and optimistic exterior. The story is just so powerful and so amazingly delivered, and it plagued my mind (in a good way) for weeks after I had finished the game. Everything is top notch - story, character writing, art, music, gameplay - and you find yourself completely absorbed in the world and characters in no time. A must play, through and through - this is one of those games that just might change your life. 

(P.S. Kel is best boy)

If someone were to ask me what my favorite game was, my default response as of right now would probably be OMORI. Playing this game has influenced me so much that I don't think I'd be the same person I am today if I had decided against seeing it through to the end. I'll try to keep it vague to avoid spoilers, but do know that playing without a single clue as to what to expect will likely bring the best experience.

  First off, my biggest criticism of this game is the description. "The path you've chosen" is literally one decision at about the 3-hour mark of the average playthrough, and if you've went in completely blind, you will have absolutely no idea that you just secured yourself into playing the game "incorrectly." If you need to know: [spoiler] Open the door, let Kel in. [/spoiler]
  In my first playthrough of the game, I didn't do that. As a result, my playthrough was immensely unfulfilling and felt purposeless by the end, leaving nothing but the thought: "That was it?" Through it all, I felt that this was a unique experience that I would never be able to feel again, and honestly, I had hoped for the game to answer my own questions about myself for me. Had I left it at that playthrough, I would've left feeling miserable.
  Then, I watched a review of the game, and surprise, it turns out everything I did had absolutely nothing to do with the "main game." Still, I played through the game again, knowing basically every major plot point now, no real surprises left for me, including [spoiler] that door choice [/spoiler]. Here I am, praising this game for being my favorite game, and I already knew everything about it before I had made that jurisdiction.
  OMORI can be a deeply personal game, though as implied, that depends on who's playing it. Those who can relate to many of the game's aspects may find themselves either finding comfort or sinking further into whatever dread that had found a connection to the game. Lucky for me, this game provided a scenario that let me ponder on my own thoughts as I played through it, both in and out of Headspace. I can still go back through the game's soundtrack and remember almost exactly what I was feeling and thinking when I first heard each individual track.
  I'd love to keep gushing about this game, but it's really only been my own experience with it. When someone who's just looking for a good story plays this game, although they might not relate to the game as hard as some others, they can still find an enjoyable and emotional story that they're likely to remember.
 
  I have problems with this game. The gameplay is disappointing; I really think the combat's emotion system could've been so much more than just fancy stat labels, and there isn't much variety in how to approach said combat. Headspace, too, feels largely unnecessary, being a linear path of what is effectively filler meant to waste time ([spoiler] and yes, I know that's the point, but I still think it's a bad execution of the idea [/spoiler]). The story, in my opinion, plays rather "by the book," really just being a blend of great qualities, but nothing really "flavorful." It's what it wants to be, grounded and emotional, and that's about it. That isn't to discredit it's quality! I'm just saying that if you want something unique and one of a kind, you might want to look elsewhere.
  Also, the developers. I haven't looked into any of the controversy surrounding them, but it seems that they're constantly wrapped in it, and there are accounts of the game's development being very problematic. Just knowing what I know, I don't feel comfortable at all supporting them.

  That's what I think. OMORI isn't the most emotional, nor is it the most inventive, innovative, or even realistic depiction. I do think, however, that its critical acclaim is justified. It's not a game for everyone, but it's still "general" enough to fit into a wide criteria. Go in with an open mind, letting your own thoughts entertain you through the silent noise of filler. Let yourself feel; you might find something unforgettable.

[h1] A long-awaited odyssey: OMORI delivers a masterpiece [/h1] 

Finally, after years of anticipation since the haunting melody of "Oyasumi" first graced my ears in 2016, I've had the chance to delve into the world of Omori. Life's twists and turns kept me away during high school and work but last month, I finally carved out the time to experience what has been an eagerly awaited journey.


[u] 1. Story [/u] 
Omori, drawing inspiration from the holy trinity of "Yume Nikki, EarthBound, and Undertale", manages to create an engaging and thoroughly enjoyable experience. The storyline, a complex web of emotions and revelations, left my mind in disarray. My hunches about MARI and the unfolding events proved accurate, yet the game's execution left me utterly shocked and enthralled. The dual endings, one melancholic and one hopeful, captivated me, refusing to release their hold until I saw both.

[u] 2. Visuals and soundtracks [/u] 
 Visually, Omori is a masterpiece, with each detail crafted purposefully and with love. The art style, drawstyle, and attention to detail elevate the game into an immersive and visually stunning realm.
The music, a hauntingly beautiful composition, strikes a perfect balance between calming and eerie, setting the tone for every emotional beat in the game. It's a soundtrack that lingers, enhancing the overall experience.

[u] 3. Charackters [/u]  
Character designs and personalities, initially met with ambivalence, evolved into a deep affection for every member of the cast. The pain, the coping mechanisms, and the struggles of these kids unfold into a tale that tugs at the heartstrings. Every character is relatable, each carrying the weight of their experiences.

[u] 4. Good elements [/u] 
 Omori's humor, influenced by Undertale, injects a layer of levity into its melancholic narrative. Silly moments and jokes, deal against the backdrop of a bizarre dream world, manage to make players smile amidst the emotional turmoil.
Plus the genius references, from Touhou to Fullmetal Alchemist, add another layer of charm. These nods, both silly and familiar, are scattered throughout, rewarding players with moments of recognition and amusement.

[u] 5. acceptable play hours [/u] 
Clocking in at the perfect duration for an RPG maker game, Omori strikes the delicate balance between a captivating storyline and a manageable playtime.

In conclusion, Omori is a masterpiece, a testament to the creative genius of Omocat. As I bid farewell to Mari and Hero, I am left in awe of the emotional rollercoaster this game has taken me on. Thank you, Omocat, for delivering an experience that will linger in my thoughts and emotions for a long time to come.

10/10

It was a good game. To be honest I thought the ending didn't make much sense, but if you ignore the main plot the rest of it is really really nice. The characters, moment to moment dialogue and all of the side stories were really sweet and well written. The horror elements were also very good. Soundtrack is really excellent. Also, a decision really early on completely splits the game into a whole other path that is totally different, and I just respect that massively for the amount of effort and commitment that takes.

Do not read the following before you have played the game.

[spoiler]
I do not believe the main twist makes sense based on what we have been shown of the characters involved. Mari has been piling pressure onto Sunny over the recital because of her perfectionism, and Sunny lashes out by breaking his violin. An argument ensues, and Sunny kills Mari by pushing her down the stairs in a moment of anger. Basil witnesses this and helps Sunny to disguise the murder by framing it as a suicide.

Let's start with Mari piling pressure onto Sunny due to her perfectionism. Her perfectionism is really not covered in depth by the game I feel, it's alluded to in small ways here and there but overall it's not really shown in any major scenes of the game or any flashbacks. She is otherwise shown as a sweet and doting sister to an almost absurd degree. She consistently prioritises Sunny, to the point of putting her own life in danger to protect him by diving in to save him when he almost drowns, and she is in floods of tears when he is finally revived. After this event she insists the group no longer hang out in their favourite spot to prevent triggering Sunny's trauma. She swaps beds with him when she notices that he has trouble sleeping. Overall, she puts her brother above herself in many if not all situations. I do not believe, from what we are shown of her character, that she would put enough pressure onto Sunny to cause him distress, and certainly not to the point where he would lash out physically.

That leads neatly to the next point - Sunny smashing his violin. This violin was gifted to him as a christmas present by all of his friends, many of whom go to lengths to get the money to afford it. This violin would absolutely be a cherished, if not treasured, possession of his. I do not believe for a second that he would destroy it, and especially not in some kind of petulant tantrum over his sister making him practice too much. Sunny is shown as an incredibly passive character, to the point he barely even talks, and he is also shown to treasure his friendship group to a fault. He is not shown as having any history of outbursts, especially violent ones, so I just don't see this event happening.

These reasons are also a large part of the reason I just cannot believe that the two siblings have their confrontation at the top of the stairs. Mari dotes on and protects Sunny, and Sunny is a passive and generally caring character. Mari would not have even started yelling at Sunny, and Sunny would not have violently lashed out, based on the information we have been given about the two characters. I note that this scene is never shown with any kind of hint towards the dialogue between the two during this confrontation - I think this is intentional, because were any to be written and included in the game, I think it would be much more noticeable how much of a flip for specifically Mari's character this confrontation is.

Once Mari has been pushed, Basil then tries to protect Sunny from getting in trouble for his crime by suggesting that they frame the death as a suicide, and then single-handedly hangs her from the tree in the backyard while Sunny sits in a catatonic state. This is a character who much like Sunny, is shown to be incredibly passive - he's a sweet little boy who likes flowers and taking pictures of his friends. Where he would get this horrifying idea, let alone actually suggest it to a boy who's just killed his sister, is beyond me. Again - we are not shown anything of Basil's character, any dark undertone or other inclination, that he would even be able to fathom this kind of plan, let alone suggest and then execute it. You could perhaps argue that he isn't thinking and is acting on some kind of instinct to protect Sunny, but I don't think a panic response would elicit something as dark as this out of nowhere, especially at 12 years old. 

Also, while I'm nitpicking, are the police in this town just non-existent? Hanging a body that clearly, from any kind of basic inspection, died from blunt force trauma and would be covered in bruises and is implied to be bleeding (Sunny's sheet music has blood on it) is a terrible way to cover up the murder. I could suspend my disbelief for this if the rest of the twist was believable, but since I already don't buy the twist, this just sticks out as something else preventing me from getting invested in the story.

Overall, I think the twist could have been more believable if the player had been given more indication that Mari would inflict her perfectionism on the other characters, or even just Sunny, and that Sunny was shown to react with panic/violence when put under pressure or from people intruding on his personal space. How you would fix Basil, I really don't know... I guess he would have to be shown to have a darker side or be willing to do dark/violent things to protect his friends. Perhaps if he was older also, as I just don't see a 12 year old coming up with the idea of staging a suicide.

Going into the game, the vibe I was picking up from what I was being shown is that Mari had committed suicide, blindsiding everyone, and that the various characters were coping with their grief in different ways. Dream Basil is removed from the dreamspace because he suddenly remembers Mari's death and Omori does not want to confront it. I was expecting a fairly heartfelt story of dealing with grief and sudden loss, but I feel like the game kind of threw all that away to have a big dark horror twist and a (as a result of the unbelievable twist) forced message of facing your past mistakes and confessing them with honesty, even if it means people might not forgive you. If the game had done more to show these darker sides/character flaws, and made more of a point of carrying the message of self-forgiveness and confronting mistakes from the beginning of the plot, it might have possibly landed better.

I really want to buy into this story, but I just can't based on how it set things up, and that's a shame - because it is otherwise incredibly well written, atmospheric, and clearly had a lot of love put into it. I do still believe this game should be played, but I just wish it had more consistency in its portrayal of the characters.
[/spoiler]

If someone were to ask me for an example of a video game that's also artistic, OMORI would easily be my first pick. I didn't know a game could make me cry until I finished this one. I'd really describe it less as a game and more as an extremely disturbing and touching story told in game form.

That being said, this game might challenge your patience. The primary motivator to continue is the drip feed of enigmatic horror moments, which convey the sense that something dark is waiting to be uncovered from beneath OMORI's brightly colored surface. Said moments are interspersed between long segments of RPG gameplay that can get stale in spite of the unique Emotion battle mechanic. Overall I think this pace is still forgivable and makes plot developments hit harder, but your mileage may vary. It's difficult to put into words how amazing the tail end of the game is, but I'm sure lots of people dropped it before getting that far.

I find it difficult to recommend OMORI for a lot of reasons. It does a lot right, but then screws it up along the way. 

     My first gripe is less with the game, and more with how the developer handled the game after the Kickstarter campaign was funded. I won't go into detail here, since you can look it up if you're interested, but I felt it was worth mentioning that I do not like OMOCAT, and this review is tinted by the lens of someone critical of their work.

     The game starts off strong with a lot of intrigue. It gets you invested in the world and has you wondering what the hell is going on. There are a lot of things that leave you confused, but it's easy to tell that those things are symbolic and will be explained in time. As someone who's a fan of the psychological genre, I felt they hit the perfect balance of bewilderment: enough to lure me in, but not so much that it was off-putting.

     Unfortunately, after those first 2 hours of intrigue, the game falls flat on its face and stumbles around for the next 25 hours or so. All of a sudden you're no longer playing a psychological horror game, but rather a stereotypical RPGMaker game that tries really hard to be Undertale. With practically no exposition whatsoever, the questions you had at the start go largely unanswered and ignored. Thankfully, the NPCs are written decently, and some of the scenes were amusing, I guess.

     The battle system is half-baked and easy as all hell. None of the party members felt like they excelled at anything, except for the healer character who was good at, well, healing. You end up just spamming basic attacks, and then the occasional AoE ability that all of your characters have a near-identical version of for some reason. It's just not fun, and that's coming from someone who enjoyed even DQXI's simple turn-based combat.

     During the last four hours or so, the game relentlessly dumps exposition on you. You aren't even really playing a game, it's practically just an interactive movie. It did a fantastic job of delivering the exposition, but what the actual hell? Like, why am I getting a feature-length movie of all the exposition that could have been given to me throughout the 25 hours of boring questing? The promise of exposition would have made those awful battles at least bearable to play through, because the story truly is interesting.     
     
     OMORI feels like a 6 hour game that OMOCAT somehow bloated to 30 hours, completely sacrificing the integrity of the game and cadence of the storytelling in the process. It flat out is just NOT fun without the psychological horror aspect or plot exposition.       

    I'm happy I bought and played through OMORI, but I can only recommend it if you're a fan of the psychological genre and are willing to sit through 20-ish hours of bloat in order to get to the game's phenomenal finale.

Let me start this by saying this game was wild, roller coaster of emotions. This game is a great example of how trauma, depression and anxiety affects all of us, how we all handle it in different ways and how they affect others when we handle our traumas said way. OMORI was a beautiful game that I thoroughly enjoyed playing. The characters felt realistic in their personalities, I kept thinking to myself "this kid has amazing friends that I wish I had.", the design of the game is beautiful, the story line is engaging, etc. in short, I highly recommend playing this game, this game makes it clear that if you stay true to yourself and don't give in and you persist that everything is going to be okay.

Even if this game has been out for 5 years, 20 years, or for centuries tucked away into the deepest bowels of your Steam recommendations, O M O R I is honestly better played blind. I ain't spilling, but it's like laughing until you can't laugh anymore and then start crying because you can't handle breathing because of how much you've been laughing and find yourself in a horrible middle ground between pain and pleasure.

But honestly, there is no fear of missing out with this game. There is only fear. And missing out on a well-spent life. But if you do decide to start playing this game for yourself out of curiosity, I will only say, this game is not just an RPG. Sure you have a role, as a player, of a game, but then things get so much better from the world around you turning so much worse.

You can choose to avoid everything, or you can try to put in the effort to change the world for the better. Sure, it might only make things worse or put you through your own personal hell, but at the end of day, it's all done for the friends you've made along the way!

Right?

This is honestly one of my favorite games that I have played. Amazing characters, great soundtrack, unique visual design, and contains deeper psychological themes that most games will not dare delve into today. The gameplay is an interesting take on the classic RPG style but instead with emotions which can all have strengths and weaknesses. This game contains 3 different endings, which are all worth checking out and this is one of those games that I think it is worth getting all the achievements for since there is so much detail in this game. These are some of my favorite characters that I can certainly relate and empathize with, as they are just written so well. As for story and theme, I cannot go into it as it will spoil the game, but I would highly recommend this game to anyone. If you like humor like Undertale or Earthbound this game will be for you.

OMORI does a great job of slowly revealing its dark and tragic plot through a whimsy and adorable adventure. That contrast between endearing and edgy makes the experience that much more unsettling. With the help of superb soundtracks and fantastic art style, OMORI really managed to touch my heartstrings.  

My only complaint is that the game is too long for this type of story, and it ruins the pacing. Some obnoxious characters that overstay their welcome and distract from the actual plot. Although I admire the amount of content they crammed in, I think in this case less is more. 

If you like JRPGs you probably already played this. If you don’t like JRPGs know that there is a worthy experience if you can force through some repetitive combat and boring side plots.
This game actually made me shed tears, its so happy and wholesome but the dark truth behind it is interesting.

One of the most fun games i've ever played! The characters are written really well, and the dialogues are all really fun to read... 

The story is captivating, and i think that going into the game with absolutely no knowledge about the plot whatsoever would be literally unforgettable... Yet, i have to say, even though i had spoilers for what would happen at the end, i still managed to enjoy my stay, and i even cried like a bitch in the ending of the game!

I heavily recommend it, truly one of the most passionate projects i've seen in the internet, and it's definitely a game deserving of my money... Despite all of the struggle necessary for this game to come out (nearly a decade of work), i really think it's my favorite game... And i thank OMOCAT and the team for not giving up on it.

Conclusion: I fucking love air conditioning... (and you should buy the game, i guess)

Edit:
I did this review at about 91.8 hours of game time, and will be doing an actual review of this game now that I have an additional 200 or so hours logged.

OMORI is a story-driven indie RPG that was in development for 5 years. It is phenomenally well written, with tons of symbolism that all ties to the story's focal point. There is not a single detail in this game that does not serve a purpose, which is incredibly impressive. The gameplay is quite easy, despite the complexity of the mechanics. I've done several challenge runs across my nearly 48 playthroughs of this game, as the surprisingly deep mechanics lend themselves to a lot of variety. Unfortunately, some of the options available are simpler, and downright better. Like nuking every boss in, at minimum, a couple of turns with kel's run n gun skill. The story is the focus, so I can forgive the gameplay on some level. OMORI has one of the best representations of mental health and trauma I have seen in a video game, and its usage of psychological horror is top notch. OMORI lures you into a false sense of security with headspace, only to catch you off guard with the horrors lying underneath, in a way that flows incredibly well. Even if you dislike horror, you might like OMORI because of the vast breaks in tension that headspace provides. After all, this is a quirky indie rpg with compelling characters. I absolutely recommend it.

I dont know. I played it about half way through. And then I watched someone play it about half way through a year later. And I just couldn't get into it either time. I love these kinds of games too. Anything inspired by Earthbound is gonna usually attract my attention but I felt the story was disjointed. It's telling two stories at once, the story in the dream world, and the story in real life, and they just feel so separate from each other. I found myself constantly wanting to get back to the story in the real world and just felt like I was forcing myself through the dreamworld segments that were throwing out a lot of charm and silliness but I was like "Okay thats great and funny and all but its hard for these constant stream of silly jokes to land when I feel there are more pressing matters at hand." 

Really wanted to like it. But its fine that I didn't honestly. I feel plenty of people obviously love it for good reasons. And there are plenty of good reasons to love it. Just wanted to express how I felt about it.

(total playtime is like 40h, and watched about 60h)
I play a lot of games, so very few of them have any effect on me. After finishing this game, it took a few weeks for me to not think about it every day. It is a really good depiction of how a person might deal with whatever life threw at them. It is completely filled with emotions, and the game conveys so much of that by just visuals, faces, how things are drawn, actions etc. instead of text. You sometimes just look at a thing, and you will think of that for days. I am listening to OST and I tear up, I played this game a few years ago like, bruh, what the fuck? Can you stop your influence already, I want to be able to like other games again.

OMORI is undoubtedly my favorite piece of media of all time, I cannot express with words how much I love every facet of this game, this is the only game that I have ever sought and attained 100% completion for a game, and I did it because I literally didn't believe how much I loved this game and how close to perfect this game is in what it seeks to accomplish. Please for the love of God play this game and under no circumstances spoil it for yourself, the only thing I will say in this vein is, if given the option ALWAYS OPEN THE DOOR.

I am a very, very unemotional person, before playing this game I probably hadn't cried since I was a young child and the only thing that has made me cry since playing this game is things relating to this game (notably a song that plays towards the game's end), Evangelion and Hashihime of the Old Book Town, all of which are things I engaged with (at least partially) because I explicitly wanted to feel what OMORI made me feel on my first play-through (and it only was ever even challenged by Evangelion).

...and not only does this game have a heart wrenching story, almost every other aspect of it is either the best in a video-game or above average for what the game seeks to achieve.
The music is the best I've seen in any piece of media except music itself by a wide margin, even years after playing, tracks like GOLDENVENGEANCE and My Time (Bo En) still give me chills and other tracks make my eyes water and one has even made me cry with the music and it's associations alone. I also listen to the more ambient tracks quite often in the background.
The art (directions & execution, not graphical fidelity) is probably the best I've seen in any game, the pixel art while being quite generic in style, is incredibly detailed, pretty and instantly recognizable as uniquely OMORI, this game also includes hand drawn and animated scenes and images which pop up quite often, and are executed as best as I think you could with the art-style.
The game-play; compared to a typical games like say Call of Duty or Mario Kart isn't great; but first of all it doesn't need to be and second of all, for a JRPG it's pretty good and quite creative. For me at least, the game-play kept me completely entertained for  full play-throughs of both of the main routes (one of which is much more game-play heavy than the other).

(Minor Spoilers for the names of certain routes ahead)

I have played through this game fully 4 times as of yet. My initial playthrough, where I got what I think is the 'intended' ending, the 2nd where I did the Hikikomori ending, the 3rd where I got the achievements I didn't get on my 1st and 2nd playthroughs, and a 4th where I simply replayed the game for enjoyments sake. I constantly tell myself, OMORI could not have been as good as I remember it being, and every time I have replayed the game, I find it IS as good, I find that the game still has the same magic as it did on my first playthrough, and although I don't think I will ever feel the way my first playthrough made me feel, OMORI makes me feel a way that nothing else has ever made me feel. I have cried every single time I have played this game, at least once, usually twice, my eyes still water up when I hear Mari's signature tune and OMORI still gives me gives me chills constantly. I don't think I could possibly explain how OMORI makes me feel with words, all I can say is, please buy this game. The only thing that holds this game back from a perfect 100/100 (Which has never been achieved in my eyes) for me is that some parts of the game can drag on just a tad once you're on your 3rd or 4th play-through.

98/100

I've completed two endings so far and I honestly think this game is amazing, the story was really good and I thought I knew where it was going but I turned out to be right then absolutely wrong, (which is good!) The horror is definitely a little bit scary at times especially when it happens at points where you don't expect it, but once you get hooked on the story you'll probably be more focused on that then on a couple of spooky encounters.

Pros: 
-An amazing art style.
-A really good soundtrack.
-Some really amazing story telling.
-Multiple endings.
-Absolutely at no point do you need to grind, which may be bad for some but I'm going to consider it as a pro.
-Spooky moments.
-it's a decently sized game and the multiple game endings gives you a lot of content for how much you are paying.

Cons:
-There is no difficulty options so if you are looking for a harder experience you'll probably be a bit dissatisfied with that.
-If you are looking for a horror game that will scare you, this may not be the right place to look. The couple of jump scares you get won't scare you that much compared to something like Outlast.
-The reverse of the last point, if you are looking for a cutesy game then technically this would work however I am pretty sure when you get further into the game you might get a little freaked out.
-At one point in the game there are some pretty easy puzzles, but if that's not what you are into it may bring you to a halt and probably to a walk-through, (they aren't that hard so probably not though.)

Well anyways that is my review, I would totally recommend buying this game if the pros from earlier interest you! If it's on sale then I'd say even if this isn't something you would normally like, try it out anyways and see what you think. If you get the game I hope you enjoy your play-through! :>

Gameplay: 4 | Narrative: 5 | Graphics: 4.5 | Soundtrack: 5 | X-Factor: 5

When I think about the kind of games I want to play in the future, Omori is one of those titles that make me go "I want to play another game like this one day." And by that, I mean that this game is very special.

GAMEPLAY:
Omori plays out like your typical run-of-the-mill rpg, where you move around the world and interact with objects and people. But what makes this game special is the story behind it, that puts weight behind those actions. The combat is turn-based, and has a unique mechanic primarily revolving around three emotions: happiness, anger, and sadness. Happiness makes you weaker in exchange for boosting your luck and speed, anger boosts your attack in exchange for lowering your defence, and being sad raises your defence in exchange for being slower. As well, enemies could be inflicted with emotions as well, creating a rock-paper-scissors scenario of what status beats what (e.g. attacking a happy enemy with a sad attack is super effective). This battle mechanic felt fun and fresh, while also not being forced upon you as you could brute force through most of the overworld enemy encounters. As someone that loves high damage values, I sincerely apologize to Hero, Kel, and Aubrey for keeping them mad 99% of the time <3.

At some point during the game, you can play slots at a casino. And this holds a very special place in my heart, as the slots are always randomized regardless of if you reload your save. That is, I reloaded my save over and over again until I became filthy rich <3 Thank you OMOCAT for blessing me with this gameplay experience. It was the best hour of my life and if I got the chance to relive it, I would in a heartbeat.

NARRATIVE:
The story is where it really hits home with this game. As much as it's funny, quirky, and happy, it can be sad, tragic, and dark... Lines between reality and delusion blur, and the game makes you scared. Scared for the characters, scared of the past. Scared that the characters you've come to love and care about won't have a happy end. There's so much that I could say, but this is a story you have to play for yourself, without hearing about it from others. If you haven't experienced OMORI's story, yet, all I can say is: enjoy.

GRAPHICS:
The art style is so cute. Battles are so charming and full of life because of all the expressions the characters have, and can we talk about how you become a piece of toast when you die in game? Obviously, this game isn't all about being cute and Omori absolutely delivers on the unsettling and eerie art as well. I love the dichotomy.

SOUNDTRACK:
Just like the graphics, the music for this game is sometimes cute, sometimes eerie, or a little bit of both! Says a lot about this game. Needless to say, the music is amazing, fitting, and enhances the player experience.

OVERALL: 5/5
Recommended for those that like feeling emotions and getting depressed. Upon finishing this game I laid on my bed and thought about life. We need more games like this <3

I first saw this game on YouTube. A play through of it was recommended to me, but I always held off on watching it. After a few years of that same video reappearing, I finally decided to play it. When I started I had a hard time with the large word and battle mechanics. It’s just the way my brain’s wired I suppose. I simply can’t handle an intricate world that big, and I couldn’t get into the combat. Even through I really wanted to. I stopped playing the game, never making it past the garbage dump. A long while later I decided to watch a playthrough so I could finally see what happens. I found myself skipping through most of the early parts, which I am okay with. But wow, the story, the beauty of it. I loved it so much, I think it’s truly incredible. If you are interested in this game but can’t get into it then PLEASE watch a playthrough or something so you can still experience this masterpiece of a story. It’s worth it, it really is.

The story fully lived up to the hype. It's good.

Gameplay wise, this is a pretty huge game as well that, on a fairly completionist run, lasted me 50 hours in the first run, probably more counting reloads and stuff. There are alternate routes, pretty big ones too, so this game can last you a ton. Like Hollow Knight this game is extremely worth its price off sheer content alone, which manages to remain of high quality and made with a lot of visible care through the whole thing.

The only criticism for the game that I can come up with is that, if you're into RPGs, the game mechanics are interesting but for at least most of the time you're not really required to optimize at all in order to progress. Most bosses can be beaten on first try without many issues. On the opposite hand, if you despise traditional RPGs then the story is still totally worth it but you'll still have to go through a lot of RPG stuff in order to get to the meaty stuff.

Issues with personal preferences aside though, the game is objectively well made both in story and gameplay, and it's a must try for indies.
