I am now incredibly sad. But it's a good thing. At the heart of Omori's brilliance is its soundtrack, a musical marvel that deserves special mention. Composed with finesse and emotional depth, the music not only complements the game's surreal atmosphere but becomes an integral part of the storytelling. From hauntingly melancholic tunes that tug at heartstrings to exhilarating compositions that amplify the intensity of battles, the soundtrack serves as an emotional conduit, enhancing every moment of the journey. The synergy between the visuals and the music is nothing short of magical, creating an immersive atmosphere that is rare to find in gaming. Each note feels purposeful, drawing players deeper into the enigmatic narrative. Whether wandering through the dreamlike landscapes or facing the emotional complexities of the characters, the soundtrack acts as a guiding force, accentuating the highs and lows of Omori's intricate tale. Beyond the music, Omori boasts a unique turn-based combat system, inventive puzzles, and a captivating narrative that weaves through dreams and reality with finesse. The hand-drawn art style is a visual feast, complementing the game's dreamy and occasionally eerie ambiance.In conclusion, Omori by OMOcat is a triumph in storytelling and game design, offering a rare blend of emotional depth and immersive game-play. The soundtrack, in particular, stands as a testament to the creators' commitment to delivering an unforgettable experience. This game is a must-play for those seeking a journey beyond the ordinary, where every note and every step resonate with the echoes of a truly remarkable adventure.

This is my comprehensive review of "Omori". This review will contain spoilers, and details of Omori which are better experianced than watched or read. Basically Go play the game first! I will have the first paragraph spoiler free if you would like to have an informed decision before buying the game. 

Omori is a 2D retro Disturbing Rpg Thriller (thats a lot of words at once). It combines elements of Mother, Undertale, Doki Doki, and many other titles. It is unique in many ways including its emotion system and cast of characters. I would say most play-throughs of the game will last 15 or more hours. Two things to know to decide whether Omori is for you. Omori is a Slow game, this does not mean that parts of the game are entertaining but they are slow and are meant to be savored. Secondly Omori is a very disturbing game, this game dives head first into suicide, murder, child abuse, child endangerment, and more. It is not for the faint of heart and will Fuck with you. 
[spoiler]
***Spoilers Ahead***
(spoiler)
Discussing the story
 Omori begins in a fantastical world where you and your friends battle bunnys, space boyfriends, and alligators. After learning its Mechanics you are tasked with finding Your friend Basil. You and your friends search for Basil in a plethora of zones like in the space-like Otherworld, underwater Deep Well, and the spider infested Pyrefly Forrest. These sections of the game are filled to the brim with Comedy, heartfelt moments, interesting characters and interactive fights.

Interludes take place inbetween these sections when "you" Omori (Who's real name is Sunny) wake up to find out that real like is not so dreamy. Your friends are at eachothers necks, youve all grown distant, and something terribly wrong has happened to your older sister Mari. She has [strike] died [/strike] gone and it has driven all of you apart. It is three days until you "Sunny" move away. So you must get your affairs in order helping your old friends reunite before you leave.

These sections of the game tend to be more of Fetch quests going around town picking up items or running chores. They are cozy, real, and uncertain.

Ive neglected one last aspect of the story, [strike] Mari [/strike] her. Something happened and it has taken a hold of us. Why is she after us? Why is Basil afraid of us? WHat did she dO?! WhAT DId hE dO?!
...
what did we do...
...?
Omori made its way into my heart, into my mind, and finally into my fucking Nightmares. Jesus this game fucked me up. Omori has a story like no Other where you can never be sure that what you know is real or true and it gracefully unveils this knowledge in its final act. 

Discussing the Gameplay
Omori uses a turn based combat system with Party building aspects. You can't change the members of your party but you can change your party members skills, weapons and Charms. This adds a lot of versatility to the game making combat heighten towards later game. Bosses can be challenging yet satisfying to beat giving you clear roads to success through memorizing attacks and patterns in combat.

Combat in Dream world offers a lot of versatility whilst real life is less open to mistakes. For the very little combat in the real world most encounters are meant to show credible writing rather than flawless game design. These fights are most often repetitive and crushing as you only have a couple options and some of those options are clearly not viable.

The last bit of gameplay I wanna discuss is the Nightmare fights. Often you face nightmares in which you will be forced to learn a new character development like calming down, persiting, or focusing. These have added benifits to dream and real world. Most of these are quite short and are meant to be story driven what particulary aches in me though is the Finale. The finale is basically a 1 to 2 hour nightmare. It takes far to long to collect all the memories, then to go through all the doors, and then cut off all the fingers, ect. This part felt like it dragged on and on. Parts of it were particularly memorable like watching basil die multiple times. But parts of it needed to be trimmed down. Especially because the Final fight between Omori and Sunny was basically a forced complete through specific button presses.
[/spoiler]

To summarize
Omori sucessfully delivers a game that will force you to think, act, and change. Its gameplay revitalizes turn based rpgs by using new mechanics and cutesy art to keep you entertained. The characters will make you hate, love, and laugh at them.  Omori is a game about childhood, depression, and change.

I really really want to like this game but the pacing and gameplay is just so boring. I enjoyed the first 30 mins but after that nothing interesting has happened in the 15 hours since then. The game started off with an interesting premise of finding a missing person but after that it feels like I've just been doing irrelevant side quests for the whole time I'm playing. The combat is really boring and tedious on top of the game throwing so many fights at you. 

I think the game would be much better as a visual novel style game with a much more concise and better paced story.

Edit: I ended up finishing the game many sessions and months later. The last act of the game was much shorter and to the point; it did not have any of the grueling combat and actually focused on characters/story. The ending was quite poignant and definitely makes slogging through the game feels much more worth it. However, I still wouldn't not recommend the game as it was often miserably boring. Doing something I did not find fun for ~25 hours for a good payoff just doesn't feel great. I've probably dropped this game 10+ times and I really had to find the willpower to sit through it until the end.

When making a quirky Earthbound-inspired RPG about depression, you can never be too careful about becoming a target for mockery. No one wants to be the guy that made YIIK. Yet unlike Undertale, Omori doesn't take refuge in audacity or silliness. Unafraid of being dismissed as corny, it bares its heart, plays its plot very straight, and doesn't shy away from extremely heavy topics.

I don't doubt that a lot of players will be upset by the sting in this tale - it verges on the unforgivable. Yet, lacking the clear black-and-white of a typical RPG, its story was one I thought about long after the end credits had rolled. For that, I feel, the game deserves credit.

That, and its unique art style, and its unsettling undertone of horror, and for how it captures the wistful feelings of a youth that will have passed most of its players by; so much so that the real-life sections are more absorbing than the fantasy ones. Omori is a game that feels like it was made for 'my generation,' because who else would laugh as hard at an Internet Explorer download window being a video game boss?

The most emotionally impactful game I've ever played

I have played many video games in the past, but there has never been one that could close the gap to my heart as effortlessly as OMORI has. The first hour or so of this game is misleading, probably intentionally so. I thought this was going to be a cute lo-fi aesthetic RPG with some, quite frankly, sluggish combat, or something along these lines. But as I progressed through the game and the first major plot point, I realized: I wasn't playing OMORI for the gameplay, no, there are clearly better RPGs than this. But the story, the world, the characters... now this is something worth exploring. And believe me when I tell you that in the end of it all, I regret even thinking of doubting this game at the beginning.

I can't say much without getting into spoiler territory, but I can tell you this: OMORI has so, so many powerful ways of gripping your heart, tightly so. One moment you'll find yourself with a glowing grin and watery eyes, then moments later you'll be feeling the painful chills down on you as you slowly explore the horrible truth. You CARE about what is happening, without the game making you do so. It is the most meaningful game I've ever played in terms of presentation... the world building is meaningful, the horror aspects of this game are meaningful. Everything matters, and this game will make you realize this thoroughly.

What is even more astounding, is that such a brilliant game was made in RPG Maker. It just shows that a bold vision can shine adamantly even on restricted environments. Five years of rough development that paid off tremendously. A tiny group of individuals that wanted to create something beautiful. Even on RPG Maker, this game looks amazing. The little details in every level, the gorgeous pencil-drawn animations, the expressive character portraits, complementing each other to deliver a bizarre, colorful world... the soundtrack is very beautiful and very well achieved...

OMORI is sad, it is happy, it is terrifying, it is a macabre ode for young people, it is a message of love and forgiveness. OMORI is a warm smile in the cold fog, in the endless void. It is a reminder. A reminder to look ahead, past the overwhelming darkness. There, somewhere, you'll find the smiles and love of the ones waiting for you. So don't keep them waiting...

I purchased OMORI originally for the "psychological horror" tag and rave reviews. I finally started playing it last month and, as you can guess from my hours, I couldn't really stop till I reached an ending. I was told by friends and reviewers to go in blind and I'm glad I took that advice. I would write paragraphs about this game and why I love it, but I don't want to spoil anything for YOU.
So here's my spoiler free review: OMORI has a well-written story, great music, wonderful art and visual details, and I wish I could go back and play this game anew, knowing nothing again. Moreover, there's lots of things to do, all the time. I love to explore every bit of a map and OMORI rewards you for that. I never felt bored and, honestly, I've started 2 more saves to get the rest of the achievements and to play another route. 
10/10 I recommend this game to everyone, though mind the warning the game gives you for certain topics.

Play this game. I don't think you will for sure call it a one of the best games you have played, but by the end of it you are very likely to call it a one of the best [b]stories[/b] you have ever played. 

OMORI has good, even great, soundtrack, but it isn't a masterpiece. OMORI has awesome art style, but it obviously isn't mind blowing or anything like that. OMORI has fine gameplay, but for many, at some point, it can become not exciting enough and then the game just kinda turns into grinding your way through many a bit repetitive levels. Still it's worth pointing out that even though the gameplay is simple, thanks to few tricks, the limitations of the game engine aren't that noticeable and it still can be very fun. And finally OMORI has an absolutely incredible story. It is for sure its strongest aspect. Very rarely a game is able to invoke such emotions in so many people, while adjusting to their decisions in the way that feels mostly fair and reasonable. Apart from that, man, I have never played a game that made me go trough my entire phone photo gallery to relive memories with my friends and actually greatly appreciate it, while being grateful for them. Until now.

In conclusion if you're doubtful just play it. Even though of course OMORI has flaws I believe the message is completely worth it

11/10 would recommend

OMORI is a story that I think most people should experience, a game about friendship, tragedy, memories and the overcoming of trauma. 
I don't know if I should be worried or relieved that this game had made me have the raw emotional reaction that I had. Happy tears, followed by sadness followed by... I don't even know how to describe it but i never thought a game had the ability to change me like this one did. It may seem like I'm overplaying it by saying it changed me, but it did. It showed me a whole new perspective in life that I've never seen before. It showed me that there's road to forgiveness... a long. painful. gruelling road to forgiveness...

[spoiler] There is no easy way to write this but, the game made it so easy to project my experiences into the plot of it, might have been by pure chance, but being a musician with my sister and her being the reason as to why I started learning to play might have made it more painful when I discovered the truth in Omori's plot. The fact that something so bad can happen that trauma disables you for a good part of 4 years...[/spoiler]

I'm baffled as to why this game didn't recieve any awards and how it isn't talked about more. It's message is very important, especially during the pandemic as everyone has experienced isolation to some extent for the better part of nearly 2 years. Probably it's just a matter of time until some famous youtuber picks it up and drives tons of people to play it (vicariously or not) and talk about it.

This is my favorite game as of writing. 

A full 10/10

ps:. If you're finding this review before you purchase the game(either by the friend activity tab or I somehow reach the top of reviews), do it! You don't have to like JRPG's to love the story of OMORI. You only need to have a soul

This game kinda sucks. It was unclear what I was getting into but the trailers made it look interesting enough. Unfortunately it's tagged with "psychological horror" when it probably aligns more with Adventure Time or Steven Universe. It's a fluffy cotton candy game about mental illness, it is not psychological horror.

If there's some depth that I am missing by giving up at the 3 hour mark I'd still say it's the fault of the game. I did not feel like the world was interesting enough for me to want to explore.

I will give it up that this is probably the most polished RPG Maker game I've ever played, but beyond that I can't in good faith recommend this.

I bought and played this game the day it was released, and had been following the updates while it was being developed. I have to say this game makes me cry every time I play it, no matter what, whenever I hear the final duet I will cry. Its so wonderfully made, well thought out, and looks incredible. The fighting mechanics are easy to understand and fun to pay, the various fear designs and the little creatures are spectacular. I will forever not regret purchasing this game. Each and every ending was well fitted for whatever route you took. The themes of grief, guilt, and fear are so well put together and coexist perfectly, intertwining into one masterpiece of a game. There are so many little details that improve the play-through exponentially, the hangman game, blackjack, and so much more. If you are debating on buying Omori, just do it, you wont regret it.

One of those games that stay in your memories for many years after completing them. 
The characters are very well written: dialogues are creative and filled with puns, jokes and funny interactions between them. 
The story is engaging and interesting: plot twists and secrets won't be missing.
The art style is very unique, as in being a mix of various genres that work great together. 
The gameplay is fine - it's a RPG adventure with horror elements to it. Personally I find it to be its weakest point, but I was so absorbed into the story that I didn't care too much for the lack of depth of the combat system. 
Overall a great game, possibly even a must play, even tho it could be a bit too niche to reach that status. But personally I would highly recommend it.

it's been years since i last wrote a review of a game that was more than a sentence or two.

but here goes:

omori is a turn based rpg set in and outside of a teenager's dream.

its fantastical and fun elements of the dream parallel and contrast the real life sections of the game, making for something serious with a lot of heart.

this game is like a rollercoaster, but it truly is a perfect blend of humor and sadness.

also, the energy mechanic during battles is such a neat idea that im gonna be sad to play other turn based rpgs that dont have it.

don't let anyone tell u otherwise.

and [i] don't ever let anyone tell u that it's too late to tell the truth. [/i]

it never is.

please purchase this video game so there can be more like it.

OMORI is a stunningly beautiful game which is filled to the brim with character. I would even say it is worth playing for the art style and characters alone. Combat is engaging and fun when fighting enemies and bosses for the first time. Generic enemies can be a slog to get through however they are mostly completely avoidable so I cant fault that too much. The story itself is best gone into blind so I will not get into it any further than saying that it was not at all what I was expecting and that it was very enjoyable to go through. Overall OMORI is a story game with amazing style and fun game-play that is unforgettable in the best ways possible.

I'll keep this short (and spoiler free). I went into this game thinking it was gonna be good, but nothing amazing. This is my favorite game now, and it's not even close. The visuals, music, and especially the damn story and characters are an easy 10/10 for me, the most a game (or any piece media) as ever emotionally effected me as a person, literally perfect as far as I'm concerned.
The gameplay works, but I wouldn't really call it good per say? Not bad and get's the job done, but not what I'd exactly call the best part of the game. Not a big deal for me personally since every single thing else is perfect for me, but I can easily see this turning someone off from liking the game to it's fullest extent.  Also some of the achievements are nightmarish to get without a guide (or even with a guide), if that's something that matters to you. 
Flawed Masterpiece is the word of the day with this one, but it's very easy for me to look over the faults of this game when everything else about it is seemingly perfect.

One of the few games that has brought me to tears. Omori is a game that brings you in with its colorful world as well as its beautiful music. All the characters are relatable and you get attached to them by the end of the game.

I played this game over a year ago, and I gotta say...

This game stays with you. The story, characters and environment of both the real world and the dream world are beautifully designed and written. The games you feel as this group of friends are real people you know and haven't seen in so long, and that all the dreams are memories you experienced with those friends. 

The endings are all heartbreaking but all fitting. This game is definitely worth the money. It's one of my most favorite games ever and I think you'll definitely not regret buying this game, as long as you are looking for a very deep and emotional experience with a good 16 bit rpg and emotion based combat system.

I had a lot of prejudice towards this game back when it first came out. Never really bothered to look into it and just assumed what everyone said about "quirky earthbound-inspired rpg" to be accurate.
Bought it as a joke in early February and played it for an hour or two, before I didn't touch it till late October.
There's not really a good way for me to describe it, but I feel like after beating it now it's one of the most well crafted, emotional, and beautiful narratives that I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I don't consider myself to be emotional, but even then I was basically bawling during the credits.
I could go on and on about how I related to the game and how it helped me come to terms with so many problems in my life, but I feel like it's better to just say:

play the game.

I can't express that enough. 

I won't be forgetting this one anytime soon, if ever. 
11/10.

This is going to be a very stereotypical review so prepare for that. This game is absolutely beautiful with its story and the things that you can do! Two routes and four endings! The two routes are similar yet so different and I love it! The smallest actions can do a lot, especially for achievements! I'm currently 79/84 achievements and working on the last five now! The soundtrack is fun and exciting too! Only issue that I have is how much grinding you might have to do to fight the bosses (especially two days left). Other than that, I completely recommend it! Though be warned, one of the tags is psychological horror for a reason don't play if you are triggered by knives, suicide, death etc. Have fun playing if you buy it!

A deeply emotional experience that warrants multiple playthroughs, "Omori" is one of the greatest indie RPGs to grace my steam library. The main thing to note about this game is the sense of nostalgia, especially with the headspace area, that definitely shows strokes of Earthbound and honestly the entire 90s decade. This is furthered by the Faraway Town portion of the game, which is basically like a 90s hangout with your friends made into a game. This is balanced superbly with horror, as the games more intense imagery (i.e. blackspace) could have been too much if not for the happier headspace areas. The battle system is great too, though I think the emotions mechanic could have been utilized more than it was.

Overall, an amazing experience that hits you right in the gut. 10/10

OMORI is a psychological horror game, a game which I jumped into when I wasn't really in the best place in life, a friend recommended me and even paid for my copy of the game, It tackles dark topics which include depression, anxiety, and suicide, It's really important to take these warnings seriously and look out for yourself before jumping head first into a game with trigger warnings like these, don't be me (I broke-down way too often)

 I would highly recommend playing the game yourself first. especially blind, onto the review now.

My first play-through was a quiet night. Being completely alone and isolated helped me understand this game correctly. The first few hours were something I've never experienced in a game before, little things like the title screen, the music, and the recurring themes of familiarity of this dream world through its fantastic soundtrack, The music seriously enriches the player's understanding of this overall plot-rich/traumatic experience.

OMORI’s gameplay is in the form of a turn-based RPG, with a lot of exploration on the side, really simple and easy to understand, and can also be very rewarding in a very satisfying way, A lot of what you do in this game is explore with your friends and relive old memories together, while also making new ones which I found to enjoy a lot personally. especially with its story that heavily revolves around its lovable cast of characters, They all have their unique personalities, and their own lives which isn't dived into too much, but a lot of it is hinted at in a way that's realistic during the story.

the only criticism I would have for this masterpiece is its pacing, There are quite a few areas that drag on a bit too long for my liking especially when trying to interact with everything in the game. I find this game to be very hard to be able to replay with that in mind, especially for the many different endings it has to offer.

I really enjoyed OMORI and its wonderful art style, It's a game I will remember for years to come, It's had such a massive impact on me as a person through the story and tells a really important message that I think I needed to hear during the release of the game when I played it, which it delivers greatly on. definitely will be a steamroller of emotions and bangers once you launch this game. Thanks for reading my review.

Though OMORI is overall an enjoyable experience, the game is bloated by ~15 hours of gameplay that is generally unimportant to the main story of the game, save for the bits and pieces of the final Headspace sections and the very beginning of the game. The excessively large amount of dungeons bloats the game (especially in the final dungeon) and overall dampens the otherwise enjoyable story the game carries. The game feels as though it was not confident enough in its story to simply allow it to progress naturally without massive multi-hour sections of minor, one-note character moments, relatively boring rock-paper-scissors gameplay that tows the line of being mildly fun, so easy its boring, or so damage-spongy it's unbearable (looking at you, Humphrey), and slog-filled dungeons that only serve to meet Kickstarter goals and distract from the gripping story of the Real World sections of the game. Though this is likely intentional, showing how Sunny uses his Headspace as an escape from the stresses of the Real World and the trauma he has experienced, it does not translate well into the pacing of the game and after Pyrefly Forest, I was just wishing I could get back to the story and learn more about the real characters, not their watered-down, idealized Headspace counterparts.

I suppose this is all to say that the story of the Real World was so enjoyable and intriguing that the game left me actively wishing for more. Unfortunately, it only takes up around 5 hours of gameplay. Kel, Aubrey, Hero, and Basil are enjoyable characters and feel almost real, making their plights more interesting and making you feel for their characters. Watching the characters process and attempt to grow from their past is enjoyable and the overall message of moving forward from past actions and trauma is one that should be seen more in media and I am glad this game went to the effort to flesh out its messaging.

I'd recommend watching a let's play over playing the game yourself, since that way you can trim the fat of the game if you want to avoid the overly long Headspace sections. There's one section towards the very end I'd say is worth playing, but it's so late in the game I can't justify telling someone to spend $20 just to experience a 30 minute to 1 hour long section when you could get the same experience as it from Yume Nikki or its various fan sequels or clones for free with the added bonus of a better atmosphere.
I am scared yet happy, but not in the same time.

This game was SO close to being a masterpiece.

I usually start with the things that are good about the game but i am doing the opposite with Omori.
I know this point will be kind of subjective to some people but I value replayability a lot in games, I like going back to games I played to replay them, but I do not feel that way with Omori.
There are just some things from this game that affect this factor, which I will list right now:
1. The pacing was way too slow.
I don't mind when games are supposed to be slow and omori is a game that takes time to complete, but this one felt a bit too much.
That kind of hurts some moments of the game where sometimes i felt kind of bored and wanted something to happen, and this is not a game where I wanted to get bored at times, rather intrigued due to the story.
2. The game was a bit too easy.
Now, don't get me wrong, I get why this game was super hard, and hey, I am not saying games being easy makes the game overall worse, but I have to admit that it can hurt when replaying. At least for me.
3. Game was a bit too long.
I am not including extra content or other things to do here.
Sometimes it dragged way too long about things or certain sections just took an unnecessary amount of time to move on to another thing.
Again, I get why it's this way, but there was sometimes too much dialog, or some events could have been faster, yada yada.

These 3 things also can hurt the gameplay a bit, and gameplay is quite important for a game.
I also do not feel like the RPG part was something special, it's not bad tho, it works very well specially with the emotion system, but it's not amazing.
I would have liked if the side-quests also gave you "better rewards". Because sometimes they take the longest to complete, and is return sometimes they give you some clams that you could have gotten elsewhere or in a faster way. I am not saying I don't like them, they are a cool addition and a little extra, but they don't feel rewarding.

Gameplay and replayability is something I really care about, but that's pretty much the things I have against this game.
The rest of the game tho? It's amazing!

The story is perfect and original, there aren't a lot of games that speak about topics like phobia or depression in the way that Omori does, it's pretty unique in that department.
The characters are also perfect, there is absolutely nothing wrong with them, they are charmy, they are iconic and their designs are really cool.
The music is also insane! I see nobody talking about Omori's soundtrack but it fits both the RPG part and the topic that is covering, music is super important too and honestly, I wouldn't change a single track.
The style of the game is also really well done, mixing pixel-art with some realistic images and some anime-style drawings and characters was executed surprisingly well, specially for an RPG.
There is also quite a lot of stuff to do in this game, between side-quests, or secrets, or leveling up your party members, or getting some achievements. RPGs have a common flaw that is not having anything aside from the main story, so Omori doing this is a blast and I can see why 100% completing this game can be quite fun.

Overall, this was an incredible game and a great experience, specially the experience part that I would recommend.
It does suck that the bad things about it are kinda big for me, but if you do not mind them, you will think this game is amazing, and it is.
And for those saying this game is mid, no it's not mid.

RECOMMENDED!

I made it through the good ending but I wasn't impressed and I don't see myself playing the other routes.

The writing in this game is not convincing or engaging. Many features of the story felt very unbelievable (I don't mean the fantasy aspects, obviously). The characters don't act their ages and they don't have convincing reactions to the events they've gone through. They talk like characters in a children's cartoon, which is jarring for a game that deals with themes like suicide, mental illness and [spoiler]murder[/spoiler]. The different pieces of the game also didn't seem to add up to anything -- the whole thing felt like a collection of disparate elements that had nothing to do with each other. For how much story you actually get, there was a disproportionate amount of silly filler that wasn't entertaining (a lot of lame, forced humor) and didn't connect in any way to the real plot. All the side quests/plots are tedious and unrewarding.

I kept going because of the driving mystery (eventually skipping everything but the main plot actions), but in the end, the final reveal [spoiler]that Sunny killed his sister and he and Basil framed it as a suicide[/spoiler] made even less sense than the rest of the game. [spoiler]Why would Sunny, who never had any violent tendencies, suddenly do something like that? How and why did two twelve year olds come up with such a morbid deception? If it really was just an accident, why did they feel the need to present it as a suicide? How did anyone not notice that Mari's death was caused by blunt force trauma, not hanging? How did Basil manage to keep this a secret for four years?[/spoiler] The [i]reason[/i] for these events is largely left up to implication and only explained in some game data. [spoiler]But even given the explanation that Mari was putting too much pressure on Sunny before the recital, it was never shown that Mari's perfectionism had led to harsh treatment of anyone else.[/spoiler] 

It also feels like a major piece of the payoff is missing, since [spoiler]you don't get to see Aubrey, Kel and Hero's reactions to Sunny's revelation[/spoiler]. It's implied that [spoiler]they simply forgive him[/spoiler], which also rings hollow -- [spoiler]as sensitive, traumatized teenagers who have just been through serious emotional turmoil, it's likely that it would not be easy at all for them to adjust to this new understanding of events, even if they choose not to blame Sunny[/spoiler].

I'd been looking for a game to fill the Deltarune-shaped hole in my heart, but sadly, this was not it.

I don't know what to say. This game is indeed quite good. Not as insanely good as some say it is but still very good. Great soundtrack, decent gameplay (emotion system was neat but nothing that blew me away), and of course, the story. The disturbing underlying secret beneath the whole cutesy facade is what ACTUALLY makes me like the game as it has my favourite kind of horror.  A creeping horror that inexorably crawls up on you until the truth is slowly laid bare. My biggest complaint is the games pacing. It basically boils down to wandering around the dream world, something creepy happens, real life event, wandering around the dream world, something creepy happens, real life event, etc. At times it feels like some wacky thing happens for the sake of just giving you more game before you can have the next creepy bit revealed.
All in all, quite good and an easy recommendation. 8.7/10 I admit I shed a tear at the end but didn't full on cry like I did with mother 3.

This game is brilliantly well done! With such a perfect art style, music, maps, storyline, characters.. everything combined together will surely glue your face to the screen until you finish the main route!

The emotional rollercoaster that I felt while playing will be forever stuck in my heart. The sadness and fear from the perspective of the main characters are really well done in a way that I could see myself feeling the same thing. The love and friendship were really impactful as well, to the point of wishing I had a group of friends like that when I was a child ;u;
The goofiness accompanied by the visual and sound effects also made me laugh out loud most of the time (never thought I'd laugh from throwing things at a sad scarecrow - poor guy, I wish I could take him with me to explore the world)

I'm not sure if it's just me, but a few fights can get a bit boring over time, yet I still love it and will definitely play the other routes! I LOVE OMORI!

The game came off as pretentious to me when I initially tried playing it. I came back with a friend after a few months and we both thought it had a lot of great style, but leaned too far into absurdism (one of the supposed jokes in the beginning was about a nose talking to a leaf about a bunny...no punchline or context to pull it together, just random words together in a sentence), visuals for the sake of visuals, uneven pacing and definitely tonally uneven. The gameplay also seemed disjointed. There are no horror elements in the beginning. Instead, after 30 minutes of slice of life, absurdist, fluffy walking and reading text, the game then introduces battles. After 10 minutes the gameplay then shifts to that of an RPG Maker horror game, complete with a very telegraphed jump shock. I was having a very hard time holding interest both times I played, and by the time the turn based battles and horror aspects were introduced, I had a hard time being invested.

I did think the game had great style, especially with all of the hand drawn elements. I didn't think it all fit with the pixel style of the graphics however. I also thought there was some inventiveness in the combat with the different statuses, the positive and negative buffs in each, and how the statuses form a rock paper scissors weakness system. I also enjoyed all the tracks I heard.

This game has an overwhelming positive score and quite frankly I am very surprised. However it seems some thematic elements such as depression and suicide, as well as the art really resonated with most people who played it. It's possible that this game is just not for me, and that is fine, but I can't really recommend it to anyone.

This is probably one of the best games I've ever played. I adore it.

It took me quite a while to finish OMORI.  I would take breaks from it then come back and repeat the process. In fact, I am writing this review right after finishing the game. I'm not a very emotional person in general. It's very hard for me to get sad over something and even cry, but this game made me feel all types of ways. I never played a game that was so relatable and alive like this one. There were times in the game that were so relatable I just had to stop and think to myself like "Damn, is that how I'm seen / was?" I don't usually write reviews, but I had to for this. OMORI will have a special place in my heart forever. I had such a great time with the game and will continue to cherish it.

You ARE the main character. The main character IS you. You and the main character share the same mind. What you're thinking is what the MC is thinking. This game will make you think and feel what the MC is thinking and feeling. I can't explain how and why without spoiling the magic.

You may think MC is a non-verbal blank slate for the audience to project themselves on but that's far from the case. Despite being silent the whole game, MC is very well characterised and you'll have a very intimate understanding of him by the end.

Combat system is simple but allows for organic combos and strategies. Although, it is easy to find a winning strategy early on and stick with it for the whole game.

Wonderful artstyle all throughout with the exception of the pixel art which is okay and gets the job done and only excels on a few occasions. I wish more than just the main characters had dialogue portraits.

Some section go on for too long.

There's no quest log so you probably want to make your own real life notes about side quests and even the main story at some points. Otherwise you (and by extension the MC) will forget what you need to do. Also, if you're making notes IRL, the MC is also making notes in the game, you just don't see it.
HellMari will be in my dreams forever. But overall great music, characters (also the only horror game I can play.)

Very touching and collaborative.  OMORI says it's going to be one hell of a ride, but it kinda takes a long time getting there.  The bulk of the game is dream-state weirdness for weirdness' sake, and it feels jam-packed with throwaway characters.  But when you do get a taste of the story, it's yeah, a pretty freaking good story.

When my patience was waning, I just had to wait until the next fight.  Combat is engrossing and engaging, supported by a banger soundtrack that makes you feel like, hell yeah!  This matters.  You'll find so many opportunities to mix-and-match strategies with a long line-up of skills and equipment pieces.  It really feels like you're playing as a team of friends, making the story feel all that more impactful.

It's just a really sad story, too.  The build-ups serve a purpose for big payoffs.  Despite some weaknesses, OMORI is legend-status.  It also has lots of optional content.

Now that I've finished the game, I see where folks were coming from with the mixed feelings about the game. 99% of the game is brilliant. It's thoughtful, well made, visually gorgeous... but the ending [spoiler] felt like it was made that way for no real purpose other than to be edgy edgelords. It ruined my outlook on the game quite significantly as it sort of shit all over the character development that happens throughout the game [/spoiler].

It took me about 23hrs to clear with a few side quests completed, so I feel the pricing on it is fair and tbh this is my sweet spot for game length. I didn't feel like it dragged on at all, and it was long enough to explore things nicely. The music is a 10/10, art is 10/10, gameplay is a solid 8/10 and I'll recommend the game, but I have conflicted feelings about just how genuinely my recommendation is given how cheated I felt by it.

Please be aware of the content warnings for this game. They're not to be taken lightly. There's more comprehensive lists than the game advises and you can see some of them at https://www.dualshockers.com/omori-controversy-explained/ .

If you are in crisis and need to talk to someone, there are a few different global orgs listed at https://www.helpguide.org/find-help.htm

I even would go so far and say that Omori is my favourite game of all time. 
I cant even play other games without comparing it to Omori (Omori is just better) and I don't think that I can ever enjoy a game like I did with Omori anymore.

While I havent finished this version of the game, I have finished the switch version, and i must say I am really glad I played it. See, Im a huge wuss when it comes to horror elements in games, downright refusing to play them just because they got a bit spooky. This happened to me with OMORI (this game) a few years back. But once I got this game on the switch, i was like “im gonna finish this” and ended up playing through the whole thing. There are quite the number of spooky things in this game that i will not get into to avoid spoilerers, and when I got through all of it, i was kind of proud of myself. this was the very first horror game I have fully played through, and it even taught me a life lesson: You will never get over your fears unless you face them head on. And Ive been a lot better with that recently, as I have been doing things that I initially feared doing, like socializing more and inner tubing. Of course, I still have a ways to go, but I feel as this game has kickstarted my journey of self improvement. So thank you, OMORI, for helping me not be completely pathetic

This game is easily my favorite game of all time, the amazing art style with its deep story will make anyone who plays it interested. There is so much about this game that i absolutely adore, all of the characters are extremely well written and all pull on your heart strings its hard not to get emotional when playing this game. As someone who has dealt with a lot of anxiety, depression, and grief, the way this game portrays those feelings and thoughts is like no other, I truly felt seen when playing and its ending made me cry so hard even on multiple playthroughs. I do not want to spoil anything about this game for anybody because it will be ruined when you dont go in blind, I recommend OMORI to ANYONE who has dealt with similar things in the past, even if you are not a fan of the rpg genre the story of OMORI is worth it by itself, the heartbreaking characters and the amazing message and story is truly like no other, if you ever have the chance, please, play this game as soon as possible, you will NOT regret it.

The final 3rd of the game just really ruined it for me. Wouldnt recommend it to anyone I personally know, but if you want a Horror JRPG with some badass music and dope combat give it a shot.

Gameplay: *Possible Spoils* The gameplay loop is Dream World (Bulk of the gameplay) into the Real World (Bulk of the Story). When I got to the 3rd Dream World section, the pacing really fell off for me personally. Its the longest of the DW segments and the back to back bosses was unnecessary. Everything else was fine and unique. 

STORY: *ABSOLUTELY SPOILERS DO NOT READ* 
.
.
.
.
.
.
,
,
Ok so I know this will get hated, but what was that ending? Regardless of what Sunny did being on purpose or accident, why am I to feel bad for him. It really feels like the game wants me to justify his redemption due to all the "trauma" hes been dealing with. But what about the pain and suffering he inflicted upon basil? Not only did he put basil through the "accident", he hung his "best friend' out to dry. What about the pain he caused to all of his friends? WHAT ABOUT THE FUCKING CAT? Most killers start off by killing helpless animals. Also makes sense because what is the most common enemy in SUNNY'S Dream...........bunnies. Completing this game gave me a heavy SH2, except trying to get me to justify James is a good guy.

So, it's been a little while since I played an rpg horror and games like these always bring me back to Ib and Misao. Part of me was expecting this game to play out the tradition of survival horror (simple puzzles and running away from things). Having played it now, I can say the turn-based combat is actually really fun :-)

Naturally, you have the option to grind, but i found that simply fighting the enemies encountered in your quests gives you more than enough xp (to comfortably fight bosses). While combat is not the sole feature of the game it does makes up for the majority of gameplay. Having unique combat themes for different locations really helps to build the atmosphere and it also stop the game from feeling repetitive. The sound design is crisp, consistent and varied, which I appreciate (and i also appreciate not listening to something that makes my ears bleed jrpg fans if u know u know). Also, the bosses have unique personalities and the casual dialogue with them helps to break away from all the seriousness.

Visually, the game's art style is simple but at times really beautiful. I found myself admiring even the really simple things (like potted plants?!). Each area has its own terrain palette and theme, and the homes that house the npcs all have intricate details that give them subtle character. There are also some cut scenes that feature hand drawn animations, these are all beautifully illustrated by omocat and hold the game's melancholic undertone.

I used to follow omocat's Tumblr so I've actually been a fan of their work for a while now, and when I first heard about the game I was really excited for it. Some time has passed since but I'm really glad I decided to give this game a shot. I've only completed one of the endings so far but I look forward to replaying the game. I hope everyone enjoyed the game as much as I did! ˚ ༘♡ ⋆｡˚ ꕥ

First up, this game is a masterpiece and for the story alone, the Steam-version is perfectly fine.

The reason why I'm giving a negative review are the following:

1. The console versions which released over a year ago, had some extras for an alternative route in the game, which have not yet been patched into the steam version.

2. The xbox version, the only version with said extra content was pulled from the xbox store for some unknown reason. If you only have a PC, you cant play the extra stuff.
Again, if you only care for the story and not the gameplay, this doesnt really matter.

But 3. The xbox version was the only one, which had a perfect german translation, no other version, even for other consoles, are available in german.

It has been month and there has been no update what so ever (the microsoft support confirmed that it was pulled by the Developer and that they are working on it).

This lack of communication is, first and foremost, extremely frustrating, not understandable  and unprofessional.

Again, the game is a masterpiece, but play it on console if you can.

I spent around half of my first run teetering on the edge not knowing if I would categorize the game as simply good, or great. But then enough awesome happened to settle my choice and go for a 100% clear.

Something I could feel and that was proven during replaying was the lack of QOL for certain things. Especially not being able to skip some bits that can drag, and the game structure that is quite punishing for some achievements if you didn't plan for it.

What I really loved on the other hand, and that were still fun on the third/fourth time, were the bosses. It all meshes really well, the emotions mechanic merging with the character of the bosses, their banger theme, and their moves. It wasn't just battles, but experiencing them.

During most of the story, I had a small fear that I would be disappointed by the resolution somehow, but when reaching it I was conquered.

The gameplay might be simple, but the battles are fun in their way of using a sort of stance dynamic through emotions. It's deeper than expected, although making it tend on the easy side but I don't mind that at all.

The art style is also something I really enjoy, something with childish substance made with skill. This game is quite clever with a good amount of fun and integrated references.

The game was endearing and the combat worked well for me, it was worth experiencing.
All I have to say in the end is WHEN I FLEX, I FEEEEEEL MY BEEEEEEEST!

ok, genuinely this game is by far my favorite, its way of handling horror in such an unsettling way is immaculate, and how it shows headspace starting to crumble as soon as sunny goes outside and sees his friends again is incredible. I love how it shows how omori is trying to 'keep sunny safe' by leading the party off their quest to rescue basil by creating whole new areas when sunny overcomes his phobias. I absolutely love how at the end of the game basil has become erased from headspace and from everyone's memories and how kel goes to the length of kicking basils flower crown into the void in humphery because he didnt know it belonged to basil. The foreshadowing for this is awesome from the cut scenes where we see aubrey and kel attempt to draw basil but cant recall exactly how he looks, as well has the scenes in humphrey where we see their memory of him dissapear. I have not played any of the omori or neutral routes as of writing this, so i can't speak on them, but the ending for the true route is amazing and i love how omocat left how the group reacted to sunny telling them the truth about mari up to interpretation. i love all of the visual and sound design for this game as it made it very fun and exciting for me, not to mention how much i would dance around my room during battles because the music was so good (im looking at you, world's end valentine). this game is wonderful and i love it with all my heart. i am so so glad that i went into this game blind because it just made it so much more emotional and personal. i cannot say this enough but this is my absolute favorite game ever. 10/10

I went through some super challenging times in the years before playing this game. This game is a piece of art. Its characters are super well written and loveable. The visuals are cryptic, vibrant, and calming, and the soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal. OMORI is my favourite game of all time, I'm sure you will love it.

I love Omori. Its not hard to understand why either. It tells a shocking and gripping story that pushes you from area to area hoping to unravel its ends. It provides shockingly relatable accounts of trauma and the rifts it can cause around those affected. But more importantly is it has absolutely charming characters that are a delight to be with and watch grow around the events at the root of Sonny's seclusion and mental illness. 

This game haunted me about my own feelings while also not slinking into a sad story of a characters fall into mental illness and torment.There is hope for our cast, there are good times ahead. Sometimes it just takes work.

I played through Omori several months ago and I still think about it almost every single day. What a game.

Truly one of the best first person shooters of all time. The sniper rifles are way too overpowered in multiplayer though, especially the Dragunov. The operators have really cool abilities such as Kel's "Flex" ability. Oh, and Aubrey's melee ability is really fun to kill other players with. I love being able to one hit KO someone with a baseball bat in a first person shooter. Omori's "Red Hands" ability needs to be nerfed big time though. It just instantly kills the other team and is easily spammable.

Despite the balance issues though, this is a great online fps and I would recommend it to anyone else who loves this type of stuff.

I could not recommend this game more. 

The gameplay is simple, yet closely linked to the story and its themes. I think it is safe to say that its comparable to any turn based rpg (like Earthbound and Undertale)

The visual art when battling foes is quite stunning. It always looks like the main protagonist drew it with coloured pencils. 

The soundtrack is perfect and captures the situation it wants to paint to the player. I still listen to it in my day to day life. I plan to also buy it so I can keep it in my music collection. 

But most of all, the story is the strongest aspect of the game. For me, it achieved in trying to convey what the main character felt and it was highly emotional. Fear, despair, loneliness, grief and others. I was not a joy ride, but it was one that I am proud to have seen through the end...

EDIT:  Okay, now that I have sufficient time and distance from finishing the game for the first time, I can offer a more expanded opinion.

I left this game feeling hollowed out and as though I will never play it again. This is because I got what is widely considered the Good Ending, and it broke my heart. But don't mistake me: This game is a masterpiece.

What tons of modern media attempts (and fails) to convey, Omori manages. Through music, color application, and player choices, Omori so clearly expresses what it's like to lose oneself. Often it does this with bright pastels, wacky characters, and dreamworld logic. You find yourself thinking, "This is so cute! What is that?" Charmed by the absurdity, the painful parts are *more* painful. The terrifying parts? Anxiety-inducing. I left this game sympathizing with characters I never thought I'd sympathize with, for actions I still don't completely understand, even though the outcome of those actions was genuinely distressing for me, the player.

Omori wrestles with huge emotions, and it does it through a pixelated, nostalgic lens. I walked in without exposure to any of the spoilers, and I was completely unprepared for the way it crushed my heart in my chest.

This might sound hilarious and pathetic but this game literally sent me to get a therapy appointment... Lately (for a couple of years) I have been neglecting my life engaging in too much escapism doing stuff like playing video games all day (including OMORI) to ignore my mental issues after/while going through *heavy* grief but this beautiful ending [i](the good one!)[/i] made me realize that, even though it's not easy at all and it requires a lot of strength, it's better to try to face your traumas head on rather than pretending they don't exist and everything is fine. Well, it's not like I was stupid enough to not realize that before, but it's hard to get out of that loop and ask for help. Yet OMORI managed to slap me so hard that I thought "okay that's it I'm getting help I can't keep going at it like Sunny" because I saw too much of my own behavior in the main character's story/decisions/relationships [i](hell, a couple of times I also haven't gotten out of my house for several months 💀)[/i]and it did NOT look good from an outsider perspective! that was quite uncomfortable for me!! [spoiler]I, too, accidentally damaged my friendships because I had fallen too deep into my own sulking and isolated myself, without realizing that the extent of my self hatred ended up affecting my friends too and they didn't deserve that. But I guess it's not easy to be a good friend when your mind is too busy creating a parallel reality where time doesn't pass and also trying to convince you to end your life.[/spoiler] Hopefully this time with the help of my therapist, my life might get better :3

You'll be scratching your head for about the first third of the game wondering what the hell is going on - but you'll also have this strong urge to continue because you're actually curious about what the hell is happening. Not many games manage to pull off this fine balance. The combat isn't amazing, the graphics are clearly made on RPG maker, and the game has a couple of annoying bugs. Yet none of that really matters. This game will take you on a wild ride exploring yours and Omori's psyche. 

Be warned though that aspects of this game are incredibly dark and as such this game might not be for everyone. I wouldn't classify it as a horror but it's a hell of a psychological thriller.

PS: If you're having the game flicker while playing in full screen, disable Windows Full Screen Optimisation in the properties of the EXE file.

I just finished the game for the first time, and I can confidently say it has one of the greatest, most well crafted stories in any game I've ever played. Every other review on this game that describes it as an emotional roller coaster is absolutely right. Some moments I laughed out loud, some others I teared up and cried, and still others, I curled back in my chair in fear. The game does such a good job at making you FEEL things. And yes, the game handles some pretty difficult, heavy subjects, but it handles them almost perfectly. It was an amazing experience, and one that I think everyone who enjoys video games at all should try, as long as the heavy subject matter isn't too much for you. Highly recommend, new favourite game of all time!

If I could erase my memory of this game and play it over again, I would never stop playing.
10/10

So, there's a lot... In every sense.

I mean, the game is quite long and it feels like it shouldn't be that way. And there's a lot to keep in mind, which is kinda hard since the game switches between two worlds, with every turn taking enough time to forget what you did before you switched. And also, there's a lot of emotions to deal with, a whole spectrum of them, starting with happy (also sad and angry if yk what I mean) moments, finishing with uncertainty and confusion about some of the characters' stories.

All these points are kinda controversial, I know, and I totally wouldn't recommend this game for everyone. The thing I liked the most was digging through the stories of characters, their motifs (are there any motifs for something you didn't mean to do?), feelings , thoughts and I could keep this list going. This game gave me space for thinking, which is why I liked it. It just feels good to do some thinking from time to time, you know. Like, would I act the same way? Would I feel the same? Why did it happen like that? What could it mean? Stuff like that. I also enjoyed finding little secrets (it implies backtracking, which I enjoyed too, it had its little details), thinking through battle tactics and hoarding. Plus, I don't mind some grind, so there's that.

Art and soundtrack are judged subjectively, but I liked those a lot, it's simple yet it fits so perfectly. I'm into this kind of aesthetic, so yeah, that counts too.

And I know the line of thought in my review is scattered all over the place, so as my thoughts about this game. I started playing it 3 times, 2 of them I quickly lost interest, the 3rd time I'm finally close to finishing it. At least I think so. Would've I lost a lot, if I hadn't played it? I don't think so. Would I recommend it? Yes, somewhat as a piece of culture, if I may say so. It's something that you should play and think through for yourself. The story was quite controversial for me, I don't agree on some things, I don't believe some things, but it made me think a lot. Give it a try, maybe you'll like it.

This game is living proof that you don't need flashy graphics or complicated gameplay to make a masterpiece. Without giving away too much, it's the blend of a heartwarming and nostalgic plot on the surface, coupled with a dark portrayal of grief and depression beneath it all. Delving into the story alongside the main character, connecting the dots and filling in the blanks, makes for a beautiful execution of its plot, despite the heavy topics it covers.

In my opinion Omori is a work of art, and it will always hold a special place in my heart.

Get. The. Game. Now.

No amount of preparing will be enough to be ready to play this game. This game will unveil truths and thoughts about yourself that you might've never even known existed, and you can never forget. There is no turning back after you play this game. 

By this point, I've played a fair share of games dealing with mental illnesses/psychological horror, but I don't think any game is able to grasp it as well as Omori. It steadily and subtly introduces new horrors to the player, but most of the time, not in a way that feels forced or "jumpscare-y".

This is probably the best game I've played in the past 5 years. The art style is one of the most creative and recognizable art style's I've seen (I'm also a bit of biased in the form of pixel art, so I understand if not everyone likes that). In addition, I don't think most of the horror/emotional parts of this game would hit so hard if it wasn't for the music. The entire soundtrack has a mix of action/happy/nostalgic/depressing songs, with some songs in particular managing to achieve multiple emotions at once (something I find quite rare in music). The gameplay, for the most part, is pretty standard for a turn-based RPG. Furthermore, I never really found it too difficult (I never got a game over in my first run). That being said, Omori has it's own unique elements that make fighting enemies a lot more fun and creative.

The theme and writing of this game is unlike anything I've seen before, but I want to leave this mostly spoiler free (and trust me this is way better when you know little about it going into it), so I wont be diving deep into that. [spoiler] I've only completed a few neutral endings so far - my opinion on this game might change after seeing those, who knows - but as for now, [/spoiler] I give this a 9/10.

GREAT game, don't wait for a sale. Go in as blind as you can.

For me, the BEST strength of this game are its music and sound design. Everything you hear fits perfectly with the vibe the game is going for in the given moment. But the art and story are also FANTASTIC. On a second playthrough, I find the story in particular to be a lot more detailed than I first realized. A lot of thought went into how things are presented to you and why they are presented to you that way.

The RPG element is pretty unique too, though I found that aspect of the game got a little tedious halfway through my playtime. Luckily, you shouldn't really need to grind that much... unless you're playing to get all the Steam achievements.

Not a good game to play when you're not in a good headspace, they aren't exaggerating the content warnings. I wouldn't call anything in the game that "visually graphic", although it's a pretty mentally heavy game all around. 

Really, it's a lovely game that covers themes that include having relationships with friends and family, growing up, and facing the things you are afraid of. You'll finish the game with a strong desire to go hang out with your friends.
this game was fantastic! The characters, gameplay and story were some of the best I've seen. it hooked me on its dark themes and great humour 10/10 would recommend.

The gameplay is very simplistic and relies heavily on the plot, but the plot is just not enough to justify the length of the game. I was looking forward to the segments set in the real world and white space. But if that's what you're playing the game for, it just isn't worth playing the game. Very little time is spent in those segments, and they don't reveal much.  To enjoy the game you have to basically treat the story about the protagonist's trauma as an unimportant C-plot happening in the background.

You need to be thoroughly focused on what's happening in the otherworld, which is not much: You're searching for this character named Basil. You explore an area, sit through goofy Undertale-style comedy stalling antics, do some very easy RPG combat, and the characters say "welp, Basil's not here, let's go check the next area". That's the otherworld plot and you'll be spending 95% of the game doing that.

The otherworld plot tries to mimic Undertale, but the devs don't seem to understand what made Undertale work. Undertale antagonists have a personal reason why they're trying to stop the protagonist, and the touching moments involve the protagonist in some way. Omori antagonists are just random characters who show up to harass the protagonist for no reason in particular. I do some unimportant quest for a few hours, this character just suddenly attacks me, and then says "Yeah I have no idea where Basil is. Okay bye." Several grueling hours later I'm still looking for Basil, have gained no new information, and the antagonist maybe had a nice moment with their own friends that had nothing to do with the protagonist at all. This is just stalling the plot for nothing.

It isn't doing something subtextual, and while things in the otherworld are certainly modeled after the real world, they don't really symbolize anything. I.E., a place in the otherworld is named after a place in the real world, that's all. The otherworld segments are not saying anything deeper than that. The game has some interesting ideas with the emotion mechanics and follow-up attacks, but it's pretty basic, you don't have to be trying much at all.

As for the real-world story about the protagonist, it's more stalling. The prologue gives you almost nothing. After several grueling hours, the end of chapter 1 finally reveals some things about what's happening with the protagonist and his relationships to the other characters, but it features even more characters showing up to attack you for no reason and speaking but giving no info before leaving, just to pad the game time. While it does finally tell you something at that point, it's hard to even be invested in what's happening with Basil in the real world. The times you "save" him from the bullies... he was actually just harassing them in the park and they were yelling at him to leave them alone... then I guess to show that they're bad people, they attack you for no reason when you show up. And then after four more hours, the end of chapter 2 gives you literally nothing - it just repeats the same plot points it showed you after chapter 1. No new information has been introduced, and it totally skips whitespace in a cutscene. Four hours of gameplay and nothing about the plot has changed whatsoever. 

The game is basically just wasting your time for nothing. The old "stall the journey as long as possible to make the destination feel more impactful than it really is" trick. I definitely can't recommend it to anyone. If it has some compelling story or message to tell, well that's too bad the author chose to stall so much for such superficial reasons, because I won't be finishing it.

The game full of trauma and depression starting from the accidental murder of a loved one, and how your friends have changed for the worse.

Where does this game draw the line, though?

Profanity. Horrible, and disgusting profanity.

Its a pretty enjoyable and unique experience. I have some complaints, but the story and unique vibe of the game are impactful enough for me to let go of them in the great sheme of things. 

My main complaint is that some sections feel boring and drawn out. Sections with comparably little interesting in way of gameplay or lore happening. They dont happen that often but often enough to were you start to notice boredom set in, especially if you dont come from a RPG maker game background which frankly arent known for their amazing gameplay. 
The game does have an interesting combat mechanic it introduces called "emotions", but sadly it falls flat since most enemys, including bosses, are too easy to offer any sort of challenge and dont make good use of this. 
The lack of challenge helped add to the overall boredom that quickly began to set in during later stages. Especially since fighting random goons felt more like a chore than anything else and running away from those encouters became mandatory to eliviate their annoyance.
Side mission vary in enjoyabilty, plenty of them are fetch quests but plenty of them are not.
At the same time the side characters themselves are pretty cool and add to the the overall charming atmosphere "Headspace" has.

Still, the Artstyle/Music and Setting carry the game heavily. 
The pacing is a bit off and the main story only starts to hit off during the last third of the game, but the payoff felt worth it and the road to that point was an overall engrossing experience worth playing.

This game is pretty good, people kind of over-hype it, but I'd put it up there with Undertale though, it's a little long but I'd say it's worth it, just lower your expectations a bit... people make this out to be a masterpiece but it's nothing that crazy.

But seriously, stay away from the fan base, it's genuinely a fucking nightmare.

Oh wow, what an experience. The game's story is truly something else, I'm speechless. The narrative had a lot of twist and turns and fooled me multiple times. Although i recommend this game for its narrative, the game play loop gets really stale after a while, especially in the middle of the game. In the dream world, the story is all over the place and dialogue felt like it was written by a middle schooler, which might be what they were going for, but i just found myself dragging through story and characters i just didn't care about, like the shark guy and the pink princess. The real world segment was incredibly enjoyable though, and i found the contrast between the dream world and the real world really appealing. The story touches on some dark topics like depression, regret, fear and self hatred and the game managed to pull it together really well. Overall 9/10, the story is incredible, although the repetitive gameplay loop stops the game from being a 10/10 in my opinion.

I bought this game on a whim because a girl I had a crush on mentioned it in passing. Initially, I didn't think much - I'd blow through the first few hours, enough to start a conversation about it. What happened next fundamentally changed my life. OMORI is, without hyperbole, the single greatest, most ecstatically beautiful, unabashedly charming, heart-wrenching piece of art I have ever experience. The overwhelmingly positive score this game has does it a disservice - it is not good, it is not great. It is without flaw. Every pixel and every second of this game was an emotional and visual thrill. The scenes, the characters, the music, the story - all of these things have fundamentally altered every major aspect of my life. When I finished this game, I took a good ten minutes just to sob at my desk. In a time where people are finding themselves alone, uninspired, and existentially lost, this game shines through. OMORI is what the world needs. I know this 100 percent sounds like meatriding, and I get it. But play this game, and you'll understand.

Thank you to Omocat and everyone who worked and funded this project. You have made this world a better place.

I just want to thank the devs,

OMORI came into my life at the perfect moment, and I am beyond glad to have had this experience with my during such a rough point in my life. I saw this with all of the honesty in the world, this game has forever changed my life and I am better off for it. 

Sunny, Basil, Mari, Hero, Kel, and Aubrey will always have a place in my heart, 

thanks to everyone who made this piece of art possible, from OMOCAT, the developers, the kickstarters, and especially the community.

OMORI is, without a doubt, one of the most profoundly moving games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. Its music consistently strikes a chord deep within your soul, and its characters feel incredibly real. The storyline evoked emotions that left me staring at the screen for a while after finishing the game. Admittedly, I'm not the best at writing reviews, but I wholeheartedly recommend you experience this game for yourself. It's an unforgettable journey that's well worth your time.

I'll try and keep this review mostly spoiler free because I went into this completely blind and dont regret it at all.

Its an amazing experience in anyway that I look at it. The art and art direction is beautiful and will always keep up to match the game's themes, the soundtrack I could listen on loop, the characters are charming and the writing wanted me to interact with every little thing in the world.

Im a fan of RPGs and I never found the combat to be lacking, the emotions mechanic had me planning what skills the characters should use and it felt very rewarding.

Omori's art and combat are really great, but that wasnt what kept me coming back to the game. The story is phenomenal, which has probably been said by a thousand other players, but its true. It did feel confusing at time, but im 99% sure it was intentional. The story isnt exactly spelled out for you, so when it clicks it felt really good. 

To simply put it, this game is amazing and I love it.
4/5
fire game

i cannot stress how much i loved this game, and i will especially continue to adore it for years to come. 

OMORI has something for the casuals and the masochists. some achievements are incredibly grindy, time-consuming, or rng-based. however, a casual or non-completionist player can just avoid these, which i would definitely recommend at least on your first play-through. 

i would recommend OMORI to anyone in the right headspace, regardless of their background in video games. it is very user friendly and easy to pick up. there are challenges, too, if you wish to seek them out. much love, and thank you OMOCAT and all the wonderful folks that brought this project to fruition

I think Omori is one of the most important games in my life right now, i'm a antisocial person who easily daydreams to deal with stress in my life, when i saw that Omori was about dreams, i was really excited, like: "Wow, he's literally me!" And... Yeah, i am more similar to Sunny than i'd like to admit.

Depression is a very difficult topic to use in any type of media, people often create coping mechanisms to help with it, even when they are unhealthy. Omori reminded me that ignoring things won't make them go away, and running away from yourself will not only hurt you, but other important people in your life as well. Face the truth, let time do the healing and eventually... Everything will be okay.

Worth the money.
1) Story-focused RPG - less emphasis on combat and more on exploring the world and interacting with its characters, but still has a combat system that feels nice to use (in my opinion).
2) Godly soundtrack. Not every song will make you get up off your chair and start dancing, but they all have a place. If a song comes off as particularly grating or annoying to you, it's probably intentional.
3) Interesting and engaging story. Has a compelling narrative that still leaves the player room to fill in the blanks with their own imagination. Works well with the 'find-it-yourself' manner of uncovering the story in the first place.
4) Pleasant art style that is expertly manipulated to fit vastly different situations.
Be aware before purchasing the game for yourself or others that it contains references to and/or depictions of: self-harm, gore, suicide, mental illness, and embarassing childhood friends that you can't seem to get to leave you alone.
This is now one of my favorite games of all time. If what you've read sounds appealing, and you're alright with the game's content, I highly recommend it.

The creator is creepy and weird, so don't support them if you can help it. The game, on the other hand, is entirely lovely. Everything about OMORI is beautiful. It takes you through a tragic story from the view of a traumatized young boy, Sunny, who lost his older sister, Mari. Multiple endings, all different from each other.

Trigger warnings for depression, suicide, self-harm, hanging, disturbing imagery, animal abuse, flashing lights, etc. Lots of things to be wary of with OMORI.

If you haven't played the game, don't read this whole review. Please and thank you. But if you're looking for an opinion on the game itself, I recommend that you play it.
I haven't 100%'d it yet, but I'm gonna finally stop waiting to write this review. I already did everything there is to do on the console release and I certainly plan to 100% this version of the game as well.
This is one of the greatest games ever made. Genuinely, the only story in any video game to genuinely bring me to tears. It is absolutely beautiful and it's depictions of trauma and grief are absolutely incredible, as you get to see more than 1 side of both. You get to understand how all the characters grieve for their lost friend and you get to see the differences between how SUNNY and BASIL handled their traumatic experience. The only thing I can even slightly complain about is the gameplay, which is boring and repetitive once you've figured it out. I highly recommend installing mods to increase the difficulty/add more diversity in how you play the game.
100/10. Amazing game. If only another game could come even close to it. I'll miss this game forever.

i omor

I decided to write this coment now because it has been months, almost a Year since I finished this game and it is still running through my mind rent free.

Omori is a masterpiece no doubt and the story is just amazing, the way you get thrown in right away and be playing the game thinking everything is fine and you are just living your best life as Omori... 

Then after the first time you wake up in Sunnys bed I realised that thinking "everything is fine" is very wrong and now I was stuck on creating the wildest szenarios in my head...

The further I progressed I thought "wow... I am so excited to collect all the letters and finally find out about the true story but im quite sure i figured out like 80% of the story myself"

And then it hit me... this overwhelming Plottwist and all I could do was stare at my screen with my mouth wide open for hours not knowing how to process all of this Information.

Overall a Perfect Game!
