Omori is beautiful, genuinely a work of art. This game made me happy, sad and angry cry all the time and it was all worth it. The game handles topics like depression and anxiety perfectly with its art, OMOCAT and her team did wonderfully with the artwork for this game it’s cute, dark and beautiful throughout. The characters are gorgeous, the atmosphere of the game is cozy and cute but also haunting. Just a warning now for those interested but know nothing about this game, if you think this game is going to be a cute time all the way until the end, think again. This game is terrifying, scary and upsetting but it does it so artistically well it’s brilliant. Soundtrack is banging beyond belief I can’t stress that enough.

Omori is a beautiful work of art with almost zero flaws whatsoever. 10/10

OMG THIS GAME BROKE ME IN HALF, FILLED ME WITH HAPPINESS, AND BROKE ME AGAIN. I COULD RANT AND RANT AB HOW MUCH I LOVE THIS GAME BECAUSE ITS LITERALLY MY ONLY PERSONALITY SO IF ANYONES READING THIS THATS THINKING AB TRYING IT, 100% PLAY IT. 1) THE MUSIC. THE MUSIC IS AMAZING. LIKE IVE LISTENED TO MINECRAFT MUSIC AND NOT TO COMPARE IT TO THAT BEAUTIFUL OST, BUT THE OMORI OST WILL ALWAYS BE ON TOP. ITS SO SIMPLE YET ALWAYS SUITS THE THEME OF WHERE YOU ARE IN THE GAME I LOVE IT. 2) THE CHARACTERS. THE CHARACTERS ARE ALL SO DIFFERENT AND HAVE THEIR CUTE DIFFERENT QUIRKS AND HUMOR ITS GREAT. REALLY DOESNT FEEL LIKE YOUR JUST INTERACTING WITH BORING NPCS BECAUSE EACH CHARACTER (PART OF THE MAIN SQUAD: BASIL, OMORI, HERO, KEL, AUBREY, MARI) ARE SO UNIQUE AND FUN. PLUS THEIR DESIGNS ARE SO CUTE OMG 3) GAMEPLAY. GAMEPLAY IS VEREY VERY GOOD. I WONT LIE IT GETS PRETTY ROUGH WITH SOME OF THE BOSSES. IVE CONSTANTLY THREW MY KEYBOARD ACROSS THE ROOM WHEN FIGHTING [spoiler] SWEETHEART [/spoiler] BECAUSE SHE WOULDNT FUCKING DIE. FOR AN RPG GAME, IT DOES THE COLLECTING, LEVELING, CHOOSING MOVESETS, VERY VERY WELL. IF U SUCK AT RPGS JUST PLAY IT ANYWAYS BC ITS NOT THAT HARD. IT DOES TAKE A DECENT LEVEL OF GRINDING FOR THE MORE HARDER BOSSES BUT AS DOES ANY OTHER RPG GAME SO THATS OK. ALL IN ALL, I LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS GAME, ITS MY ONLY PERSONALITY, AND NO ONE FUCKIGN LIKES ME!!!

This game has literally been one of the highlights of my life. I remember when I first started I said to my friends "This game isn't really my style." This game has been my favourite game for nearly a year now and just when I start to think I know all about the lore, something new comes up. This game can literally make me cry at any given moment. If you think this game 'isn't your playstyle', play it anyways. Best game ever. (1000+ hours of gameplay later and my opinion has only improved.)

This game is a roller coaster of emotions I've had a very strong sense of joy in the battle, frustration to challenging bosses with amazing villains, fear in the scary moments, and tears me up in the sad moment.

Keep in mind when playing this game for the first time to avoid spoilers at all cost and
don't picture this as edgy Undertale, it's inspired by Earthbound which Undertale is inspired off of. Usually Earthbound-like games surround deep themes around young characters, mostly the only similarity to Undertale, but it is no way close to being Undertale but it's *this or that*.

very gud

I should preface by saying that I was seriously considering writing this review before I even finished the game, being how much it changed me. However, it made sense waiting until I had gone through everything to give my thoughts. If I could describe Omori, to new players, in one sentence it would be this: “Get ready.” I was aware that this game had many depressed after playing it, and that made me curious. Despite claiming that it hurt them, they still deeply recommended it. I agree with their logic. Omori gives a remarkable projection to the sorrows of life, from the lens of innocence and vulnerability. It’s not one that is easy, but it’s one that is sincere. This game had me both deeply terrified and sad, but all at the same time, more compelled to continue. Not many have this capability. So, despite whatever pain you might feel from playing this game, I still believe that you will have found the journey worth it.

My life will never quite be the same.

I tried this on a whim thinking it would be a great, probably small indie. There is no better game to me. I've never had this kind of emotional experience with any other game. I play horror games constantly - and so I could never have imagined that this would be the game that made me the most afraid. But it runs the gambit so amazingly - and as someone who has been depressed for years - it helped me make a a bit of a breakthrough. Mileage may vary on that one- but give it a chance

Do not look anything up, I cherish how the journey and my feelings unraveled so much. Save any optimizing for the second time around because you will want to play again. Play with your heart

A lovely RPG about getting over trauma
[h2]Rating: 5/5[/h2]
[h3]Music: 5/5[/h3]

[h3]Gameplay: 4/5[/h3]
- Fun & deep turn-based combat
- Exploration through an open world that is pretty much always rewarding
- Has surprises on how different systems can be recontextualized

[h3]Graphics: 5/5[/h3]
(idk how they could be any better)

[h3]Story: 6/5[/h3]
- Interesting & lovable characters
- [b]I have never felt emotions from any media as strong as I have felt from this game[/b]
- Funny
(Not really spoilers, but whatever)
- [spoiler]Multiple layers to everything that kinda like interweave and interact with each other in crazy ways that you don't expect yet make sense[/spoiler] 
- [spoiler]Multiple endings[/spoiler] 
- [spoiler]Ends up being also realistic to what its trying to portray[/spoiler] [spoiler](PTSD)[/spoiler] 
- Its just great

[h3]Length/Price[/h3]
- >30 hours of content for me (I did like 2/3 the side quests)
- I would think it would have been worth if it were 40 or even 50 bucks

[h3]Criticisms:[/h3]
- Occasionally it wants you to do a specific thing, but (very rarely and for really not that long) your not sure & you end up going in circles or doing backtracking
- Basic movement is a little bit boring, but doesn't matter most of the time and is only a problem because of above
- Saving only happens a certain locations, not when you close the game. There are plenty check points in most places, but can be a tinge of annoyance
- I am a person who has a real hard time understanding extended metaphors & this game has a lot of them & does a much better job than 90% of other things with them. However the last couple hours of the game get a little more 'abstract' (not a bad thing & necessary for what it is trying todo) and I was only able to partly (mostly) follow along. If your a normal person then you should have no issue
- This game sucked my life away and from the point I started to the point I finished, all I could think about was this game (I will probably continue to for a couple days into the future too)

That is literally all of my criticisms. Everything else is perfect. And each item is really small, they are only keeping the game from a 6/5.

All in all, 5/5 > 2/5 so I recommend it

This is a game about friendship and self-redemption. The theme is very serious but the way of presentation is cute, funny and intriguing. The story blends realism, romanticism, surrealism and sentimentalism in a perfect way. I firmly believe it reached the perfection of story oriented RPG.
As for gameplay side, the battle system is sort of original but still not very interesting to play. Given that OMORI was supposed to be a visual novel, it is tolerable to me. If it was released as a visual novel, its gameplay could be even worse.

I cannot recommend this game enough. I first played this with no prior knowledge except that the game was sad at times, and I would do anything to experience that again. The story is amazing, and is only further perfected by the emotional music and the incredible characters who you can easily get attached to. The game is $20, but it is absolutely worth every dollar. I highly recommend playing this game without looking anything up as to avoid spoilers because nothing beats that first playthrough where you don't know what's coming next. Though also do take the trigger warnings seriously as the game does get very heavy at times. Overall, if you enjoy psychological horror as well as incredible storytelling, Omori is the perfect game for you, and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

I was pretty skeptical going in, but this game did a great job keeping me engaged with it's story and characters, and making me truly feel immersed and caring about what was at stake. I have a very hard time staying consistently engaged with story driven games, but this game did it effortlessly for almost 30 hours. I don't know if there's ever been a game in which I was so invested in the mysteries that the game was setting up, and the ending did not disappoint in delivering with painting the full picture of what the story truly was. The ending itself was phenomenal and truly heart breaking. My only initial complaint is maybe that there were some moments in black space that felt a like it was trying a bit too hard to be dark, and in some instances made it feel kinda comical for me. But otherwise, this game rules.

Omori review part two although what I've wrote in part one I've came to appreciate the game much more especially the combat system

Omori takes a familiar RPG format and creates something entirely new out of it. The battle mechanics are engaging, the boss battles are exciting, and the music is fantastic. Just like with Toby Fox's Undertale, Omori feels like you bought an album that came with a game along with it as a bonus. On top of all that, the story is full of mystery and intrigue that only give you more questions the farther you get into it. This drip feed of vague information Omori constantly gives you, pushes the player forward until its ultimate climax. Out of all the games out there, this one is a cut above the rest. It deserves to be experienced and rewards those who complete it. To those of you who read this and decide to check it out, just remember to water Basil's plants. 10/10

Such a good game i had to write my own review for the first time! (a lengthy one for anyone interested in the opinion of strangers)

->P L O T
The player assumes the role of Omori, the alter ego of a teenager. The world is split in two sides: Faraway Town represents reality, while HeadSpace (as the name suggests) is an imaginary place, Omori's escape from reality. The story follows Omori and his friends on their journey to find someone missing, oscillating back to the teenager's reality and so forth. The main themes and motives include friendship, family, grief, redemption, anxiety, depression, suicide ( and many others ofc). 

As a depressed fellow myself, there were many aspects of the story I related to on a deeply personal level. Regardless, I find that the story can be appealing to just about anyone, as it is a wonderful mix between wholesome and disturbing( on a psychological level). OMORI combines joy and sorrow, tangling these two polar concepts successfully!

( TLDR: This game will heal your poor little heart and then stomp on it with no hesitation. Then heal it again and repeat the process. You will ugly cry for hours)

-> G A M E P L A Y
The lengthyyyyyyyyyyyy duration of the game is no worry as it keeps the player entertained with lots of fun and exciting mini side quests (optional) , as well as diverse foes (some cuter than others) to challenge using your own skills, weapons, charms and so on. Grinding is possible but definitely not necessary to advance. Difficulty is easy to medium, any foe can be defeated with a bit of planning and strategy, if none at all,  in this humble stranger's opinion. Even after finishing the game, I intend to play again knowing there are still loooooooooots of things to do and discover.

(TLDR: Very fun, will keep u constantly entertained. Friendly for noobs like myself)

->G R A P H I C S
Stunning. Fantastic. Amazing. Spectacular. Marvelous. Splendid. Excellent.
I was captivated by the charming 8 bit pixel style, as well as the hand drawn sketchbook visuals. Wonderful use of colors (or lack of when necessary). 

(TLDR: Pretty af)

-> M U S I C
The soundtrack of OMORI has become my favorite after finishing the game. It has everything from catchy playful tunes to heartbreaking sounds of piano and violin. I find it hard to describe music with words, but in terms of feelings the soundtracks adjusted to them accordingly. I have never felt so disturbed by ominous and eerie music before. It makes you feel....the sound of emptiness. Of course, heartwarming joy, happiness, or relief is also present when needed.

(TLDR: It's like a shawarma with everything. That everything being every emotion on the spectrum)

-> P R I C E 
Maybe not the most student friendly at first, but after playing, I can proudly say that i would use my entire life savings on this game if I could. Omocat, please take all my peasant money.

->C O N C L U S I O N S
Overall, this game was a 10/10 for me, I have nothing but praise for the work put into it. 
It is heavy mentally, so I advise being careful before playing. It triggered unpleasant memories in me, but even so, OMORI has a special place in my heart after such an impact. It was really wholesome and funny, bringing a smile to my face while playing. There is a high probability that the game will change your perspective in life. Thank you, OMORI, for showing such raw, pure, nostalgic and infantile emotions to me, taking me back to an uncensored past and back again in the reality where my life goes on, but grows from every memory I have created. 

And THANK YOU, kind reader, for reaching the end of my review. I wish I could re experience OMORI, but I hope you have/had as much of a special experience with this game as I did :) .

P.S. I strongly advise you to have a couple packs of tissues prepared before playing. Have fun dear <3

OMORI is a masterpiece of storytelling, art, and music. The characters are so lovable and relatable, the world is so colorful and imaginative, and the plot is so gripping and emotional. OMORI is not just a game, it's an experience that will stay with you long after you finish it. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves RPGs, psychological horror, or just good stories in general.

P.S. The battle mechanics may seem strange if you are new, but you will get used to it over time.

There's no kinda story I love more than redemption stories... As a matter of fact, they are a necessity to remind individuals such as myself to forgive ourselves, trust ourselves, love ourselves and simply remember that our mistakes, imperfections and scars don't define the rest of our lives and who we are. To be able to deliver such strong messages is no easy task, but Omori just nails it splendidly; Although this game starts its storytelling process with a bang and there's lots of tension, mystery and suspension there right from the beginning, Omori takes it time beautifully to build everything up and prepare you for one of the most gut-wrenching endings in video games history. The shift between the tones of the more lighthearted parts of the game and the bleak and scary parts is the magic of the storytelling of Omori. Yes, all the sweet details here and there and the metaphorical and environmental storytelling is great, but what makes Omori unforgettable is the hard hitting dose of protagonist's real life in contrast of all the cute moments in Omori's universe or all the funny interactions between the gang... It just gets you.
Not wanting to give away much about the story, let's move on to the gameplay! There's a lot to unpack here! There's this unique and interesting take on jrpg's turned based combat style in which offers you some new mechanics that are really fun to play around with. At the beginning of the game, the combat might seem a little confusing to the players who are not that familiar with turned based combat systems, but there's no need to worry cause the game does a great job at explaining the mechanics to the player. Just remember that if you want the combat to remains challenging. avoid grinding... Specially at Orange Oasis' Pyramid; You can just fly to the maximum level there. Aside from the combat there are many of puzzles and some mini games to keep things fresh and more fun, but not all of them are right there in front of you; Keep an eye open for these rewarding experiences.
AND what can I say about the gorgeous eye candy art-style and character design of Omori that hasn't been said thousands of times before? The visuals are one of the two most important selling points of this game. You just gotta see everything for yourself. 
Overall, Yeah, I totally recommend this game. It's truly one of the best gaming experiences I ever had. Looking forward to whatever Omocat is gonna do next!

one of if not my favorite game of all time. better than u are probably expecting. it's hard to describe fully why without ruining it, but one aspect i think it perhaps undersold is that the quirky RPG built on top of the psychological horror elements is an astounding benchmark it it's own right. the game manages to be constantly funny, charming, and inspiring despite it's deeply depressing and at times horrific undertones, and every setting, adventure, and interaction oozes the game's unique charm. even without the core of fear and horror, i would still very easily recommend this game 100% as a classic and also incredibly fresh Earthbound-esc RPG. whi;ethe RPG elements such as combat and leveling are pretty basic and not particularly ground breaking, they're perfectly fun enough and serve their role well throughout the game's story. combat was rarely ever a chore, grinding is never needed although helpful if you're struggling with the mechanics, visually they're a treat, and the boss battles were fun. enemy art and design goes a very long way.

however, that is not what this game is. it's also gonna make u feel afraid, deeply sad, upset, maybe even hatred. an incredibly important part of OMORI is that those experiences are inseparable and inescapable, but also not inherently at odds. the one critique i have is that at times the two aspects of the game sometimes do feel at odds with each other, as if you are switching between two different games. however, OMORI always is able to draw you back into the fact that it is both and make you feel happy, uneasy, afraid and brave all at once. if you're prepared for some fucked up stuff, and love quirky RPGs, it's a must play.

I don't know where to begin or how to end this, but I've been thinking about writing something for this game for a long time but just never came around to it. It's difficult to explain the wide range of emotions I experienced throughout my playthrough, because it made me think and reminisce about everything that has ever been in my life thus far. I consider myself a person that is never truthful about how he truly feels and someone who never shares their feelings and thoughts, I am someone who doesn't cry in front of others and never complains about how bad it is, and that's fine because that's just the way I had to grow up to survive.

I've never played a video game that has made me just sit back and [b] really [/b] think about everything that has led me up to this point in time. Many memories resurfaced again, it made me think about the childhood that I never had, friends that I could never get, things I never got to experience, about someone that was special to me, and about people that have long left the world. 

It all made me realize how truly miserable I feel, because I've always believed that I was numb to everything, but the reality is that I was feeling so much to the point where I've had to subconsciously numb myself to run away from it. I think the reason the game resonated so much with me is because I saw myself in Sunny, because we aren't really that different, we both locked ourselves away and shut out the whole world in order to protect ourselves and cope with the pain.

Throughout the game while playing as Sunny, I was trying to right his wrongs and guide him down a better path, because in a way it felt like I was trying to fix my younger self while also making sure that Sunny doesn't end up the way I did. I've felt constant anguish ever since finishing the game and even now while writing this wall of text I still feel the same. I cannot help but think about the past that could've been and wishing that things could've gone differently. 

People always talk about seeing the light at the end of the tunnel and how things get better, but my approach to life has always been to just try and be comfortable living in the dark, because it doesn't get better. But if there was a way to start life all over again then I would gladly take that chance, the things I would give just to be able to go back and have the things that I never got, like being a kid and have a chance at a normal life while being surrounded with love and having tons of friends to hangout with without having a single care in the world. 

But it's too late for that.

OMORI has a wonderful, beautiful story with lots of lovable, established characters, music that goes insanely hard, and a terrifying undertone. This game is not for the faint of heart. It has jumpscares, loud noises, disturbing imagery, and (more importantly) references to depression, anxiety and suicide. If any of these things are disturbing to you or make you feel uncomfortable, this game might not be for you.

This game has an incredibly captivating story that makes it hard to put down, but you probably already know that. What you might actually be looking at reviews for is the combat, which seems to be hit or miss with people.
It's pretty easy with only a few exceptions, so don't go out of your way to grind (I didn't go to Dino's Dig until the very end of the game). Skills unlock at a fair pace, and experimenting with new strategies is a lot of fun (mood wrecker, painful truth, and megaphone in particular).
Plot is great, play style is awesome (if you're into undertale and stuff, it's kind of similar) And it just gets better over time. Totally recommend!

[b] A white egret orchid. [/b]
[b] In the language of flowers, it symbolizes the phrase… [/b]
[b] "My thoughts will follow you into your dreams.” [/b]
[hr][/hr]
August 26, 2023, a night of indelible memories and a dawn that shall forever remain unexpunged from the corridors of my mind, accentuated by the mellifluous serenade of birdsong outside my window, juxtaposed against the ineffable tears tracing their paths down my visage. On this date, I completed [b] OMORI [/b] for the first time.

[b] This game, profoundly, embraced my soul. [/b]

I pen down these words while reflecting upon each nook and cranny of my soul that [b] OMORI [/b] has touched, gently yet unabashedly. The fingers that grace my keyboard now are the very ones that aspire to caress the melodies of "Duet" on the most delicate of pianos and violins. Even though my vision is blurred by tears that could form rivers, never before have I perceived with greater clarity the message this game aims to convey, in the most exquisite manner I have ever witnessed.

The beauty intrinsic to this game is a concept that eludes my capacity for expression, given the deeply personal and intricate impact it has evoked within me. The most intriguing fact is that, on a personal note, I've always been passionate about writing. However, [b] OMORI [/b] has proven to me that words often fall short in capturing such significant moments. In addition, an enduring passion of mine has perpetually been photography, owing to the profound ability it confers upon us to encapsulate moments within the unfathomable expanse of time. In the pulchritudinous universe of [b] OMORI, [/b] however, the art of photography beckoned me into a cycle of unbroken introspection before my mirror, compelling me to inquire into the very essence of my emotions and thoughts.

[b] OMORI [/b] prompted me to revisit a vital query pertaining to the continuity of our existence concerning what we can express, in its raw and unadulterated form, as human beings: 

[b] What constitutes art? [/b]

Art, that effervescent alchemy of the human spirit, stands as the purest manifestation of our pursuit of transcendence. It does not merely interlace pigments or sculpt forms; rather, it is the language of the soul, unveiling the concealed mysteries of our inner world.

In [b] OMORI, [/b] as exemplified by the duality between Headspace and Faraway Town, art in the form of expression confronts us with reality and dreams, often concurrently. It presents the hues of the heart and the nuances of our deepest aspirations. Every brushstroke, every note, every line traced is a glimpse of our being, an invitation to delve into the mosaic of human emotions.

Through this art, we embark upon realms that elude the grasp of time. The creations are not mere artifacts; rather, they are gateways ushering us into realms of contemplation and connection. The dance of colors on a canvas, the evocative melody of a song (The notes of [b] OMORI's [/b] soundtrack reside eternally in my heart as evidence of immortality), the silent narrative of a sculpture — all these are intimate dialogues, resonating with the echoes of our innermost thoughts.

In the most profoundly personal sense, [b] OMORI [/b] has been, is, and will continue to be a journey of self-discovery, an introspection that surpasses the superficial and delves into the depths. Art unveils layers of our psyche that often lie unexplored. It challenges us to confront our fears, our hopes, our emotional scars. And, in doing so, it aids us in embracing and comprehending our very [i] humanity. [/i]

[b] OMORI [/b] has taught me that art is the poetry of our existence, translating the nuances of life into forms that elude the limitations of language. It enables us to scream in silence, to smile with tears in our eyes, and to dance on the wings of imagination. In every stroke, there is a sigh; in every hue, an echo of the heart. It is the dance of life and soul intertwined, a testament that we are more than flesh and bone - we are the very essence of expression.

This game has not solely imparted to me insights into the resplendent concept of art through my personal interpretation and experience, but has also become a haven for an inquiry that arises as a contemplative quandary for all individuals who dare to cast a fleeting glance upon that which, in its profound essence, finds refuge within our souls: 

[b] What truly defines love? [/b]

The response pertaining to the aforementioned subject guides us towards an answer that intertwines with a question: 

Can [b] art [/b] truly encapsulate the essence of [b] love [/b] within its definition?

[b] Love [/b] embodies [i] forgiveness. [/i]
[b] Love [/b] embodies [i] hope. [/i]

If, by means of simple words, we are able to encapsulate the expansiveness of this concept, then in culmination, I write:

[b] OMORI [/b] is an art form.
[b] OMORI [/b] is a manifestation of love (hope).
[b] OMORI [/b] is the embodiment of the artistry of learning to love and forgive oneself.

This game is a fragment of my love.
If you, specifically you who knows that you are you, are reading this, I hope you always find the significance beyond the lexicality of "less than" to "hash".

If you, reader, have perused this review, which has functioned as an endeavor to articulate an array of ruminations and sentiments dwelling within my soul through the conduit of writing, until its ultimate culmination, my aspiration is that it has stirred a resonance within you.

If you find yourself adequately poised for this, play [b] OMORI. [/b]
[b] P.S. [/b] However, I want it to be clear that this game is [b] not [/b] for everyone; it is exceptionally unique in how it addresses sensitive subjects.

In the event that your decision leads you to embark upon this experience:
I sincerely hope you uncover the depth of conceptualizing your own unique [i] humanity [/i] throughout this game, one that has reached the depths of my soul in a manner beyond adequate articulation, I aspire for it to similarly resonate with your own being.

The technical lexicon of a meticulous analysis of this game can never truly equate to its abstraction. 
Words would never suffice, regardless of the allowed character limit.

No game has been, is or ever will be like [b] OMORI. [/b]

Remember, we do not transcend our fears by obliterating them, but by embracing them in coexistence. We must acquire the art of self-forgiveness and extend that forgiveness to the world that surrounds us.

This is the story I am not going to tell anyone, but a few anonymous people on the Steam webpage. The writing I did has only one goal: to make a conclusion of my own thoughts and emotions that came up in my mind throughout playing this game.

I came to Omori as a normal, mentally stable fellow, without that many sad and depressing thoughts before playing. I consider myself a person who will never complain to somebody about my emotions and thoughts. I'll never cry to anyone and will never say how bad I'm feeling; that's okay for me. I never had depression and expected nothing from this game. A month ago, I decided to finally quit video games because of the intensive studies that are going to begin this September. I'll have to move to a completely new country for me, alone. I will work hard, and there is no way I could spend my free time in front of a computer. I considered Omori as my last single-player video game of my teenage years and for the foreseeable future.

My first play was at night. Being completely alone helped me understand this game correctly. My first session lasted for six non-stop hours, and I've never felt what I felt during this play. There is no other video game that is able to make you feel that blank post-gaming syndrome constantly, like Omori did. I felt it from the beginning until the end, whether I was in front of a computer or not. I'm still wondering if this "hollow" feeling will ever fully leave me. When I decided that this is enough for today, I went to the bathroom and spent almost an hour there, thinking. The main subject was my childhood.

The thoughts of my childhood became a sad ghost that follows me every night and day. I think about it every time I have to solve some task about my university admission or studies, every time I walk through a place that was special only for you and a few people you knew back then. Do they still remember it as I do? Do they still cherish it as I do? Will they ever come back here with a desperate hope of seeing some of us or just to see it again?

That night, I felt completely miserable. There is no way to get back there. There is no way I could ever talk to all my good old friends again, no way we could gather again and do the things that kids like us usually did. Some part of them is lost in a big city with their own troubles. I'm sure that they have forgotten how great it was together. Some have left the country forever, and some are even dead. Money wasn't a concern in my childhood. There was no war, and I wasn't afraid that I'd never see my parents again due to a Russian rocket attack. When I was 12, my only worry was spending another summer with my friends, with a stash of snacks prohibited by my mother, and that limited version of Coca-Cola that is no longer produced. I never thought about all of this before playing OMORI. I never missed my childhood times and never dreamed about those times. Omori's headspace is a mirror of our infantile times we all had and miss.

This masterpiece is not about gameplay, graphics, or storyline. There is no way you can rate it separately from your own mind and the changes that occur in it during the play. This game is about nostalgic, infantile, pure emotions that emerge from the hidden part of your soul and will never leave you until your death.

There is a theory of the "last dream," which means that when you die, your brain will produce a last, long dream—some even call it heaven. I am sure that this "heaven" will be some kind of headspace, but with your own friends, games, and troubles. I hope that I'll be able to feel these emotions of a little kid who just minds his own business, playing games with friends and dreaming again. Wait for me, my friends. I'll play with you once again, someday. Even if I have to die for this, it'll be a worthy reward. 10/10, the best game I've ever played.

After finishing the game on normal route blindly, i wanna say the experience is quite ok. Not really that great as i expected as the hype/trend years ago. Well im guessing the game is popular in Japan due to the mods, idk if it was that hyped outside of Japan. The game are not really that scary, just creepy vibes and some usual disturbing stuff. Idk maybe for me it is just not that creepy as i thought it would actually be lol. 

[h1]Short review of my experience playing the game (very minor spoiler dw)[/h1]
I would say the game horror aspect was on point at the early and the late part of the game, but in the middle ([spoiler]i think around capt spaceboy until humphrey[/spoiler]) i really forgot about the horror aspect of the game since most of it just focused on battle lol. 

Other than that i think the game by itself is pretty good in terms of quality. The story plot is fine, the game does make me wanted to know the story more the more i played. At least it is not some mid half ass made storyline lmao. The game has two separate route so the story wont be too linear and it took around less than 20hrs to finish one gameplay til the end.  The game soundtracks is good (sweetheart battle soundtrack the best imo), I really care about soundtracks for games like this and they pretty much nailed almost everything. The scenery and atmosphere of the game is good.

For in game mechanics, it just works the way rpg game works. There are battles in the game, some boss fights need some strategy and equipment but at least u can get by with just enough snacks and skills. The level is there but u might not need to level them up that much by farming small monsters. Speaking of small monsters if u dont want to waste time fighting them like i do, run is definitely what u would do though some needs few turn to run from them which at times can be quite annoying lol.

[h1]Conclusion?[/h1]
The game is good but to me not so much in the horror aspect maybe bcs i have experience much worse rpg horror game like corpse party or ao oni lol. It is recommended to go blindly for proper experience of the game. I just hope there is an in game feature that let me navigate myself through the whole 4 days easily for the purpose of completing the achievement but i dont think i would see the game updated just for that anytime soon lol. Nonetheless, this game overall is good for casuals and the game is quite worth the price especially during sales. I recommend this if ur a casual gamer looking out for rpg horror game for the first time.

Personal Notes: If you have never heard of/played Omori you are seriously living under a rock. Omori is probably the best Story game ive ever played and ever will play, dont let the pixel jrpg let you off on this game, it makes it better in my opinion. Omori's story and atmosphere blew me away, I was never bored exploring the dreamspace area of the game. The music in Omori is another part that just makes this game a masterpiece, over 179 Ost's for it and i dont dislike a single one.
Omocat and her team really did do an amazing job creating this psychological horror jrpg. Omoris modding community bringing the rating factor up so much as well, its a very active community and some of the mods ive played are really well built and have a lot of effort put into them. The characters of Omori are some of the most well written characters in gaming , without spoiling too much each character has there own problems which u learn throughout the game and is truely depressing once youve completed the game. I love every ending in Omori (I think there is 5) some are good and some are bad BUT you should experience those for yourself. 10/10 The definition of a Masterpiece, try this game out now. Thank you Omocat

What I thought would be a tacky "PSA" for mental health, ended-up giving me one of the most profound experiences I've ever had with a video game.

I seldom see a piece of media present themes like depression in a way that isn't 'in your face' with it's messaging, but OMORI manages it with flying colours. OMORI doesn't tell how the protagonist feels, it puts you in his shoes and makes you feel for him.

I know that many people are put off by long, story heavy games, but I say that OMORI is a great starting point if you are one of those and is looking to try something new. It's hours long, and finishing can be a considerable undertaking for people with bigger priorities in life, but I assure you it'll be time well spent. The story touched me deeply, and while I won't be giving any spoilers here, I'll say that it pulls the carpet from under your feet in the later part of the game with a big revelation.

For me the price of the game was money very well spent, and I cannot recommend it enough.

this game is agonizingly boring. Will update my review if it gets better.

*UPDATE*
This game has a great story and the way it unfolds in bits and pieces was pretty cool but I rather would have watched youtube play through of this than actually played it myself because the gameplay was incredibly boring and so drawn out. I do want to check out the other endings if there are any but I can't sit through 20 hours of this pile of shit gameplay. 

The quality of life aspect in this game is HORRIBLE.Theres so many unnessary fights you are thrown into where you are sitting there rinse and repeating the same combat moves over and over and over again and then having to see the same 10 second victory animation. The horrible and annoying repetitive background soundtrack was making my head hurt too when im trying to read the text.

Overall I think a large portion of the games positive reviews is because the ending of the game and its story resonated with alot of people because it does touch on the topic of depression, guilt and how it stays with you as you grow up but you have to swim through an incredibly long and drawn out game with unnecessary combat and missions to really enjoy the effects of it. Seriously if this was a short game like doki doki the impact would have been alot better but 20 plus hours to just reach a conclusion that you somewhat know mid way through the game is ridiculous.

I have no actual words to explain what I've felt during this game. Friendship, sorrow, mental illness, horror, happiness, losing hope and more. Omori is one and only kind of experience in my words. Sometimes it made me feel like shit, sometimes like a hero. The sad and tragic story behind this game is not given you at the beginning, although it is shown a bit different than what it actually is, you'll get absolutely shocked by the plot twist at the end. 
I wouldn't say Omori has the best mechanics but I would tell you that it's unique. Once you understand the emotion chart everything becomes much much easier as the game wants you to use it.
I actually do not want to say a lot about this game because you as the reader, should have absolutely zero hesitation giving this game a chance and it would make me happy if you learn about it by playing it yourself.

Do yourself a favour and buy this game immediately play it.

Special thanks to stelegarto for showing me this game and changing my life forever.

As the game comes, its very inaccessible for visually impaired people. The default resolution options are awful, either forcing you to look at a tiny window and strain your eyes or make all of the beautiful visuals extremely blurry and low res and ruining your experience. I could not reliably control my character because of how small everything was and how I was unable to see anything clearly. 

I'm also not impressed with the start of the game, I have only played for about an hour and I found the game's writing very uninteresting when the horror wasn't at the focus of the scene. I can only assume that it's a slow start and it'll get better as you go. But with that and in combination of being unable to see much of anything without harming my vision, I'm probably going to refund this if I can't find a workaround for the graphics.

Edit: Finished it after getting a better computer and some hardware related accessibility fixes, cried. The game has pacing problems, and drags horribly for about 7/8th of the game but then when that ending hits, it hits hard. It's worth staying around for, and all of these accessibility issues are very prevalent still, but it's a solid 7/10 purely because of the ending payoff.

this game means a lot to me and I recommend you stop reading reviews and just play the game. It can express how good it is much better than I can. 

but if you wish to listen, here is my two cents:
omori is especially great at making you feel the way it wants to make you feel. it makes you anxious when it wants you to be anxious so that you can feel comforted when you finally return to a cold white void. it makes you attached to your 'friends' so that anytime you are alone feels twice as much so. it makes mari and her picnic the safest place to be so it can make the whole world feel cruel when she is gone. it makes your mind white and empty so you hate it when the skies turn black and that void is now filled with things. things you dont know what it is but things you want gone. things you want to forget
yet you must realize that there is no point living like this to progress. Life itself is a rebellion against entropy itself. and happiness can only be achieved by moving forward no matter if it feels uncomfortable or even painful. it is always important to go at your own pace. slowing down or speeding up when you think you should but deciding you want to stop at this moment and relive it over and over will lead to no happiness

but there is something I neclected to mention
sunny never overcomes what he is going through alone. if he had never answered the door when kel tried to help him he would not have ever gone outside of his house on his own. And that is true for all of us. There exists no such human that can live alone. and yet you must open the door to let kel in. You must make your problems known so that ones ready to help you even at their expense can help you. And you must trust there will be people that want to help you no matter how much you believe otherwise.
There may even be someone trying to help you right now. Not someone else but you. They may be saying that you should face your flaws. agnowladge that it exists yet you may not listen for a never ending list of reasons such as: it seems a lot of work, it feels hard just to clean your room or take a shower, you feel like everyone would hate you if they knew how you really are or they hate you even now, you may think it would be better if you just died.
but those reasons are just arent there in reality. they are just reasons you made up because you cant trust yourself, you cant trust yourself when you tell yourself that there are people that love you and that you can become better. 

you must trust yourself you can be better so you can get help so you can be better. You are the person that can help you the most but a friend just there to listen to you ramble about your problems and how you are goes a very long way.

Note: I re-edited this a lot after finishing Omori. (This game is a masterpiece and I would totally recommend it!)

I heard of the game Omori a few years after its release, thinking it was just a classic, funny, inspirational mix of other games like Undertale or Earthbound until I actually played it, and that's when I slowly became very emotional but in a good way. I bought this game around Christmas and despite running into a few spoilers, I still gave the game a shot because of its wonderful art style and story-telling and I also admire how they go in depth with each character and their lives. This game kept me switching between depressed and excited (and now I'm a bit more careful about stairs.)

(SPOILERS BELOW)

What really got me emotional was the library in Headspace. During the playthrough, I couldn't figure out what the boxes [_] were for a while, but now that i know it hits even harder. More importantly, Omori portrays many responses to loss and guilt very accurately, with elements like "Something" and other wacky characters. I'm glad Kel (the best character) had enough dedication to knock on Sunny's door for probably days? And thankfully, the story eventually led to reuniting the group again. The ending for defeating his phobias and Sunny using the final duet was so beautiful that I almost cried watching the whole thing, it was precious seeing someone defeat the literal form of trauma. 

Overall, this game made me feel conflicted for days but thanks to the ending, I feel complete and I'm happy Sunny got his good ending (at least with the ending I chose. Now i have the word "close" in my head everytime anyone falls, so yeah...) I'm so glad i played this game :)

[b] At the very beginning of this passage, I will show my conclusion to this passage: [/b]
                                                      [h1] THIS GAME IS TOTALLY A MASTERPIECE! [/h1]
                                                           [h1] And you really have to give it a try![/h1]
OK, let's start with the plot! ([b]Warning! There will be spoilers below, think twice before you read my passage <3[/b])

    Omori tells a story about a boy named “[b]Sunny[/b]”.
    Sunny was born into a harmonious family, and he has a gentle and considerate sister “[b]Mari[/b]”. Mari is a perfectionist and she's good at playing piano, also, Mari has a boyfriend “[b]Hero[/b]”, they were almost a match made in heaven.
    It seemed like Sunny would live a happy life like most of our people, however, the fact was not like this...
    On one of his birthdays, Sunny received a violin that his friends and Mari gave him together, with this violin, he could play with Mari. Under practice day by day, Sunny could finally play with Mari on the same stage.
    However, on the morning of the performance day, everything changed: Sunny accidentally broke the violin, and because of this, he had an argument with his sister Mari. Didn't know if it was out of anger or accident, Sunny pushed Mari down the stair, [spoiler]and because of the damage of falling...
    Mari died, by falling.
[/spoiler]
    All these scenes were fully captured by Sunny's best friend [b]Basil[/b] who just came to Sunny's house.
    [spoiler]Under intense fear, Basil and Sunny chose to cover the truth: they carried Mari into the forest outside the house and hung her on a branch with a jump rope, creating a scene of Mari committing suicide.[/spoiler]
    After this thing, Basil became depressed, and Sunny became autistic, never going outside his home.
    After all things happened, Sunny's family decided to move. During the days Sunny still stayed at home, he started dreaming. In his dream, everything seems beautiful, the dream world is another world that contains every happy and positive thing Sunny experienced in his childhood: the Space Husband, the Sweetheart, and her castle, and so on. The Sunny in the Dream has another name “[b]Omori[/b]”(as you can see, it's the game's name).
    And that's where the player's games start.
    During the gameplay, you have to act as Omori and explore the dream world with your friends in it. In the morning, the dream will temporarily come to an end, and you're going to act as Sunny to explore the real world. When the time comes to night, you will enter the dream again.
    When you enter the dream, A silent land below a dreamy purple sky will come into your sight, the first time I came to this scene, I had a strong feeling of peace and loneliness, everything seemed to convey a hint of beauty and serenity, and it almost made me think this is a wholesome game before I got the news of Mari's death.
    Although this is a psychological horror game, most of the time I spent in the game was about Sunny's dream, which entertained me a lot and made me linger on with no intent to leave the dream world. I bet this game's scene shaping is impressive, the first time you enter the dream, you will feel happy and peaceful, but gradually, you will get an intense feeling of loneliness, this is what everyone will get during his playthrough. The dream world is sometimes absurd, almost every scene is dominated by dreamy purple-pink and light blue tones, it well shapes a world of dreams, the space, the Sweetheart's castle, the world under the sea, and Humphrey's body, they both create an absurd world belongs to Omori.
    What is quite praiseworthy is the background music, they both have a dreamcore style, which can make you immersed in this game. (By the way, my favorite music in this game is “By your side”, this is the music when you enter the plot related to Mari)
    The reality world is kinda heartbreaking, you will soon learn that Mari is dead, the game seems to have reached a turning point at this moment, and from this time, you have to search for the truth [spoiler] about why Mari died. (Well, at this time you don't even know the cause of Mari's death)[/spoiler] 
    The last day in the real world is really with one climax following another, on that day, all the truth will come to light, and the game will also come to an end. 
    When I finished playing this game and watched the final duet, I suddenly found I have no strength to utter a syllable, my heart was fulfilled with complex feelings, happiness, sadness, emptiness...
    Omori disappeared, the dream disappeared, and I'm empty inside. I don't know why I had this feeling of emptiness, the game had already had the best ending, Sunny defeated his demon! Gradually, I came to know why I felt sad and empty, I was totally inside this game, I HAD BECOME SUNNY HIMSELF, I started escaping from reality, I felt scared every night I woke up in my home, and I always couldn't wait to enter my dream only because in my dream, my friends always went on well with me and I could have a perfect wonder world. And so, that's why I felt lost when Sunny stepped out of his dream.
    But soon, I found that there was no need to be upset, I have to face reality, and I also have to face my life, Sunny did so, why didn't I?
    Although Sunny's story seems far away from our life we are all Sunnys, we always make mistakes, and we are always afraid of facing mistakes, and we also want a world in which are no mistakes, no pains, and no sadness, just like Sunny's dream, so it's normal for us to try to escape from reality.
    I think Sunny's story doesn't only tell Sunny to face reality, it also tells us to do so.
    I don't think that I will ever play a game that has touched me deeply as this one, I've played games that have made me cry, I've played games that have made me feel pain, and I've played games that have sometimes made me depressed, but I don't think I have ever played a game that's made me think and feel like this before or more it was just a journey, I don't think I will ever be able to forget this game.
    I don't know what to say anymore... I'm glad I did play this game, honestly even if no one liked this game, it doesn't matter, this was the game I needed to play and this was the game I need to experience and enjoyed the journey, and I enjoy everything about it.
    I haven't felt these emotions for a long time, what makes me feel over everything: keep your friends close man, and cherish them as much as you can, you never know when they'll be gone, besides your family your friends are the most important people in your life, and if you do right by them, they'll do right by you.

But seriously this game has beautiful writing and is painfully realistic for those experiencing mental health issues. Each character has their own struggles and is painted as one of the five stages of grief, allowing people to relate to them even more. I was left sobbing and blankly staring at my computer screen for ages after the true ending, I can't even begin to describe the emotions I felt when I heard the final duet. The music in this game expresses emotions so perfectly to the point where if I even hear the first note of that damn piano I think I'll burst into the tears again.

The psychological horror aspect of it might make people think it's unrealistic but it's really not. Hallucinations are real. Nightmares are real. Escaping to a different reality is so common in those experiencing grief. I love this game because someone out there could actually BE Sunny, or Hero, or Aubrey, or Kel or even Basil.

I also just wanted to say that the foreshadowing of what's to come is perfect, it can be so subtle sometimes that you just walk right past it in your first play-through but when you replay it, it's like your stomach drops when you realise. Two of my favourite one's are the sign in orange oasis saying 'You did it!' with a jump rope next to it, and another is the dialogue of the religious statue - 'It feels as if it is judging you.' You pass it off as a gag/joke that it's staring at Sunny weirdly, to later on realising it can have a double meaning.

This game is easily one of my favourites, thank you, I didn't know this before but I honestly really needed to play it.

(This review is extremely negative! OMORI is still my 2nd favorite game of all time. This is some very tough love!) To start, I still recommend this game, but it is not for everyone.

To put it bluntly, this game is long. Super long. The average playtime to finish this game is 20 hours, and most of that time is not spent progressing the plot. It’s spent doing endless fetch quests, roaming around, fighting hordes of enemies, and reading so much dialogue that it can put some people to sleep.	 

HEAD SPACE: While I could write about every single part of the game, and critique how it could’ve been better, the entire rest of head space is essentially the same thing and so boring it can be summarized in a few paragraphs. Basically, you spend about 90% of your playtime in head space where the plot does not move forward. You just do a bunch of boring, pointless side quests that take forever. 
You do puzzles that are painfully easy. You fight billions of the same enemy, and most of the time turn your brain off and just spam the attack button, and this isn’t even scratching the surface on how boring head space is. It got to the point that it took me a month and 13 days to finish this game because I kept taking breaks after enduring this slog fest. 
This whole thing combined leads to a repetitive cycle where you trudge through headspace hoping to reach the point where the plot progresses and you enter the real world, which usually only occurs at the end of each segment of head space. So you get a quick spooky event about the “truth,” then get sent to the real world.

THE REAL WORLD: The real world consists of a few fetch quests and missions, and has some of the main problems from before. The best thing though is that it actually moves the central plot forward, and isn’t entirely pointless in the grand scheme of things. However the main problem with the real world is that there are so many moments of character development that should be mandatory, such as the description KEL gives about HERO’s depression when you interact with the Gravestone. I didn’t even know about this in my playthrough, and it's a pretty big plot point that should be expressed.

I’d also like to elaborate on the combat for a moment. The combat system with emotions is unique, but rarely utilized. Even if you wanted to use it for yourself you have 4 party members whose emotions need to be turned. That means 4 turns of using “Cheer,” or “Sad Poem,” or “Annoy,” (Plus an extra turn if the enemy’s emotion needs to be changed) In these 4 turns, you could deal so much damage, or be dealt so much damage that it becomes entirely pointless. (And yes, I am aware of the items that make your entire party or foes a specific emotion, but those are later in the game and are classified as items, so they are meant to be single use and “powerful.”)

Finally, the main part of the game that even kept me playing: The story and writing. To start, the game is very cheesy when it comes to its characters. I thought that this would be isolated to head space alone, but no, it carries over to the real world. Since the writing style stays the same, and none of the teenagers speak like teenagers (They rarely curse at all. This game talks about suicide, so the game can handle curse words. Curse words are usually the best way to separate fantasy from reality because yes, people do curse in stressful situations and it helps emphasize the importance of the situation), the game ends up being pretty unrealistic and feels like you're reading a manga, not seeing an actual friend group going through a hard time.
A good example of this is AUBREY. In about 3 days, after seeing SUNNY fully basically for the first time since MARI’s death, and going through various mental breakdowns, AUBREY goes through the classic Family Guy “Aw geez, I’ve been a real jerk,” then makes up with the entire party of friends. So you're telling me a person who held a grudge against their prior beloved friend group for years, to the point of which doing physical harm to them would just lose that grudge in days? Yeah, okay.

This game also terribly conveys depression. Suicide is a game mechanic, for some fucking reason, which is so insensitive and strange. The bad ending of the game also is just SUNNY killing himself with a (banger) song playing, which is just edgy and unnecessary. These moments seem to be just there for shock value, nothing more.
The game wants to convey that SUNNY has depression, but instead shows that SUNNY is scared of spiders, heights, and swimming, and does not want to go outside. So basically SUNNY just has a bunch of phobias, and is extremely fucking guilty because of the twist (more on that in a moment). 
SUNNY is also never smiling, ever. Which is strange, because most stories about suicide (with personal experience here, too) are shocking to surrounding friends and family because the person who committed suicide never seemed to express being depressed, or them in a state where they’d want to commit suicide
But OMOCAT has a very 1 dimensional view of depression. The game portrays people who are depressed as “Depressed people are sad. They never smile. They commit suicide,” when it is far more complex than that.

Now, coming to possibly the worst part of this game, the twist ending. We learn that SUNNY and BASIL killed MARI by pushing her down the stairs, then framing it as a suicide. So everything prior, SUNNY and BASIL’s “depression,” it's not depression. It's guilt. MARI was never suicidal, she was killed. Which essentially means that what could’ve been an interesting take on depression (as MARI was always so happy and vibrant) is destroyed by the fact that she never committed suicide and that it was framed. So all portrayals of depression in this game are fucking stupid and do not compare at all to the real world.

Also, the twist makes no fucking sense. So MARI gets pushed by SUNNY down the stairs. Then she falls on a fragmented violin. If she wasn’t bleeding before, she is now. Then, SUNNY drags her bloodied corpse back up the stairs, and lays her in her bed. So now there is blood everywhere across the house. Then, SUNNY and BASIL take her body (which is still dripping blood everywhere) to a tree, hoist up her 15 year old body with 12 year old noodle limbs, and then proceed to tie a noose around her head (which is harder than it looks.) 

Then the police had to either:
A: Be extremely stupid and not notice the violin shards in the body.
B: Not to be called, and the murder scene covered up by the parents. Also, we have to assume that SUNNY’s mother did this on her own, because the father presumably left SUNNY because of this incident. Leaving your entire family is a big thing, and it would make no sense for the father to cover up the murder and then leave. He would most likely keep the murder to himself, but leave in disgust.

Then the game portrays SUNNY and BASIL as sympathetic and innocent. Are you fucking kidding me? The plan to cover it up as a suicide is ridiculous enough for 12 year old “innocent boys,” but even if they did come up with this plan, the adrenaline rush to cover it up would’ve been long gone after SUNNY put MARI back in her bed.
This would be actually very interesting if the story was more of a “who-dun-it,” and we were watching psychopaths coming up with their plan, but instead we’re supposed to be watching innocent boys who made a mistake and are supposed to be forgiven and tell the truth. Yeah right.

The thing is, there was even no need for this twist ending. I understand how subjective it may be, and you can fight tooth and nail claiming that “The ending is believable, it's about being honest with yourself, etc.” But if the game really wanted to dive into depression, it could’ve instead explored the very real situation of a person who appears to be happy and vibrant committing suicide. Instead we have a twist ending more because of “shock” than because of telling a good emotional story.

I don't play many RPG games unless it has something I really love. With Omori, it was completely different.
Battle: A simple RPG type with a fun little rock paper scissors gimmick to the battling
The Music: Holy shit, The Music, It's so fucking good especially the boss music, especially Sweetheart, really love the mix of violins (correct me if I'm wrong) and Pianos. Never thought that would go hard in a RPG like this
Characters: are really good, Hero is especially my favorite out of the 4 party members Sweetheart is also a pretty comedic character throughout the story I like
Story: It got me bored at first until SOMETHING got into the story and when they started to show the real world of the game, really shows you get to know some characters and how it reflects in the dream world
Last But not least
Art:The Worlds are fucking beautiful , Especially the final world with all it's color 
And even the cutscene art is more amazing
Overall 
9/10

[h1][i]The following section may contain minor and/or major gameplay and/or story spoilers! Please read at your own risk![/i][/h1]

[h1][b][u]REVIEW:[/u][/b][/h1]
Waiting for something to happen?

A fair amount of people enjoy cats, and they always want to pet them in the game; I do too! The thing is, you can't pet the cat in this game, but you can pet a shadow dog! ......You can't pet the cat like I said... BUT.... you [b]CAN[/b] kill your cat! Dissecting it, actually! Yep. This game is nuts.

I'm not even too sure how I found this game, honestly. I do, however, know that it caught my eye when I saw the tags included turn-based JRPG, mixed with psychological horror. Now that's my type of jam! I was all in for this. The result? It scared the hell out of me and left me feeling lots of sadness, albeit some happiness at others.

Even though I haven't replayed this game, I know I'll be returning to it in a year or two. Seeing all the different endings is something that I really want to do! On my first playthrough, I got the good ending. I've searched to see if there will be some sort of “OMORI 2”, but everyone doesn't think it's likely.

Well darn. Hopefully in the future, there will be some sort of spinoff or new characters and story with the same base concepts. This is a must play game, even if you don't like turn-based games. The story is impressive! Meow!

[h1][b][u]THE RUNDOWN:[/u][/b][/h1]

[u][h3] STORY[/h3][/u] Fantastic. I don't want to give away too many details, but if you're wondering if a game with a nostalgic Pokemon feel can actually scare you, you'll have to try it out for yourself. ONE SPOILER THOUGH! I’ve even heard of a scare where something happens and the game crashes (on purpose) which would’ve scared the hell out of me if I wasn’t spoiled over it.

[u][h3] GAMEPLAY[/h3][/u] Great. Sure, there’s a bit of flaws with it, as sometimes it feels a bit too easy, but overall it was fun. If you want to buy this game for the gameplay alone, skip this title. You WILL NOT like the game.

I enjoy switching between the White Space and the real world to see what happens with Sunny (Omori's true self), and vice versa. In OMORI, the breaks for real-world activities resembled Persona. In OMORI, however, the breaks had a more significant effect on the plot, making me both excited and scared to find out what would happen next. Hands down my favorite part of the game.

[u][h3] VISUALS[/h3][/u] Visually stunning and really captures the theme of the story, which makes me like it even more. Honestly, I might not even like the game as much without it looking the way it does. Wait, horror put into this adorable pixel-art? Amazing and well executed, and incredibly unique!

Upon entering Black Space, the once charming pixel-art style takes on a disturbing quality. It scared the hell out of me. I loved it. Bravo, OMOCAT.

[u][h3] DIFFICULTY[/h3][/u] Average. I wish there was a difficulty setting, as sometimes I advanced too easily (considering I’ve played a few SMT games), to have that many problems. There were a couple of bosses that I appreciated with the difficulty spike raising up, though. It was alright at most points.

[u][h3] MUSIC & SFX[/h3][/u] Great. The music feels good, the horror elements and audio scares are good (and scary) as well. My favorite music track in the game was “It Means Everything.”, played during AUBREY’s boss fight. So surreal, so sad and so catchy.

[u][h3] VOICE ACTING[/h3][/u] N/A.

[u][h3] GRIND[/h3][/u] It can be there if you choose so. It's not a biggie, but you may want to grind a bit for those difficulty-spiked bosses I mentioned. Just do a few sidequests, and you’ll be fine. Speaking of which…

[u][h3] EXTRAS & SIDE QUESTS[/h3][/u] Pretty good and fair! There's a bunch of 'em, and sure, there might be some that make you feel baffled trying to figure out where to go. It's just about as good as any other game with simple side missions.

The extras, however, are amazing. Considering how many multiple endings there are and even some REALLY... scary areas, etc., this is impressive. More about that in the replayability section!

[u][h3] GAME TIME[/h3][/u] The game doesn’t overstay its welcome; it’s just about right. Maybe there could’ve been a few more areas along with 2-3 more days in the game, but for most people, it’s well paced.

[u][h3] END-GAME CONTENT[/h3][/u] N/A.

[u][h3] REPLAYABILITY[/h3][/u] Definitely replay this game a few times. There are multiple endings and paths to choose when you play. Choices matter in this game. Let things unfold naturally without researching them first. If you want the biggest impact for yourself, play without Google, at least for the first time around!

[u][h3] PRICE[/h3][/u] Undoubtedly great, and I hope more people support this indie studio! So glad to see it’s coming to consoles soon, which is exciting! I think everyone saw that coming.

OMOCAT actually started out as a clothing brand. You can now buy new artwork, plushies, and various other things on OMOCAT’s site! In fact, if I’m not mistaken, OMOCAT is an actual… person? And that's your daily dose of fun facts! Nice!

[u][h3] BUGS[/h3][/u] None. No... (MAJOR GAMEPLAY SCARE SPOILER) when the game crashes after you collect all the hangman keys, that was supposed to happen!

[u][h3] PC REQUIREMENTS[/h3][/u] Pretty low. I put “Decent” above, but honestly a potato could probably end up running this game! Not a bad thing, though!

[u][h3] AUDIENCE[/h3][/u] Strictly for adults. Okay... maybe some teens. Apparently, this game brings comfort to some people. I am not sure how, as it was pretty darn depressing. I’m going against the majority and telling you that if you have depression or suicidal thoughts, you should probably stay away from this game!

A storytelling MASTERPIECE. I haven't been able to get over this game since I played it in 2020, so forgive me for not writing a review sooner. I've obtained every possible ending, along with every achievement on the hikkikomori route, so let me say...PLEASE PLAY THIS GAME. ITS AMAZING.
damn...

Omori is a simple psychological fantasy bloated with a long run time and conflicted thematic execution. The few sidequests are simple nothings. I feel no connection to the main world of this game due to the very premise of it being a fantasy of twee concessions and power. I understand it's supposed to be this way. Your friends are supposed to be simple caricatures. The whole world is, but it isn't worth twenty hours. Sad pirate man or repetitive laughter lady isn't worth twenty hours. 
I know what they're meant to represent, but it's under-baked.

Mechanically, the combat is decent for most of the game. Its simplicity is complimented by interactions between party members and how they synchronize. The phobias are hardly relevant aside from sadboy aesthetics and roadblocks. The few plot points smash you over the head more fervently than a semaphore at a whack-a-mole convention. By the time the plot's mysteries are uncovered, Omori stumbles over the intersection between real world complications and surrealism (when it should've focused on the latter). This is relevant because the late sections agonize over these points for so long that it becomes the gameplay via walking simulator. The Yume Nikki slop has some good bits in it, but there's little reason for it aside from intertextual hooplah. Travelling through every memory already repeatedly mentioned throughout the game adds more head injuries to count.
 
I spent a while deciding whether I liked this game or not. I still played through it, which says something. I've grown up on rental junk, with some games being wildly ambitious treasures scuffed by odd decisions, or even improved by ones normally counter-intuitive, yet evocative of the human experience in a way that sparks my neurons. 
This isn't one of those games, but it's filled with 'stuff'. It's artistically well-made, intricate stuff. It's musical stings that only appear for one fleeting moment. It's specialized animations for everything. It's digipet rock-paper-scissors. There's so much stuff just floating about, but it doesn't have much to serve.

Summary:
There is nothing more banal than a neet's imagination. It's full of sound and fury, signifying nothing until the tantrums stop and it recedes into a forty hour moe binge.

[b]Omori[/b], an RPG about exploring a dreamscape of it’s main character.
That’s the shortest description I could make for the game, however this game is so much more.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Let’s start with gameplay and mechanics:

You simply explore the dreamscape talking to characters and encountering enemies in aim to progress the story by getting done whatever situation or problem is at hand.

It’s an RPG game, so expect experience, leveling up, equipment, skills/spells and “classes” (this last thing in the loosest way of the term).

Battles spot a simple, yet dynamic system of interchanging strengths and weaknesses paired with a rock paper scissor mechanic, where one status (or emotion in this case) will be always weak to an emotion, and strong against another one, so learn how to swap, manipulate and play around with them to ensure victory.

[h1]Story[/h1]
This game strong suit, accompanied with a very cute “pencil and pastel” art direction, it will grab you for a journey through a young man working through some stuff that happened in life…
And I’ll stop here not to spoil anything more other than saying that writing may be a little generic at the start and middle point but picks up speed in many moments and especially in the later part.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
This title is one the best example of a game tying narrative and gameplay mechanics as one.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
Sometimes you’ll end up wandering directionless because you’ve missed a detail, some other times some sections of the game where not much happens drag on for a bit to long, but these are just nitpicks not actual criticism.
[hr][/hr]

[spoiler]This game perfectly describes the escapism we suffer from the internet and its consequences in our lives.
Let me explain; as in HEADSPACE, our internet friends are not real. They can't comfort you nor stay with you by your side if you are feeling depressed. In fact, they can betray you, backstab you, doxx you, and more with no consequences which is worrisome to even think about it. They do not do it at first because it is their "good will" but they can always do it if there is any reason or motive to do so.

Maybe "real" friends are not perfect but i think it is the better choice, reality always beats fiction although it could be a more pleasant experience.

On the other hand, escapism is an option if you don't have any friends. It may be your only thing you have to cope with[/spoiler]

So I've played this game a few times now, or rather I played it once and watched my friends play it. And in short, this game is good and I can't recommend it enough, I waited for it to go off sale before I bought it because of how much I enjoyed it. Now in long, I think this game really captures a specific feeling. It's story is very relatable, I've been in a similar situation with a friend group falling out and everyone doing their own thing. It's easy to get very distant in those situations and this game captures that feeling super well. However, when I was younger, I lost a really good friend. He would come over all the time and we'd play with action figures and watch batman, yk really cool stuff. At the time, I can't remember how I took it. All I remember is the funeral, and referencing the silly things he'd say while playing with his stormtrooper figures. While playing this game, he's all I could think about, and I appreciate it for that. Because it's not often that I can relate to feelings that games, movies, or songs capture this well. So if you want a good cry get this game :)

OMORI is a turn based RPG game which centres mainly around the main cast of characters in the dream world and the overworld.

PLEASE [i]PLEASE [/i]PLAY THIS GAME BLIND, THE STORY AND CHARACTERS ARE THE STRONGEST PART!!!

The ONLY downside of the game is how long it takes to beat. Even just focusing the main story will probably take you about 15-20 hours. It took me 45 on my first run trying to do everything I could.

EVERYTHING ELSE is perfect:
- The turn based gameplay is deep, progressively more challenging and really rewarding
- There's a TON of stuff to do, lots of areas, sidequests, items, battles, and story stuff
- The characters, both main and side, are amazing and all really interesting and unique
- Dialogue is great and it's really fun watching all the characters interact
- Music varies between decent and ABSOLUTE BANGERS, but always fits the mood of whatever's happening
- The story is really emotional and INCREDIBLY good, especially with how it slowly unfolds without giving everything away, but just enough to hint at what's actually happening
- Seriously play this game for the story if nothing else, battles might be a grind but trust me it is SO worth it

This game is terrifying. It absolutely NAILS the horror parts. Maybe 90% of the game is normal and friendly, so when the horror kicks in you feel it. There's a few jumpscares, but most of it comes from how god damn unnerving the game feels. The slow increase of strange and creepy things is something you notice and can tell is happening but just having to push on through. Weird things hidden all over the place that you're not sure if they have meaning, or are just some strange thing to find. The slow move to full psychological horror at the end of each segment where you are completely helpless and can only go head on into whatever nightmares await you is amazing. The atmosphere and vibe of the game will flip immediately. When the game turns on nightmare mode, it makes sure you know it.

In conclusion, if you like turn based RPGs, an amazing story, a really great cast of characters or any of the above then PLAY THIS GAME.
